reviews.reviewTitle: USELESS WARRANTY--DESIGNED TO THWART RETURN OF DEFECTIVE UNITS
reviews.reviewText:
BUYERS, BEWARE! CUISINART'S "LIMITED WARRANTY' MAY BE LEGAL, BUT IT'S NEAR-FRAUDULENT!

I bought this kettle in September, 2015 and it failed in December, 2015. The one-year warranty is USELESS. When I called for troubleshooting, they shipped me a replacement for the base. The replacement took almost a month to arrive, and was dead on arrival. It may have been defective, but most likely, the kettle was at fault. When I called to request that they replace the kettle, I discovered that (1) I'd have to ship the kettle back to them first, and (2) I'd need to enclose an extra $15 payment to cover Cuisinart's return shipping expense for the replacement unit...because the kettle only has "a limited warranty." So (counting $15, plus my own packaging and shipping cost) I'm being to told to expend at least $30 in order to get a replacement for a unit I had for three months--a unit that has never been abused or mistreated in any way.
This is a PREMIUM product. It should have a PREMIUM warranty policy--just ship me the replacement, place a hold on my credit card until I return the bad one in the replacement packaging, etc. And the manufacturer pays for shipping both ways. This is common practice for other high-end products (and most Amazon returns), and I think it's inexcusable that Cuisinart takes an approach that seems DESIGNED TO AVOID having to honor their warranty.
The representative was polite and professional throughout, but could not allow me to speak to her supervisor "because of the heavy call volume."
She gave me the runaround; it's not her fault, she's just doing her job. Like any employee, she has to carry out her employer's policy. But Cuisinart's policy in INEXCUSABLE; it's not worth paying to replace the unit, and I'm never buying any Cuisinart product again.

DO NOT BUY THIS UNIT IF YOU EVER EXPECT TO NEED SERVICE UNDER WARRANTY!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Dangerous flaw and not built to last
reviews.reviewText:
UPDATE: I am updating this review after discovering a dangerous flaw with this kettle. The kettle is supposed to shut off automatically when it boils, and it usually does, but every couple of weeks it just doesn't, and just continues to boil, even though all lights are off. Luckily I've been home every time this has happened, and so I unplugged it to turn it off. Even lifting it off the base doesn't turn it off, as it just starts boiling again when you put it down. If it was left like this, the water would all boil away, and since the kettle thinks it's already off, I'm not sure what would happen at that point. It has a feature that turns it off when there's no water in it, but that works when its on, and I'm not sure if it would work when it thinks it's off. I reported this to Cuisinart customer service but other than offering me a 20% discount on a new one, didn't seem to be too concerned.

I had high hopes for this kettle, as it had some features I wanted, but in usage its not all that great, and the durability is poor. The first issue was the warning sound it makes when it boils, a critical feature. Its pretty much inaudible, 3 beeps from a circuit board mounted device that can't even be heard over the boiling water its so quiet. Since it auto shuts off once boiling, you end up walking over to it to check on it, and then have to restart it and wait for 30 seconds as it reboils. As well, all the lettering from the buttons wears away within a few weeks, and now my lid has failed, and won't open when I hit the button, so I have to pry it open with my fingernails. The lid can't be removed for cleaning inside. There is also some kind of dark stain on the bottom of it even though its only ever had tap water in it. Not sure what this brown stuff is but given all the other issues, this is not a kettle I would recommend, and now I have to buy another kettle after spending a lot of money on this one. I have Milwaukee power tools that cost less and have a 5 year warranty, so I'm not sure why Cuisinart can't do a little better.

reviews.reviewTitle: The slow demise until entropy takes over!
reviews.reviewText:
Purchased this product from Amazon on May the 8th 2013 and today (8/12/16) three years later it has expired. This was a great kettle for the first year of ownership we really liked it to begin with.
During the first year it lost it's button decals, we though that's OK we can deal with it, it still works so we nursed it along for a while.
Then in the second year now and again it started to just boil and boil without stopping, eventually it wouldn't stop boiling so we kept our eyes on it and turned it off when the water was ready.
Now it just warms up a bit and beeps miserably.
Time to give up with technology and get a whistling stovetop model "KitchenAid KTEN20CBPR 2.0-Quart Kettle with C Handle and Trim Band - Pyrite" this should last longer than three years and is much cheaper.

reviews.reviewTitle: Tea kettle speed test: Cuisinart CPK-17 vs. Miroco MI-EK001. Are they comparable?
reviews.reviewText:
Several reputable consumer tests rank the Cuisinart CPK-17 adjustable temperature tea kettle at the very top. That caught my eye. But so did its high price--almost double the also nicely designed Miroco MI-EK001. Both have the same 1.7 liter (57 ounce) capacity, with very similar features. I bought the Cuisinart first but was intrigued by the Miroco at roughly half the price so I bought it, too. I had earlier compared the Hamilton Beach 41020 to the Cuisinart but found its workmanship not nearly as good, and its lack of temperature accuracy disappointing. In my opinion, the highest quality appliances should be fairly priced, but reliable and also of long term value.

Spoiler alert! Can the Miroco compete at half the price? REMARKABLY WELL although its features are not identical. The Cuisinart does offer offer small convenience advantages depending on your household’s priorities.

Cuisinart CPK-17 vs. Miroco MI-EK001/ Design:
As you can see in the photos, both designs are similar, but not identical. The Cuisinart weighs a couple of ounces more than the Miroco, noticeable when filling when empty but not when pouring with water inside. The Miroco has a slightly wider pop up lid with two separate buttons for opening and closing. That may make the Moroco easier to fill for those with less pouring dexterity, yet both models have ample filling room.

For better balance with the Cuisinart I have to “choke up” (a baseball term) on it’s handle with my fingers over the temp controls but this has never been a problem. Before trying the Miroco, I thought its squared-off shape handle might be uncomfortable. However, since I have medium sized hands, I prefer it to the Cuisinart’s slightly more bulbous handle. All things considered, the ergonomics of the handle on the Miroco is a small advantage.

Cuisinart CPK-17 tea kettle vs. Miroco MI-EK001 / Workmanship:
This was a very pleasant surprise. When I compared the Hamilton Beach near clone of the Cuisinart, one big difference was cheaper workmanship for the HB. No so with the Moroco. Beautiful, smoothly machined and solid. Both brands are quality appliances and impressively built. Both have similar fill windows that turn a pleasant blue while on. The Cuisinart only shows liters while the Microco shows cups as well as liters. I find the Miroco slightly easier to read. While the lid designs are different, I prefer Cuisinart’s open button which can be accomplished one handed. For the Miroco, using only one hand, you can’t open the lid at the same time as holding the handle.

Cuisinart CPK-17 vs. Miroco MI-EK001 / Temp choices and features:
The two kettles have virtually the same features. As you can see in the photo, the design approaches are different. Both have a great feature that will allow you to hold the brewing temp for another 30 minutes. So, what is different between the two brands? For the Cuisinart, the keep warm feature is on by default—it can also easily be turned off—either before or after brewing. For the Miroco, the default is off and the keep warm button must be pressed manually. Due to busy mornings in our house, I prefer the Cuisinart design with the default to be on automatically. As an example, I typically wake up first, have a cup of green tea brewed at the proper 175 degrees and then wait for my wife to join me. Everything is ready to go with no additional button pushes needed. Later, we’ll pour water for oatmeal for our daughter. All can be poured at the same temp held by the kettle. However, if you typically would not need a second cup, perhaps you might prefer the Miroco approach. Turning on its keep warm feature is easy, especially before brewing.

Since we pour multiple cups, one other Cuisinart advantage we really like is a memory feature. If you take the kettle off the base, then return it to the base within a couple of minutes, the Cuisinart keeps the temperature and hold setting. As soon as the Miroco is removed to pour, when returned to the base, the tea kettle is fully shut off. This may be a disadvantage for some. However, to get back to the settings to hold the kettle for 30 minutes longer requires a few quick button presses, easy to do in only takes a couple of seconds. You just need to get in the habit of remembering.

Cuisinart CPK-17 vs. Miroco MI-EK001 / All important performance tests:
As both are 1500 watts, each has terrific, fast speed far surpassing stovetop kettles or microwave heating. For a full 1.7 liter pot (57 ounces), the Cuisinart shut off at the 212 degree boiling point in 7:06. The Miroco took 7:35. In everyday real world usage, this is not a meaningful difference yet the Cuisinart is slightly faster. For 24 ounces, the Cuisinart finished in just 3:31 and for 16 ounces, it was done in only 2:32. The Miroco was not far behind. Plenty quick all around.

At the green tea setting of 175 degrees, the Cuisinart took just 2:22 for 24 ounces, and a terrific 1:40 for 16 ounces. The Miroco finished 24 ounces in 2:40, and for 16 ounces, just 1:52.

Both of these pots are very well insulated. Even an hour or two after turning off, the water inside is still plenty hot. If initially set to boil, a full hour after turning off the Moroco is still at 178, while the Cuisinart is slightly cooler at 167. Each can be brought back to a full boil in just a minute or two, depending on how much water is inside.

Cuisinart CPK-17 vs. Miroco MI-EK001 / Temperature consistency:
When brewing to 212 degrees, both brands hit the boiling point and are ready to pour. Yet, it is likely that in buying a versatile temp variable kettle like these, you may also care about consistency at different temperatures, and in using the keep warm setting. For example, Chinese green teas are best brewed between 170 and 180, while delicate Japanese Senchas benefit from 10 degrees cooler yet. When using each kettle’s 175 degree setting for green tea, as soon as the brewer beeped and stopped, I used a Thermapen instant read thermometer and learned the Cuisinart measured 176 degrees. Excelllent performance indeed!

For the same test at the 175 degree setting, the Miroco was 182 degrees but quickly dropped down into the mid to upper 170s. Whatever your preferred brewing temp, keep in mind that as soon as the water hits your cup, it will cool slightly more. Thus, the Miroco’s performance was also quite good—far more consistent than the less than satisfying Hamilton Beach clone of the Cuisinart I reviewed earlier.

What about temp consistency using keep warm feature? Once desired temp is reached, each kettle will sit idle until the internal water temp drops 6-8 degrees. Then a sensor kicks in, very briefly turns on the kettle for mere seconds, bringing the temp back in range. Both brands did well using the keep warm setting.

Cuisinart CPK-17 vs. Miroco MI-EK001 / Warranty and the long term:
Although Cuisinart has a laudable three-year warranty, several reviewers here complain that obtaining warranty service can be cumbersome and that the units sometimes go out before the warranty has expired. The buyer must pay for warranty shipping both ways. I paid $4 extra for the Assurant extended warranty. However, most warranties of this type only kick in after manufacturer warranty expires. Keeping fingers crossed! We own four Cuisinart small kitchen appliances and have never needed warranty service, happily. My original Cuisinart food processor works great after 30 years.

Concerning the CPK-17 kettle, several reviews state the number markings can rub off in time. This is not a concern with Miroco’s design—the markings lie beneath an acetate covering. Miroco’s warranty is 18 months warranty plus an 18-month extension with registration.

Cuisinart CPK-17 vs. Miroco MI-EK001 / Conclusion: These are both five star machines. We are keeping the Cuisinart at our main home and the Miroco at our vacation home. The differences between Cuisinart and Miroco are mainly differentiated by three things: 1) The keep warm feature is the automatic default for the Cuisinart but can easily turned on with the Miroco. 2) The Cuisinart has a handy two-minute memory feature that remembers the keep warm temp setting if the kettle is removed, then returned to the base. 3) If those features are considered crucial to some, the Cuisinart runs nearly double the cost, yet is well known brand name with a long term track record.

reviews.reviewTitle: Failed product and weak customer service follow-up
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this product in September 2015 for a little over $80. By December it had ceased to work at all. After multiple email and telephone exchanges seeking to verify the serial number and assure that the product was not used commercially (it was not), I was informed that the the product was covered by a "Limited" warranty, meaning that I would have to pay to return the product to Cuisinart and pay $15 for shipping and handling for a replacement product. I think it is unacceptable for a reputable manufacturer to sell a product that has clearly failed (in under 3 months of use) and expect the customer to pay to have the product replaced. Replacement of the product in this situation should be "no questions asked" and at no cost to the customer. Furthermore, I can't understand why Cuisinart would not want me to return the failed product so that they can figure why it failed. Unless they already know ...

Update: After much back and forth, Cuisinart offered to waive the $15 replacement service fee, but would not take responsibility for the cost of returning the defective device. I refused and have recycled the kettle. Coincidently, I had a recent customer service issue with a Cuisinart competitor, SharkNinja. In this case SharkNinja offered to replace the defective product. They wanted me to return the defective device so that their engineers could determine the reason for the failure. They immediately shipped a replacement, and emailed a pre-paid shipping label for the return. That's how a warranty and customer service are supposed to work! I'll never buy another Cuisinart product.

We have loved this electric water kettle, until it just went belly up a year and a half after buying it.
You'd think that a Cuisinart product would last better than this. So sad.

UPDATE:
Since this kettle was under warranty, I applied for a replacement with Cuisinart. It has now been over two months of submitting documents and phone calls and I have yet received my replacement unit. I, for one, cannot recommend buying Cuisinart appliances as they do NOT HONOR their guarantees.

reviews.reviewTitle: They use REFURBISHED PARTS and pack the product inadequatly.
reviews.reviewText: The online description said nothing about using refurbished parts. However the product I received had refurbished "genuine Cuisinart parts". Among other things, that meant it has only a 90 day warranty. It is dishonest to describe a product as new and send one with refurbished parts. There was no protective bubble or other material inside either the outer box nor inside the inner box. The inner box has a dent in it. Do not buy this product online.

Electric Kettle stopped working after 5 month. Cuisinart offered to replace it under their warranty, but I have to pay for shipping both ways ($15 for one way shipping) and wait 7 to 8 business days for replacement to be shipped. Why should I pay $30 and wait so long for a defective product replacement? Low quality product and useless warranty.

reviews.reviewTitle: Too expensive when it doesn't last
reviews.reviewText:
So why 2 Stars you wonder?
Well I've had this Kettle for 2 years (if that) and the Kettle Still works. So I shouldn't complain right? I mean it looks great, it boils water to different temperatures and its cordless.

Well for $80 bucks I expect the Kettle to last me for more than 2 years without issues. I mean I could have bought 2 cheap kettles and still be out ahead. OK - Get the point you say? OK - I will

A little under a year the numbers rubbed off. OK - I was a little disappointed but I made due besides I only use 3 buttons (four if you count the lid opening button) but I made stickers for the buttons (which fell off about a month of use).
Then about six months ago the lid began to get stuck and would need assistance to get opened. OK - even more disappointed but you know make due with what you've got.
Last week the lid stop opening all together (can't pry it open) and now we have to pour the water in thru the spout (so much fun).

So for $80 plus shipping I am very disappointed with Cuisinart. I wouldn't recommend it go with a cheaper version and if it breaks you are still out ahead.

This teapot is great. Heat water to specific temperatures for green tea, white tea, French press coffee, etc.
Teapot heats 10 times faster (so more cheaply) than a stove-top kettle. This teapot is great.

18 months later, it leaks internally and there is water all over the counter. Cuisinart says box it up with proof of purchase and a check for $15 and mail it to Arizona and get a replacement (guaranteed ?). A common complaint in the reviews is that the pot leaks. Do I want to take a chance? Sort of like sticking your hand in the fire a second time to see if it's really hot.

$15 and $15 more to ship it and a two-week turn-around if I'm lucky? Naaaah. I just ordered the Amazon's choice Secura teapot for $30 that has 4 1/2 stars on 4000 reviews

reviews.reviewTitle: Day 1: Wouldn't stop boiling and rust formed on inside bottom of kettle :-(
reviews.reviewText: My niece had this kettle and I came to love it, so when my old kettle was dropped and stopped working properly, (wouldn't stop boiling) I decided to buy this one when it came down in price. As you can tell from my title, it was a big fail!!! On day one it would beep when the water reached a boil, BUT it wouldn't switch to the "Keep Warm" mode. Instead, it just boiled and boiled and boiled. Initially, I was going to have Amazon replace it. However, when I went to package it back up, I noticed spots on the inside bottom of the kettle. Some were the type you get after extended use, that you can clean by soaking with vinegar. It was very odd these spots appeared after just one day of use. What was even more disturbing was some of those spots were rust. Needless to say I am looking for another brand/model. I am wondering if Cuisinart cheapened the kettle since my niece purchased hers. A stainless steel kettle should not be showing rust after just a few uses. A $100 retail price kettle should stop boiling when it reaches temperature. Just a big disappointment.

Purchased the CPK-17 in August 2014. Loved it until Jan 2017 when the pop-up lid stopped popping up; had to use a fingernail to lift it fully. Because it was still under the 3-year warranty, Cuisinart replaced it no questions asked.

Now, 19 months later, the pop-up lid suddenly is locked in a closed position. No matter what, it will not open. Just called Cuisinart about it only to learn that the 3-year warranty is based on the original purchase. In other words, I'm out of luck.

Decided not to risk going through all of this again and just ordered the Hamilton Beach, which is priced considerably lower anyway.

reviews.reviewTitle: For way more than just making tea
reviews.reviewText: This thing is great. We use it every day and for way more than just making tea which is what we bought it for. Anything you need to boil water for, this is how you should do it. Leave the pot and stove along and boil it in this. Need to heat milk for the baby? Set to 185-190, when done, pour in a bowl and set the milk in this. Won't scorch the milk and you have total control over the temperature so it won't get too hot for the baby. Don't put the milk in the kettle though, that's a bad idea....so I've been told. We loved this thing so much and must have used it 3 to 4 times a day for the last 5+ years and still holding strong. We loved it so much we've given them as gifts and had other people buy them after visiting. It has to be the most used appliance in our house. If you have kids, get this, and forget the bottle warmer. You will be heating milk, making oatmeal, and making noodles for a long time and this will do it faster than anything else.

reviews.reviewTitle: Get the Bonavita Gooseneck kettle instead
reviews.reviewText:
Get the Bonavita Gooseneck kettle instead. I had one for several years but eventually it started to leak around the gooseneck because I'd put pressure on the neck too many times. I decided to try this one since there's no long neck to leak. Sadly, though, it has the following deficiencies:
- If "on", it defaults to "keep warm" when returned to the stand within a few minutes, which may cause you to boil it dry if you return it empty (we already did this several times)
- The last 250ml or so is very hard to get out of the kettle
- For the last 400ml or so it dribbles instead of pouring smoothly
- The temperature range for "keep warm" is somewhat wide for making consistent coffee/tea
- It only has a few temperature settings (the Bonavita Gooseneck kettle will do any temperature and keep +- 1 degree)

reviews.reviewTitle: Leaks. Warranty sucks. Wirecutter recommendation is bad.
reviews.reviewText:
Initially we liked the features of the kettle. After 3 years of daily use this started leaking all over the counter if it was more than halfway to the max line. Given other reviewers' thoughts on Cuisineart's warranty I'm not even going to try.

I am SO tired of sending appliances to landfill. It's horrible for the environment but I feel like I don't have a choice. My mother had the same kettle for 30 years. I'd be very willing to pay good money for something that was backed be a customer-friendly 30 year warranty. If someone knows of something like that please comment on my review.

No more Cuisineart products for me. And Wirecutter recommendations are getting second thoughts too.

reviews.reviewTitle: It smells and I’ve tried everything!
reviews.reviewText:
I love making hot tea and hot chocolate in the fall and wintertime so I thought an electric kettle would be easier to use than just a pot on the stove especially with the temperature control.
The kettle works great, but I have a major complaint that is making me want to throw this kettle away. It smells! I have tried regular soap, vinegar, baking soda + vinegar mixtures along with actual descaling cleaning products to no avail. I’ve researched this over and over and cannot find a single solution that works. I’m beginning to think it’s related to the plastic inside the unit. I really hate to throw this away bc i paid the full amount for it and it’s a nice, sleek design, but I cannot forgive a smelly batch of boiled water. Would not recommend.

I splurged for the expensive Cuisinart brand over the $19.99 Hamilton and regret it. We bought this kettle in May and it began leaking in October. I woke up to water all over my counter and damaged items out on the counter that were soaked and ruined. I have emailed Cuisinart with no reply. Now I’m relacing it with a Hamilton kettle, which I should have chosen to begin with. I was being snobby and thought the expensive Cuisinart model looked sharper. This has a design flaw and Cuisinart should not keep selling it. Believe the reviews and choose a different brand electric kettle. I loved it and it worked great.. until it didn’t. ☹️

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't know what you've got til it's gone
reviews.reviewText: I didn't realize how much I really liked this kettle until I thought it died. I immediately searched my order history to buy it again, if it was still possible. Turns out I purchased it Oct 2010. I figured that seemed like a good long life, longer than my computers, so I quickly ordered another one. Then I found I had unwittingly pushed a test button on my electric outlet so it wasn't truly dead. I decided not to cancel my current order because I want another one on hand when this one does die because it is a FANTASTIC kettle! Best I have used. Highly recommend!

reviews.reviewTitle: The outside will burn you after use
reviews.reviewText: I've been using a Black and Decker one of these things for many years. When I used this for the first time, the immediate thing I found out was that the outside was extremely hot, as opposed to the Black and Decker. For this reason only, I'm rating this a ONE and I wish I hadn't have gotten it. Not to mention that it's obvious the lettering on the handle will eventually rub off, as many people have reported. But it's the hotness of the outside that I think is a safety issue.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is my second (but for the right reasons)
reviews.reviewText: I bought one of these for our house during the winter of 2017. We absolutely LOVE it - couldn't be happier. Who would have thought changing from a stove-top teapot (which I only replaced because it wore out, since it a beautiful, hand-drawn piece I'd gotten as a gift years before) could totally change the way we use our kitchen? No more kettle getting inevitably full of cooked-on food spatter (since it had a permanent spot on the back burner). No more only having three burners available (for the same reason). No more worrying the pot would boil dry (because the whistle had stopped working quite a long time ago). And no more guestimating how long to leave the pot off the boil to reach the correct temperature for oolong or genmaicha, and no more bitter oolong or genmaicha because I guestimated how long to leave the pot off the bottle before pouring it over the tea. We love our electric kettle so much that I bought a second to give to my mom for Christmas this year (no more being afraid she'll forget to take the kettle off and maybe burn down her house)(semi-sarcastic concern). I can't wait for her to open it. She's going to love it as much as we do.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lasted a little over 3 years, may it rest in peace
reviews.reviewText: This was great while it worked, we are avid tea makers at home and this runs at least once a day! Sadly it finally gave its life yesterday after 3 plus years of service, hesitant to invest in another one, hopefully they make a more durable model.

Everyone should have a good electric kettle, but finding the right one is hard. This product falls right in the mid range of prices, but has qualities that make it better than the price tag. It has a large capacity in the reservoir and I can easily make 5 mugs of hot chocolate or tea to satisfy everyone immediately. I really like the variable temperature so that I can better gauge cool down time and do some subtle brewing as I learn more about teas. I also love the stay warm feature so that I can go back for a second cup any time. Even if it cools, don't worry, this heats a pot faster than a single mug in the microwave.
If asked a few days ago I would have nothing bad to say about this kettle, but having used it for just a little over a month and half, it has developed a squeal when it brews. I can't figure out why and it is a bit ear piercing. It was pretty silent until now. If I figure out what is up or someone else knows, I will pass it along.

reviews.reviewTitle: Auto Shut Off Feature Failed, Then Warranty!
reviews.reviewText: Twice within the first year this kettle failed to shut off automatically and just kept boiling. Then twice it beeped that the water had reached boiling and it was barely tepid. This is a crappy product, actually made by Conair. The old Cuisinart name means nothing anymore. This is a really dangerous product flaw and I reported it to The Consumer Product Safety Commission. I filed a warranty request but instead of receiving a replacement, I was asked to return the defective kettle and fill out a form that asks questions like "Did you read the instructions?" So they expect me to sit and wait for their "engineers" to find out what is wrong with this kettle when in 2019, mine is not the only one that has experienced this flaw. Do not buy this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Kettle died after a few months and Cuisinart would only replace it if I paid to ship both the defective and replacement units
reviews.reviewText:
The kettle died after only a few months of normal use. When it starts heating, it will turn on like it's going to work and then beep like it's done within a few seconds. Sometimes it doesn't turn on at all.

I contacted Cuisinart customer service and after several exchanges back and forth over the course of over a month (it takes them an average of 5-7 days to respond to each email), they said that they would replace the kettle, but that I would have to pay for shipping the defective kettle back to them and shipping for the new kettle to me. After calculating the cost of shipping, it was barely going to save me money over buying a new kettle, and from what I've read this is a common issue for theses kettles so the same issue might happen again.

I would not recommend this kettle or any Cuisinart product based on both poor quality and customer service.

reviews.reviewTitle: Button to open lid is stuck, now lid won't close.
reviews.reviewText:
I was impressed with this kettle, boiled water quickly and provided pretty accurate water temp for my tea.

I was surprised after just 2 months when the button to open the lid became stuck when depressed. Now the lid will not stay closed.

Very disappointing for a Cuisinart product. I'm now holding for the manufacturer and will update this when I know how they will handle this.

Purchased this and used it infrequently. With that in mind, I was shocked when it stopped working altogether. Searching online, I was able to trace the problem with a faulty relay. Given that it's out of warranty, I ordered the part myself and it's time to do some DIY fixing. With that said, while I wait for the relay, I will need to purchase a different item because I don't want to give money to a company which seems to have frequent quality issues, and uses very cheap parts (the relays should be rated for 20M actuations, and believe me, I haven't used it 20 million times since I purchased it).

We bought this to replace a stovetop kettle, for a faster boil.
After about 1-2 months the kid piece broke off (this kettle stays in one place unless it’s being filled with water, or pouring water, never once fell), that piece wouldn’t go back on.
The kettle still worked, but we couldn’t open the lid for fear that we would lose the mecanisms that kept the lid shut.
Well today, almost one year after purchasing, the kettle stopped working, it won’t heat water, and it just beeps at you.

reviews.reviewTitle: #1 Kettle - Far Better Than Its Competitors
reviews.reviewText: When our old Cuisinart CPK-17 PerfecTemp 1.7-Liter Stainless Steel Cordless Electric Kettle finally reached the end of its all too brief lifespan (3 years) we decided to explore a few alternatives to see if there might be anything better available, something equally efficient, but more durable. After ordering several other models: a Secura, a Hamilton Beach, a Breville, a Nexia, a Cuisinart DK-17 Cordless Stainless Steel Electric Kettle, all of which failed to meet the standard we were seeking, we ultimately decided to replace like with like, and duly reordered this one. It is undoubtedly far superior to every other kettle we tried, so we are happy, and our only concern is that it will live longer than our old deceased one that had started to leak and to become somewhat unreliable in its temperature selection functionality...

We love these kettles which get used at least 10 times a day for various teas and coffee and boiling water for other cooking/baking projects. The various temperature choices are wonderful, since we use different teas and several coffee brewing methods which have various optimal brewing temperatures. The kettles and the temperature controls have been 5 Star. The computer element Has been the weak link for both units we’ve owned. The first lasted not quite 5 years, and our current one fritzed out this morning after just 3 years of use. No rust, the number pads and the kettle look great, love the heavy, solid metal construction, but useless now that it’s lost it’s brain. I think 3-5 years is not an impressive enough lifespan to keep investing $80 into a tea kettle, no matter how great it’s functionality. I just purchased the Hamilton Beach that looks identical to this one for $30 less. If we only get 3 years out of that one we will still be coming out ahead.

reviews.reviewTitle: After a week it started to STINK and gunk swelled up inside on the bottom
reviews.reviewText: Yes, it was thoroughly cleaned, multiple times. About a week or so after use some really odd smelling gunk started to swell up in the seam at the very bottom of the pot (inside) and I tried to clean it using vinegar and whatever it was started to disintegrate and was so nasty and toxic smelling I threw it out. Which really sucks... because we bought one and used it for about 2 years until it started to make really loud popping sounds - which was why we replaced it with another one. Not going to do that again.

reviews.reviewTitle: My microwave is never used anymore
reviews.reviewText:
I had wanted to purchase a kettle for awhile but never seemed to muster up the will to do so. However, we drink a lot of tea in my house and my microwave was always going. To save it - and a bit on my electric bill - I chose this item based on its features, reviews, and brand reputation.
While my family was skeptical, I've heard more than once since I purchased this a few months ago that it's one of the best "gadgets" ever. Everyone uses it, the temperature controls are excellent (and were what sold me on this model), and I use it more than I would have thought. For example, when I make broth, I no longer heat it on the stove or in the microwave. I just hit the boil function on this and pour into my cup. It saves time, energy, and cleaning more stuff.
Definitely worth the money and counter space (it replaced my coffee maker because you can hit a button to boil water for the French press). Great product!

I purchased a $20 Hamilton Beach for the office and this stainless steel shiny beauty for my home. Guess which one still works and guess which one died after just a couple months? Hint: The one that still works doesn't in any way resemble this stainless steel paperweight and it cost 1/4 less. The Cusinart Doesn't heat water anymore. *You had one Job* - a major bust Cuisnart. For $100 it should probably work. Even for a year. I contacted support but you have to pay to return it and pay to ship it and I could get two of the cheap-o models. Last time for Cuisnart for this guy. Fool me once...

This thing worked on and off. i tried contacting the support but worst customer support. no call back , just waiting .
i was out of the return policy time.. it would not heat up, sometimes it worked sometimes it would not.
Just piece of junk. Cleaning this is nightmare, opening too small for even smaller hands.
I usually do not write reviews but this one deserves it

This is the second one of these I bought. Guess it's the last. This one lasted 6 months and the bottom started leaking. The previous one just quit working. Lit up but wouldn't boil. This time the bottom seal is apparently blown. I'm disgusted. Cuisinart should be better than this.

*Update 8/29/19: I thought I would share that I emailed Cuisinart through their contact form on the Cuisinart website. A representative responded to me and asked for the date I purchased my kettle, product serial number, and my mailing address. I responded. Two days later, I received another email asking me to send them my original receipt. I responded accordingly. Today I received a third email from Cuisinart that explains my kettle's manufacturer's warranty lasts only for 3 years and is expired, but that I am within a 6-month grace period. If I'd like, I can mail my kettle to an address they will provide to me at my own expense. This is all well and good, but I'm very frustrated that it took three email to tell me that I have no recourse for my suddenly broken kettle. Again, I've had enough of small appliances made with substandard materials that cost more money than they're worth. I'll be going back to basics with food preparation and will support any decent, consumer-friendly company that will manufacture a simple tea kettle or coffee maker with quality stainless steel and quality components. I hope more consumers will do the same. I'm sorry to say it, but products made in China are not made well nor are they made to last. Consumers have the ability to take a stand against poorly made products with their voices and their wallets.

* Update 7/11/19: This is a review of my third kettle. My first experience in 2011 was so good, I just had to try again. This kettle worked flawlessly for three years. Then suddenly and unexpectedly, the base went out and the kettle is now useless. Three years is not long enough for an $80 kettle to last, in my opinion. I'm moving on from Cuisinart.

2016: I actually purchased two of these kettles, the first in the fall of 2010 and the second, one year later. The first kettle worked great in every aspect, and is still working perfectly today in year 2016. No rust ever, but occasional mineral deposits that are easily removed with a vinegar rinse. The second kettle regrettably never worked, not even for a moment. I'm not sure if the kettle itself is faulty or if the problem is in the base. Due to my locale not having access to regular mail (extreme rural Alaska), it was simply too difficult to try to return it. My husband is still optimistic he can do something to make it work. If nothing else, perhaps the working part can be switched out with the first kettle when it finally fizzles out, whenever that is. So I have a mixed opinion: one kettle rates 5 stars while the other rates 0 stars. I'll be generous and give a mean review of 3 stars for the two. I'm interested in buying a new kettle to use while visiting family during a lengthy stay, but am concerned whether I'll receive a 0 star product or higher. Consistency in quality seems to be an issue, reading through a number of reviews. Here's hoping... By the way, I'm extremely appreciative to those genuine reviewers who are not posting as a result of obtaining their kettle 'with a discount in exchange for an honest and unbiased' review.' If this is where Amazon sellers are headed, I'm not biting.

Most of my kitchen is made up of Cuisinart products. They've always served me well and lasted a long time. So based on previous experience, I chose Cuisinart when I went looking for a cordless kettle. I noticed immediately that the lid on this kettle seemed to have trouble staying shut, but I brushed that off thinking it was intentionally created that way to keep from too much pressure building up or boiling over... I don't know. Anyway, within less than three weeks, the lid now will not shut at all. The "open" button (which is the button that releases the lid to open) is compressed all the way down, as if it's stuck somehow, and I can't get the lid to close. There's no parts missing, nothing broken, nothing chipped. It simply won't stay shut. I can still make tea/boil water in the kettle, but I need to put something heavy on the lid to keep it closed. That's not a solution for a product that I paid nearly $100 for! Plenty of lower priced kettles that have good reviews. I'm careful with my electronics, and I don't abuse my products. This is clearly a defect in the manufacturing, and that is something I find very disappointing for a brand such as Cuisinart. I will give them a call to see if there is something they can do for me, but from all I've been reading online, Cuisinart seems to have a poor reputation for replacing parts, such as this lid that isn't working anymore. And since my shipping box is gone, I can't return the order or I would have returned it through Amazon. Pretty bummed :(

LOVE LOVE LOVE my electric kettle. Been looking for years for just the right one. Heats up in seconds to minutes depending on how much water I'm boiling. Love that there are several heat options so I can boil the water at a lower temperature for the kids hot cocoa, etc. Also has a nice "stay warm" feature. I like to make my own Tazo Iced Tea which required you boil water and add to a specially designed pitcher. It used to be a tedious task having to boil "pots" of water (very timely) and try ever so carefully to not spill while transitioning to the pitcher. With this kettle I need to boil about 2 1/2 full and in under 5 minutes have my pitcher full ready to go! Love having the quick ability to boil a quick tea while running out of the house in the morning! Another nice feature is there is small filter that is removable located in the "pourer". Highly Recommend - great product. As far as downfalls, the lid is not removable and therefore you can not let air dry upside down. I air dry with lid open and clean wipe inside with a paper towel. Seems to dry just fine that way.

We had an older version before this one, and it worked for about 4 years, considering we are using a kettle religiously 5-6 times a day :-D The old one started leaking all of a sudden. So, this one, we had for few days, and this is what I have to say:
1) do not just rinse it before use as they recommend; boil it full and empty, few times, to make sure all the smell disappears
2) maybe it makes sense to finish the buttons with resin or some sort of sealer as the marks are going to erase soon (they did on our last one so I just printed “a cheat sheet” and kept it near (after being tired of writing them on with a sharpie only to watch them to dissolve again )))
3) it’s great that it has a 160F option. When we were researching, that was one of the factors as my daughter only uses this temperature
4) the light is definitely brighter on this one so it’s easier to see how much water is in it, especially considering that the scale is so conveniently located behind “in the armpit” ;)))))
5) the ready signal is definitely louder than it was in the previous model. They probably think that people only make tea when there is a loud party; or only old people with hearing impairments do that. It sounds a little like alarm clock so I’m going to ask my handy husband if he can adjust it so kids don’t wake up when the kettle is on in the middle of the night!
6) the “bump” on the base where you are supposed to position the kettle on, is taller and leaner than previous one, - too bad bc I was hoping to use both bases with one kettle (one for the basement), it’s easier to just carry the kettle rather than disconnect the base and connect it again , and so forth

Overall, happy with purchase. We’ll see how it goes later.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lost trust in the Cuisinart Brand
reviews.reviewText:
This kettle is fairly noisy compared to the new one I had to just buy to replace the CPK-17 after 10 months of use. The heating element failed and when I attempted to return it I was reminded the the warranty was "limited" so I would be responsible for shipping and handling in both directions to Glendale AZ. It doesn't seem to make sense to potentially pay up to 1/2 the cost of a unit to have it replaced/repaired.

This experience will definitely impact my decision to buy Cuisinart products in the future. Up until now I have been a fan as an owner of a food processor, coffee grinder and coffee maker. I would not recommend this product mostly as a result of the company's decision not to stand behind it.

This kettle is everything you could want! I use it mostly for french press coffee, but my guests have used it for various kinds of tea, instant oatmeal, or hot chocolate with great success.

I did a lot of research on these kettles, and I found that the one thing to avoid was kettles with plastic insides. Every single one with plastic innards had comments about plastic taste in the water. Stainless and glass interiors didn't have this problem, but glass was more susceptable to scale buildup. So I went with stainless. There aren't many of these kettles with stainless insides, and the ones there are are generally more expensive. I looked at the Breville and some others, but they were simply too much money. This one, while not cheap, offered a great feature set, accurate temperatures, stainless interior, good controls, unobstrusive base, and pretty nice aesthetics.

The kettle is easy to fill, solidly built, and heats water very fast. It finishes its heat cycle with an authoritative BEEP that I can hear from the next room as I watch Sports Center. Another bonus is that even once it has reached temperature, it will keep the water at that temperature for up to 30 minutes, so if I'm busy doing something else, my kettle can wait until I get there, and my water isn't too cold or too hot! The most important thing about a good cup of french press coffee, besides the beans, is the temperature of the water.

The base is very minimal and you don't even notice it when the kettle is sitting on it, it looks like one piece of the kettle. The controls are easy to reach while holding the kettle by the handle, and the little LED light on the water level indicator is bright and helps you see the water level in a dimly lit early morning kitchen. It also automatically shuts off after a bit if the kettle heat has been turned off. The kettle will turn off automatically after a certain amount of time, but it also is easy to turn off once you've poured out your needed water by pressing the "keep warm" button again.

Cleaning is as easy as making a water/white vinegar mixture and letting the kettle boil for 10-15 minutes, then rinsing it out a few times. This removes lime scale deposits and calcification.

For the build quality, looks, features, and performance, I can't rate this kettle high enough! Look no further!

reviews.reviewTitle: What did I do without this all these years?
reviews.reviewText:
Great product. I read a lot of the reviews, and really focused on the bad one's because I wanted to make an informed decision. I almost didn't buy this because of some of those reviews. However, I am not seeing any of the issues that others have shared and so far I'm absolutely thrilled with it. I love being able to make my more finicky teas with the proper temperature water. My tea is no long turning out bitter, or brewed improperly because of the water.

The only thing that I wish was a little different was the beep letting me know my water was ready. It's too quiet to hear in the next room. But then, I've been used to a whistling tea kettle. :-)

There were several negative reviews about the beeping, as in costant beeping. I figured out right away that it could do that if I didn't have it set up properly (user error), but could stop it immediately by tapping on the "START" button. It turns the kettle off immediately, which includes the beeping...

I purchased this pot in Nov. 2015. After about 9 months of use, the pot started to leak around the lower handle attachment. I contacted Cuisinart and they replaced the entire pot for $15 plus shipping return of the defective pot. The replacement made it about 4 months and it began leaking in the exact same place. I really like the product for accurate and safe heating without monitoring. Several temps to choose from. I am going to cut my losses and not pay for another replacement that may leak in a few months. The pot has "made in China" on the bottom. I seem to have much better experiences with German kitchen products.

reviews.reviewTitle: water tasted toxic. lots of plastic in contact with the water.
reviews.reviewText:
had to return it. ran a couple loads of water through it, and it still made my coffee have a distinct chemical taste. maybe it would wash out eventually, but i'd always be thinking that small amounts of something is leeching into my water. i'm not sure if it was the plastic or not, but this kettle does have a lot of plastic in contact with the water, including the window near the handle, an insert in the spout, and the bottom of the lid (water condenses and drips off the top.)

on the plus side, i measured the water temperature with a thermometer, and the kettle was very accurate - within 2F of the set temperature.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not buy, unless Amazon change return policy on this item.
reviews.reviewText:
Well... It's bought on February 16. First signs of trouble were noticed in April-May when I spotted some leaks on the bottom. It's disappeared pretty quickly, so I'm not sure what it was. However, couple days ago it's finally died. Base "sticked" to kettle and when it was separated (almost without force) kettle was not powered. I also can remember strange behavior when kettle randomly switched water temperature, about a month before death. As engineer, I believe leaking was an issue. It leaked constantly and finally destroyed all metal and electronic parts.
It makes me wonder, what are chances to get electrocuted from this lovely kettle. Based on others reviews, where leak is popular topic, I believe chances are real. So, if you like to play Russian Roulette, I'm very recommend this product, you will win sooner than later :(
As about return policy. It's month from day you got it, so Amazon will not accept return. Cuisinart return/repair policy is unclear. I can find policy for New Zealand, Canada, Europe but not for US on their website. Based on this link http://cuisinartsucks.com/cuisinarts-lifetime-warranty-not-worth-the-paper-it-is-printed-on, I believe their policy (as well as business practices) is scam. It means you will spend more money and will not receive repair/replacement.

reviews.reviewTitle: A good electric kettle for home
reviews.reviewText:
Pros:
- It works as advertised: Water is heated to the selected temperature.
- The "keep warm" feature is great
- It's easy to tell if the unit is on or off.

Cons:
- It's gotten slower over time. Nothing severe, but it takes maybe an extra minute now versus when I first got it.
- Cleaning the unit is somewhat difficult. I live in an area with very hard water, and will routinely rinse the unit out with some white vinegar. The top opening is too small for someone with large hands to reach in with a paper towel to get any excess calcite alone the base that a simple vingar boil didn't snag.
- The unit is loud. This is mostly because it's made of metal. Certainly not a deal breaker, but I'd be wary of using this in an office.

reviews.reviewTitle: A few problems with this kettle
reviews.reviewText: The first problem with this kettle is that it is hard to clean out. The opening is small and doesn't allow for one to really clean it out. After a couple of years it would occasionally fail to shut off. This causes it to be chucked into the trash as one doesn't need to have one's house burn down because of such a problem. Compared to cheaper models it doesn't perform better. This kettle was used often, and though it has all sorts of nifty buttons and looks good, being stainless steel, I'm going to buy a different kettle that is easier to clean and simpler.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very satisfied -- until it stopped working
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this kettle three years ago, in 2016, based on a personal recommendation, and I loved it. It boils (or heats to whatever temperature) water fast, has lots of nice settings including keep warm, sounds a gentle tone when the water is ready, and it's made by Cuisinart, a brand I trust. I have a lot of Cuisinart items in my kitchen. This teakettle has been used at least once and up to three times a day for the past three years.

Recently, its brain has started to become scrambled. Sometimes, after it boils water, it fails to stop boiling and just keeps going and going until I manually turn it off. Sometimes all the lights blink on and off rapidly and I have to unplug the whole thing to reboot. Often the keep warm function doesn't work, and I love that function as I can't always get to the kettle to pour as soon as it boils. Maybe there's just too much electronic paraphenalia in this device. Sometimes, simpler is better. I have just ordered the bestselling Secura (for less than half the price of the Cuisinart) and am hoping for the best.

reviews.reviewTitle: Loved it - until it leaked and flooded my counter.
reviews.reviewText: This kettle has great features but today, less than 11 months from purchasing the kettle, I woke up to over a liter of water on my counter. The kettle is leaking near the base, below the handle. Cuisinart’s return shipping policy is not cost effective to replace. It’s a shame, but it’s going into the garbage.

Do you love tea? Different kinds? Like to have them at the right temperature, and at a moments notice? I bought the CPK-17 from the Wirecutter's recommendations, and I'm very happy with the decision. Very fast to heat up water, even to a boil (black tea), but I mostly use it for green and herbal teas. Maintains the temperature too, but since I just drink single cups, I turn it off between steeps, and reheat, since the process only takes a minute. Obviously, if you fill the whole kettle, it will take longer for the water to heat up, but for 1~2 cups, it's really very fast. My only complaint would be, I wished the beep that notifies you the water is ready was a bit louder.

This is one of life’s little luxuries. Yes, you can heat water on top of the stove and the kettle will whistle when the water is hot.

The Cuisinart electric kettle, however, does much more: there is a gauge telling you how much water you are about to heat; you can select the temperature you prefer (essential for different varieties of tea); it beeps (politely) when the water is hot; and, best of all, it keeps the water hot for thirty minutes.

I have used this every day for the last month. I start it before shaving and showering, knowing the water will be ready to brew tea when I’m finished. Other pluses: the base makes it easy to lift and return the kettle; the unit is sleek and well designed; it blends easily with any décor.

A minor quibble: the gauge is in the metric system.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hard to beat for the price
reviews.reviewText:
While this review is only after 2 days of use, I wanted to leave initial impressions of the product. I almost did not purchase this item due to many reviews discussing the unit failing prematurely, rusting, problems with the buttons, noise, etc. While obviously to early to evaluate rusting or failure, I can comment on the other areas of this item.

Many reviews cite the loud beep of the buttons to be an issue. They have either lowered the volume due to these complaints, or folks have people sleeping with beds in the floor next to the unit. This unit is in my kitchen and when a button is pressed it does beep, however, the noise is hardly audible enough to be heard in the next room. The beep is slightly louder it seems to alert when your water temperature has been reached, but this is a feature I find valuable.

I have tested the preset water temperatures of the unit by inserting a digital thermometer and checking the temp right after the unit has turned off at each setting. The unit was lower than each setting by an average of 1 degree, which is certainly within margin of error and could well be due to my thermometer.

The item is well made and looks good on your counter, however, know that the exterior does water spot if splashed, so keep that in mind. Thusfar, very happy with this item and I will update the review if any other negatives pop up during my ownership.

I don't use this daily, I bought it for a cabin that we occasionally go to. Some users were not impressed by things that failed with frequent use, so I felt confident this would work for me longterm, and I feel like it will. Have used it several times, and it has been great. I can hear the beeps when it is ready, but it is not loud. The keep-warm function is an added bonus that few other pots had, and also love the temp selection, since we drink the gamut from french press coffee to every single tea listed on the buttons--it IS true that you do well to match the water temp to the tea so not to have bitter tea. Makes a huge difference.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lasted a year before it began tripping circuit breakers
reviews.reviewText: I'd give it zero stars if that were an option. Unfortunately, just around the year mark it would trip circuit breakers. Initially I assumed it was a wiring issue in our home. Nope, it was the kettle. It was lightly used and well maintained. If you do decide to risk it, purchase insurance.

Love this! I've been using it for a few weeks now and it's amazing. An old roommate had the breville variable temp, and if you can AFFORD it then I highly recommend that instead.
I went for the Cuisinart because of the bang for your buck. It's just as fast and beautiful as the breville: it works like a dream!
There are few differences in the machines especially in my opinion, and I saved $60! dollars going with the Cuisinart (I bought mine for $70). The breville is also SLIGHTLY larger, but having one before, it's not that inconvenient to just boil more water if you really need more. Besides, both kettles are so fast! The inconveniences that I think are worth saving $60 whole dollars on are: the opening to pour water into the machine is smaller, I anticipate the buttons rubbing off eventually (so says previous reviews), and the place where you can see the water level is just mildly inconvenient, but after a while that doesn't even bother me. Actually, what may bother some people more is that the cord is so small, so plan to put this appliance right next to the outlet (not at all a problem for me).

Over all, love the Cuisinart water boiler. If you frugal, I highly recommend this machine as I also anticipate this being able to last me a long time.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does what it's supposed to and it does it well.
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this this in 2010, I guess it's time for a review :)
I've had this tea kettle for 6 years now, it's moved across the country with me (I only took things that fit in my car, so that's a high bar!) and I still love it.
What I like: variable water temperature that makes me excellent green tea - even if I forget to take the bag out, the water cools off quickly enough that it doesn't taste over-steeped. Water heats up fast. Keep-hot feature is very useful.
I tossed the filter thing immediately, so I don't have any issues with pouring. I always use reverse osmosis filtered water, so buildup has not been a problem
Annoyances: unlike most kettles, when you lift it off the base, it does not shut off automatically. The water level indicator is not always correct at low levels. Occasionally it does not shut off properly (keeps heating even after it boils or, more dangerously, even when it's empty). This is very rare though.
I have not had issues with numbers rubbing off, but that's likely because I don't change settings that often. They're a little faded but still legible.

Bottom line: optimal water warmer for tea lovers who don't want to spend tons of money on a Zojirushi CD-WBC40-TS Micom 4-Liter Water Boiler and Warmer, Silver Brown

reviews.reviewTitle: Cuisinart does not stand behind their products
reviews.reviewText: This has been a great kettle for the last 3 yrs. Unfortunately, it now no longer heats up water. I checked with Cuisinart to see how to fix or replace it, and they were kind enough to let me know that the warranty is only good for 3 yrs. The fact that it broke shortly after that time period is up doesn't matter to them, and they have only offered me a slight discount off of a new one. I spent $100 bucks on an electric kettle. I expect to get more than three years out of it. I am going to stop purchasing Cuisinart products at this point.

I have had different Electric tea pots and loved them. The down fall for this one is the amount of time it takes to warm the water up. I can boil water faster than this tea pot takes. Not worth the money or my time

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent electric ta kettle. Cordless kettle is nice. Love the temperature buttons for the different tea types. A+++
reviews.reviewText:
The Cuisinart CPK-17 PerfecTemp 1.7-Liter Stainless Steel Cordless Electric Kettle is a very good buy. It is probably the best cordless electric kettle out there. It has the feature of boiling to different temperatures for the different types of tea you will be consuming. It is a very good size. It sits on the counter nicely, and it has a very nice stainless steel look. It is easy to operate, and it can re-heat to keep the water at the desired temperature. It also has a boil-dry feature as well. The blue back-color is very pleasant.

There is a small slide mesh filter that easily comes out that you can clean.

Pour our the excess water when not in use and let your kettle air-day.

The bottom heating unit can start to discolor due to calcium deposits from the water. Depending on your water source, you may need to clean more often.

You can clean and de-scale the inside of the kettle with water and white vinegar or with water with baking soda and or lemon juice and set it to boil. I've boiled just white vinegar itself for a more potent cleaner, and it works fine.

I have read that some other people having issues with the lid mechanism rusting, but I have not had that issue myself. Others have had the bottom heating unit start spotting with rust. I've only had calcium deposit spotting and was able to clean it with vinegar boil and with a long sponge brush.

Other stainless steel kettles rust inside as well especially regular stove kettles, but people can't see it or know it if they are not able to see the inside clearly enough on them

I recommend the Cuisinart CPK-17 PerfecTemp electric kettle. It has worked well for me, and I think it has made my tea drinking experience better with the temperature controls for the different types of tea being consumed. The price is a little pricey for a tea kettle, but the features are nice to have. The kettle is very solid, and it looks great in the kitchen. If you have Amazon Prime, the 2-day Free shipping is nice.

reviews.reviewTitle: I thought I loved it, but I don't.
reviews.reviewText: I bought this product on June 1, 2018. By the end of October 2018, the product was "howling". When I turn it on to heat, it begins to make these very loud "singing" or "howling" noises. C'mon. It's almost new. Why is this happening?

reviews.reviewTitle: Works OK but Tea Drinkers beware
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this because it isn't plastic, I trust the company and a friend recommended it. It works OK - 3 years later.

The following warning is mostly for Tea Fanatics. This kettle has a feature that might be wonderful if you want to do French press coffee but has driven me nuts. You can set the temperature to any of 6 settings, from 160 up to boiling at 212. The default setting is the lowest, so after some period of time has elaped, if you don't push the button for boiling you will get lukewarm water. . Innumerable times I have started the kettle, wandered off, come back and poured 160 degree water over my tea bag, then had to throw it all out and start over.

Yes, by now I should've learned, but haven't, so want to warn other tea drinkers that you have to stay awake to get it right. I wish they'd set the default to boiling and then I'd be satisfied.

Edited to add: Finally died after being used several times daily for 4 1/2 years.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great kettle, didn't last more than 6 years
reviews.reviewText: We loved this kettle, it looks sleek on the countertop and functioned well. After about a year of daily use, the temperature labels had rubbed off, which wasn't a huge problem as we had mostly memorized our favorite buttons. After a little over 6 years, water started to leak out of the bottle of the kettle unto the heating pad. Unfortunately, we are out of warranty, customer service has been poor in response time and resolution. It took 5 weeks, three emails and two phone calls to finally be told they will not honor a replacement but offered us 20% off a new kettle. We won't purchase again as the higher price tag didn't convert to better quality :(

This kettle is over-priced and under-spec'd. It has a set of temperature buttons that allow you to control the water temp simply by pushing the corresponding button. For example, Cuisinart says black tea should be steeped at 212 deg F, while green teas should be steeped at a lower temperature. I suppose my palate is simply incapable of telling the difference, or could it be that the water cools while being transferred to the pot/cup? However, what I did want was the feature that keeps the water at the set temperature, thus allowing one to make tea with no wait (once the desired temp has been reached). Unfortunately, Cuisinart decided that you must make that tea within 30 minutes! After that, the kettle turns itself off again. For me, this defeats the whole purpose of the function.

The Keurig 2.0 was such a disaster, I herd it for the entire year I owned it. Then I was housesitting for a friend who had this wonderous piece of technology. I’ll never go back. That thing was donated in all it’s messy noisy glory. This is the BEST thing I’ve ever owned. I can make tea just as quick and with more, less messy options. And it’s perfect to pair with my French press when I want coffee. The exact temps make it the absolute best possible of speed efficiency and flavor. Brava. Don’t come for my kettle. She’s alllll mine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked Great in First Year and Then Failed :(
reviews.reviewText: I bought this kettle close to a year ago for my parents. I loved the fact that it was stainless steel on the inside and outside making it easier for cleaning and durability. I tested it out before passing it to my parents, and I loved it. Once they started using it, they loved it too. I like the different temperatures you can program the kettle to heat the water to for different kinds of teas. It is quite versatile. My parent are older and it has the feature where it automatically cuts off after it completes the boiling cycle. However, they called me the other day to tell me that now it keeps boiling and boiling and won't shut off! One time it boiled all the water off and kept on boiling which is a fire hazard!! They unplugged it an refuse to use it because of this terrible malfunction. So I revisited the product's listing on Amazon and read the negative reviews which frequently mention this specific problem and how the product's warranty is lame. As much as my parents and I liked this kettle so much when it worked, it's sad and disappointing that it only lasted a year. Just something potential buyers need to be aware of!

reviews.reviewTitle: Heats water fast, some design changes would make it better, needs wifi connectivity
reviews.reviewText: Great kettle! This was a game changer for making pour-over coffee. Without raising the temp too high, I am able to make coffee without burning the grounds. Features I would add/change: The water level viewer should be on the sides of the kettle, not behind the handle. In hindsight I would find an Alexa compatible model to get water heating in the morning as part of a routine. When pouring water out of this, it doesn’t come out of a solid stream, comes out as a disjointed trickle.

reviews.reviewTitle: After 5 years of every day use, it stop working... it was about time!!! UPDATE JUN 2019
reviews.reviewText:
Loved it and will buy it again. We heat water to drink “mate” twice a day every single day also tea every night before bed. This kettle lasted for 5 years and 4 months! Can’t ask for a better kettle. Accurate temperatures is what we loved the most not to mention the design.
UPDATE JUNE 2019 after buying the second one: lid doesn't close and is hard to open it.
Will return it.
UPDATED: order a new one and is perfectly working!!

first of all, the description says stainless steel but the box you get says stainless steel trim or lined or something to that effect. the part that touches your water...you know...the part you should care about....its magnetic so it is not stainless steel. personally i want to know what could be leaching into my hot beverage i drink daily. i have no idea what this is but its not stainless. ( and even some stainless contains nickel and cadmium so even if it is stainless don't totally let your guard down. learned that while researching this pot)

UPDATE 6/2016 - I have to update this review because the inside bottom of my kettle was rusty! We had been using this kettle every day for about six months and never really paid much attention to the inside of it other than to fill it, but when we moved and I went to pack it up I noticed that there was rust spots on the bottom inside of the kettle. For something that is supposed to hold water, this is unacceptable. Customer support was not helpful either :(

I bought this after my other electric kettle died a week after buying it (stay away from the Hamilton Beach one!). It gets one star taken away because when I bought it, the listing stated that it was programmable. Even looking at my packing slip now it says programmable. However, it is not programmable. Waiting 5 minutes for my water to boil in the morning is not the end of the world though ;)

reviews.reviewTitle: An essential kitchen tool but the newer model is cheaper construction
reviews.reviewText: This is one of the most essential tools in our kitchen. We use it for coffee (french press) every morning and it boils water faster than the microwave. To clean in areas with hard water, simply put an ounce or two of citric acid and fill with water, set to boil and let sit for 15-20 minutes, rinse thoroughly with hot water. This is so useful we bought a second one to use when the first one stops working. Beware though, as the newer one is not as good as this older one. They cheapened the new one (we returned it) and the replacement they sent we use as backup was thankfully one of the old models.

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought two & both failed in 2yrs ! Don’t buy it !
reviews.reviewText: I bought one and it failed after 18 months. So because I liked it I bought another - that failed after 2yrs. Now I’m done. It’s an expensive kettle and should last longer than that. Clearly it’s got a limited life cycle and is not ready for prime time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quit after 6 months of light use
reviews.reviewText:
The unit did not survive 6 months of light use. The hot water it made during that time must be the most expensive hot water ever.

Company has an expensive return policy and even though the kettle was under warranty I did not send it in. Is $35 reasonable to send a $100 kettle back for repair when it can possibly fail again after a short time?

The kettle appears to be well made and has a lot of features. Too bad the business end of it did not last.

I bought it despite of some negative reviews. Lesson learned, don't buy small appliances from Amazon and their marketplace sellers. They do not guarrantee customer satisfaction. Amazon, are you going to do something about your marketplace sellers and their expensive warranty policies? Amazon may be customer centric, but their partners do not seem to be... So I am taking my business elsewhere for certain purchases. Why 0 stars is not offered as a rating option?

This electrical kettle heats up quickly and has different settings of temperatures. I especially like the tea setting so that the temperature is a bit lower (leaving more oxygen in the water and gives a better tasting tea- especially for green tea.) The kettle is made of nice quality stainless steel. The base that you set it on to operate is very stable. It sits very nicely on the counter without the base after it has heated up. I like the blue light that displays when it is on. It has an auto-off feature for safety. Overall quality product that I would purchase again or give as a gift. I originally chose this electric kettle because it was rated highly in a consumer review. I've had this kettle for several years and it still works great!

All I can say is I am sitting here thinking, why did I wait so long to order this? I have been considering this product for a few years. The cost was a bit of a barrier but also I had one of those 5-gallon water coolers with the typical hot water option. That is what I used for years and before that I pretty much just heated water up in the microwave. Yes. Sad but true. Recently we moved and downsized and with that move we lost the space for the nifty 5-gallon water cooler. So, I was back to heating water in the microwave. Anyway, I finally broke down and purchased this item. And let me just say; W-O-W. This is perfect in many ways; easy to use, heats up fast, temperature is perfect, great safety features, very attractive appliance, takes up little space, perfect size, etc. All this translates to my absolute love for this product but also the proverbial regret of why did I not but this sooner? Also, I must say, I have been drinking tea at the wrong temperatures ALL my life!!! Honestly! What a wake up call. My first cup of green tea at the appropriate temperature in this Cuisinart was an a-ha moment for me! Previously, I had been heating my water to nearly boiling and just flat out ruining the delicate notes of my green tea! What a shame. And here all this time I just thought it was bad tea and eventually got accustomed to drinking bad tea! So, to say I am happy is an understatement. I am so glad I finally fronted up the money to buy this. If you appreciate a perfect cup of tea-look no further. Note: I am a big coffee drinker too but I have not used this Cuisinart for that yet. I have however used it for hot water for oatmeal, cooking, etc. and, just like for tea, it works perfect.

The Cuisinart gives me exactly what I need. Convenience. As a Tea blogger, brewing a good cuppa at the right temperature is critical. The only thing I needed the directions for was to make sure there were no top secret rituals I needed to do in order to initialize the thing for its first run. It was pretty simple. Just rinse, fill and go. It is pretty darn self explanatory. In FACT, it is so awesome, if you forget which tea requires which temperature, that’s okay. The handle temperature buttons have the tea recommendations written on them! Needless to say I am quite pleased with my new Temperature variable tea kettle, and I hope I will brew many wonderful cups of tea from the water I heat with it. MY full review from my blog:
teawithlia dot com

reviews.reviewTitle: Love it! (well maybe not so much - update Oct 25, 2018)
reviews.reviewText:
I've seen a few other reviews about having trouble with this product but mine is great. I drink tea every day and love that the CPK-17 has different temperature settings based on the type of tea I am in the mood for. I think it might be a little bit overpriced but that is difficult to judge right now. If it lasts for 10 years, it a good price. If it lasts for one year, well then it is a terrible price. I'll add to my review once I've had it for some time. But honestly, it seems very well built and I've purchased Cuisinart products in the past and still have them many years later.

UPDATE (Oct 25, 2018): Had troubles after 6 months with the first unit and struggled with Cuisinart to get it returned without having to pay for shipping both ways!!!! The second unit worked relatively well but I would have trouble setting the controls sometimes and would have to unplug it once a month to get it to work again. It got worse in the end and I had to unplug it at least once a day! It finally died the other day forcing it into the appliance junkyard:(

I decided to buy a completely different brand this time and went with Homgeek electric kettle which looks identical to the Epica electric kettle. Why do I mention this here. First, because I have just boxed it up after two days of service. And second, Amazon wouldn't let me review it on it's item page! This unit has the same six temperature settings as the Cuisinart but the difference is, each time you turn it on you must hit the Set button and cycle through the temps to get to the one you want. It defaults to 212 degrees! That's fine if 99% of the time you only use that setting but I'll bet most people that buy a multi-temp kettle would probably find that annoying! I usually use 200 degrees so I had to hit the Set button multiple times each time I wanted a cup of tea. I drink at least six cups a day so that got old fast! The other issue is it didn't keep the water hot after it's cycle... you had to hit another button after you started it in order to use the Keep Warm feature. Again, every time you used the kettle. The lid opener is built into the lid and was quite small (annoying) and also the lid came up at a small angle making it a bit more difficult to fill. The last issue is that it didn't beep when the cycle finished. I guess that was something I got used to with the Cuisinart.

I have now replaced my Kettle with the Hamilton Beach 41020 Electric Kettle. It looks identical to the Cuisinart and I'm guessing if I went to China I would find them being made together in the same factory on parallel assembly lines. The difference is about $11 in favor of the Hamilton Beach!

Short version: I liked the kettle when it was working, but it stopped working and after I sent it back, Cuisinart waited out the warranty period and said they wouldn't do anything for me. So basically they took my money and left me with nothing. 4 stars for the kettle, -4 for malevolent customer service then +2 just to keep this out of the hater category of 1 star.

Long version: I was impressed with this kettle when visiting my brother so I bought my own. Simple to use, well marked temperatures and tea types. Looks nice. It worked as expected for a couple months then stopped working. No indicators of declining function, just wouldn't heat anymore one day. I called Cuisinart and followed their instruction about cleaning the unit in case a temperature sensor was blocked, but no result. Sent it back to Cuisinart and didn't hear anything for months. Almost a year, actually, which is when I called them to see what was up. As with probably most other busy people out there, an automatic tea kettle is not my top priority, especially when it's just a convenience over the standard tea kettle that is still on my stovetop. In any case, I was told that a "referral to corporate" was being made and that I would get a call back in a couple days. No call.
