Now, three months later and no returned calls and I called them today and was told that it's now past the warranty period and because I didn't call within a month from the original claim, they don't consider it their problem so they are not willing to do anything for me. Keep in mind that the kettle supposedly carries a three year warranty so one might think this is still under the warranty period. Also, when I called three months ago- under the "one year" they keep claiming is preventing them from taking action- the customer service rep said nothing about their expected protocol from customers or about a kettle which they now claim was sent to me via USPS with no delivery confirmation. This last claim was made by a customer service supervisor moments before ending the call and was not mentioned in any previous interactions with them, an action which gives me no confidence that they are telling the truth. Now they say the best they can do for me is give me an address for their corporate office to which to lodge a complaint, though given their tactic of doing nothing until the problem (ie customer) goes away, I have no faith that my letter will produce any results. For future kitchen appliance needs, I will avoid Cuisinart and recommend others do the same.

I purchased this product in 2013 and am a little surprised to read the poor reviews. I can only assume quality consistency is poor. This kettle is a work horse I use it twice a day or more every day, no staining, no rusting, the letters on the buttons look.like new. For the first time a few months ago the tea began to taste odd, metallic. I noticed some sediment in the bottom, scale really. I used a dealer and it was back to normal. I removed the filter years ago, its unnecessary. It's worked flawlessly for nearly 6 years of regular use. I wanted to buy another for my shop, which is why I came back to this listing. My only complaint is other kettles I've used in hotels boil faster , I've marked this one for one cup to minimize boil time. Other it's perfect.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good. Could be better if some plastic was removed
reviews.reviewText:
Pros: Heats Quick, Easy Temperature Control, Looks good.
Cons: Plastic under the lid, Plastic in the pour spout. Plastic in the measurement display.

It would be great if Cuisinart would make a version of this with absolutely no plastic inside, if they do I'll replace this with that one. It does heat the water accurately. However, where the water sits, it does come in contact with a little bit of the plastic that displays the amount of water in the unit. Also there is some plastic in the spout, but I was able to remove that with needle nose pliers. There is also plastic under the lid, so we just run ours with the lid open, I'm not sure if the lid would shut if this plastic was removed.

reviews.reviewTitle: French press setting worth this kettle!
reviews.reviewText: Bought this because my family member has one and coffee tasted ten times better than mine despite having the same beans, french press and grinder. Turns out the water temperature makes a huge difference. I bought this for the french press setting but this has a lot of functions. One thing I took a star away for is that it is confusing to realize you have to press the setting and start button rather than just the setting button. The light stays on the setting when pressed so it looks like it started. A better feature is to have it auto start after a few seconds. The start button also functions as a stop button.

reviews.reviewTitle: So far so good, but could be better ...
reviews.reviewText: Just got this as a Christmas gift as I am a tea lover. So far it is working as advertised, so I can't speak for those that have had issues with it for long-term use. I can't say that I do like that it is stainless steel and fits well on my small kitchen counter considering it size. However, this could be designed a little better and there are a few things to note if you are considering purchasing this. First, the outside, with the exception of the handle, can get very hot. If you have children or any unsuspecting person in the kitchen, this can be an issue. Secondly, the cord to the heating unit is very short, maybe 6-8 inches. If you plan on having this, make sure you are able to place it very close to an outlet. Will post an update with more use.

I'm disgusted. Sure, the kettle looks great, but it only lasted two months! Same issue as many other people are having (turns up for a couple of minutes then shuts off before it heats the water). What disgusted me even more is that the customer services rep (I believe here name was Elisa), got aggravated that my elderly mother wasn't able to immediately locate the serial number (she claimed was on the base) and hung up on her.

Bad product, bad company. Lost me as a customer for life, I'm hoping that others will follow.

Please look at all bad review for this kettle, and note that they charge you a handling fee if you return a defective unit.

Ideas for use of defective kettle: use it to keep your drinks cold, bank, plant pot, weapon, target practice,

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for a couple years...but beware serious potential safety issues.
reviews.reviewText: I purchases this electric kettle a few years back through a local brick and mortar store. It worked well for about two years but then started to leak internally (likely somewhere around the top of the sight gauge) when filled more than ~2/3 capacity. By "leak" I mean once it begins to boil the water runs into the electric base and all over and down the cabinets. I reported this obvious design flaw and safety hazard to the manufacturer and they responded that they would replace it for about 1/2 what I paid for it. No thanks.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very Happy with my new electric water kettle
reviews.reviewText: Very Happy with my new electric water kettle. I purchased this because I like Pu-Erh and Green Teas. Both need to have water at specific temperatures to brew the best tea. I have made several kettles of water at different temps and so far so good. I do like the lit water level indicator and the keep warm setting. Two features my Breville water kettle didnt have. I am keeping my old water kettle because I love the look (blue and white ceramic) and I can take it with me when I travel or send it to college with one of my children. I know everyone seems to love stainless steel but it would be nice if Cusinart made a a ceramic or a colored water kettle option. I will be curious to see if the words on the buttons wear off over time like some reviewers have mentioned. I decided its not that big of a deal if it happens because I have had the same problem with a computer keyboard and my a/c control in my car. Seems like lettering on a black background is prone to wearing off, I have just purchased a set of keyboard stickers and trimmed them to meet my needs. A sharpie will probably do the job also. .

I bought this about a year ago when I decided to ditch using pods and just make French press coffee. I have used it everyday sometime two or three times a day in the winter. I haven’t had the issue where the number wear off. So perhaps they solved that problem. The temp settings are accurate and useful if you drink various teas that do better at low temps. It’s one of a few appliances I keep out on my counter because I use it with such frequency. I took off one star for cleaning because the opening is relatively small and has sharp edges. But it’s really not hard to keep clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: The missing component for a perfect cup of tea
reviews.reviewText:
This is the smartest small purchase I've made in quite awhile. In the past, I've heated water for my tea either in the microwave or on the stove top, usually to boiling since it's hard to be precise with that method. This kettle heats up to 1.7L of water to a set temp and it does so pretty quickly - faster than the microwave surprisingly. For example, 1.5L will heat to 200 degrees within 4 minutes. I like the lighted display and the interior light that allows you to easily see how much water is in the kettle. And since various teas taste best brewed at a fairly specific temp, this kettle allows you to accurately control that. Green teas at 175, blacks at 200 or boiling, etc. I have a cooking thermometer, and I checked 3 different setting (175, 185, 200 degrees) and it was within a degree or two of each setting. Certainly close enough, and since my thermometer isn't calibrated, it could well be the kettle is spot on.

I love this cordless feature as well - only the base has the cord and the kettle lifts off the base so you can take it to another room if you want to. And in any case, its far better than having a cord in the way when pouring the water. It also will keep the water at the set temp for up to 30 minutes before automatically shutting off. Nice. It's also totally stainless steel and has a mesh filter in the spout which can be cleaned. No replacement will be necessary. It also beeps, although not loudly, when the set water temp is reached, but I can hear it in the next room. I'm very pleased with this kettle.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lasted 6 months before it started leaking horribly......
reviews.reviewText:
My original electric kettle lasted for 5 years but recently had been getting slower and slower to boil water so I thought it was time to replace it.
Did my research and was really intrigued by the temperature control on this Cuisinart but initially balked at the high price for this kettle. I waited until the price dropped to around $80 before I finally bought it.
So, I've been using it for around a year and am highly disappointed. At the 6 month point, it developed a leak. After getting up to temperature, I lifted the kettle off the stand and was left with a pool of hot water around the stand. It took me a while but I was able to figure out that it was leaking around the plastic water gauge. My solution was to fill the kettle to no more than the 1.25 liter mark and that worked for awhile....
Now it looks like the leaking is getting worse so it's time to find a new kettle. The hot water leaks are getting dangerous as recently water leaked out and nearly scalded my foot while I was pouring water out into a cup.
Would not recommend this unit.

Everyday, either I roll out of bed and stumble to this kettle, add some water to around the 1.25 mark and hit start. It remembers 185 all on its own. A few of minutes later it beeps a few times. Then the best moment my miserable day happens, coffee. Repeat the above for 3 years 6 months. Frequently twice in a day when my wife can't find it within herself to get out of bed within an hour of me, and thus must heat the thing again. Now fast forward to today, there's a bit of a leak. Nothing major mind you but we all know this is the end. And that's fine. If you want a device that is going to go from room temperature to 185 degrees daily and last longer than 4 years look elsewhere. But if say you know what's pretty good I'm ok with that, here's your kettle.

We are moving away from microwave use in this household. This cordless electric kettle works beautifully as a replacement for preparing a quick cup of tea. It actually tops the microwave because this kettle allows for different temps for the brewing of different types of teas. We love our teas in this household so this kettle really works quite nicely for us. Haven't used the microwave very much for anything that requires a quick cup or two of boiling water since the kettle arrived.

This is totally an excellent hot water kettle. I first encountered it at a friend's, who uses it for tea, and French press. It's fast, easy, visible. I heard they don't make this model anymore, and I wonder why. the next model doesn't have the displays this one does. It sits on a base that has the cord.
it will keep water hot for a half hour. you can pick the temperature of the water with several choices. it beeps when it has finished heating the water.
It's useful for more than teas and French presses. I find it's handy for anything that needs boiling water to reconstitute or cook like instant stuff. I was using a microwave, but found that when the microwave is in use, the only option was the stove. this is cheaper to use than a stove, and I think faster.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke down and had to pay a lot more to get it replaced even though it was under warranty
reviews.reviewText: Unit stopped working withing 5 months. Called Cuisinart and they said that they would replace it but we had to pay shipping for receiving the new product and replacing the old one. So another $30 in shipping. This is the most expensive product in this category. Simply not worth it. Before this we had Breville for 6 years. It worked great. I would recommend that to anyone.

I am amazed and extremely disappointed that the kettle started to leak water at the bottom just after 8 months of moderate use. It was never dropped or misused.
Beware of the scam running by Cuisinart 3-year product Warranty: if the product failed they require you to pay for shipping back and add $15 for shipping and handling on the top of this. So if your kettle failed in a few month it is still easier and cheaper to through it away. Shame on Cuisinart brand! I will never buy any of its products

I had seen reviews saying that the button decals tend to come off, so I held back on writing the review. I purchased this product on January 23 (so 5+ months ago) and is used several times a day, and the buttons are decals are perfectly fine!

Having used teapots on the stove for many years, I was unprepared for how fast it would boil. It boils extremely quickly, and I love it! I bought it for my mom, and she loves it, too! It's just loud enough that you can hear it from different rooms, but it's not at the volume where it's annoying. The buttons also make it very easy to tell what temperature is best for your tea

LOVE IT! ~ I use this every morning for making my French Press coffee! ~ It is FAST in bringing water up to temperature for whatever you are making/brewing. ~ I have NO problems with rust, as was mentioned in earlier posted comments of some buyers who apparently had an earlier model and brought the problem to the attention of the manufacturer, who apparently solved the problem. ~ Absolutely NO complaints on this most handy kitchen product! ~ It is good practice to open the lid after pouring out the water so that the interior will air dry while the interior is still hot.
Another person mentioned the lettering coming off of the buttons, thus I have made it a point NOT to allow my fingernails to make direct contact with them, but only the pad of the finger; so far so good!

reviews.reviewTitle: A great kettle that heats fast
reviews.reviewText:
I really liked my Fridgidaire Professional electric kettle for two years but it was accidentally destroyed by a guest who didn’t know it was electric and put it on the stove. When I bought a replacement it died in three days, so I decided to try the Cuisinart since it is quite similar to the fridgedaire. So far it is working fine. It’ll heat 1.75 liters from 68°F to boiling in just over 7 minutes but I seldom heat that much. The minimum level is 0.5 liters. The tone that signals completion is mild, not obnoxious. If you’re not in the room when it sounds, you may miss it. That’s not a bad thing, it’s a good thing, especially with my sensitive pets.

There is one feature this kettle does not have that I wish it did. There is no way to tell how hot the water is as it heats. You must wait for a full cycle to complete before you know the temp. The Frigidaire kettle used a series of lights to indicate the general temp so you have an idea how much longer it might be. Some kettles have temperature displays for that purpose, but this one just lets you choose the temp and wait. No big deal, just wish I still had that feature.

Overall it’s great, but if I have any problems, I’ll update this review, just as I did with the Fridgidaire.

I've used the Cuisinart CPK-17 for almost a year (bought on 02 August 2014), and I'm really pleased with it.
When I was on the market for a kettle, I read the extensive review by The Sweethome (link: http://thesweethome.com/reviews/the-best-home-kettle/ ). I tend to trust these guys given their extensive and thoughtful tests, and so I bought their pick although it's not cheap.

I'm a great tea lover, and I drink different kind of teas (mostly greens, but also black, oolong, white, herbal infusions) 2+ time a day.
In the morning both me and my husband have tea at breakfast, but since we drink different teas which requires different temperatures, we heat the water separately. In the fall/winter I am sure to have a huge pot of tea in the afternoon, and usually we also have herbal teas in the evening.
So in a year we used the kettle pretty extensively, and it still works great!

These are the main reason why I like it:
1) it heats up to 1.7 liter of water, so if I want to fill a big teapot or I have guest I can heat enough water for everyone
2) you can choose among 6 different temperatures for different kind of teas (which makes a huge difference!), and the labels are pretty accurate (I've measured the water both in mug and in a teapot a couple of times, out of curiosity, and there were +/- 2 F degrees difference tops)
3) it's quick and noiseless - yes, you'll hear the water boiling, but that's it, it won't make any additional noise
4) given its large capacity, it doesn't take a lot of space on the countertop, plus it has a nice design and I don't mind have it around
5) it's easy to fill (I love the button to open the lid automatically), and to check how much water you poured in
6) the 30 minute keep warm option (although I don't use it that much)

As everything, it has a couple of downside:
1) it's heavy! especially if filled to its top capacity
2) the sides get hot, so pay attention not to touch them

BPA controversy: this kettle has minor plastic components, and I was concerned. However on the product description on cuisinart website (link: https://www.cuisinart.com/products/tea_kettles/cpk-17.html ) they explicitly say it is BPA-free.

To wrap up, in almost a year of constant use I am really please with my Cuisinart CPK-17 PerfecTemp. It is on the expensive side for being a kettle, but it deserves that money.

Handy little teapot. This teapot has a small footprint on the counter making it easy to place almost anywhere. The power station does not get hot making it safe around inattentive people. The teapot bottom also remains cool making it possible to set it on the counter without damage or steady a full teapot. The controls are a little excessive with small print on most of the temperature setting buttons. The manufacturer printed both the type of tea and the temperature each button will heat to.

As the teapot heats, the water boiling becomes louder and louder. This can be distracting, but I don't think we can get around the physics of boiling water.

reviews.reviewTitle: Pretty pretty pretty pretty pretty good
reviews.reviewText:
Just received my tea kettle, been looking forward to this purchase and it does not disappoint.

First run was to use the 160 degree present and brew some white tea (one note - their suggested brewing temperatures are a little higher than what I think is more commonly accepted, please don't brew your white tea at 185 degrees). It heated up quick and was the right temperature, gave me a nice gentle steeping. Second run was oolong at 190, also hit the spot, very happy with the results.

I deducted 1-star for the afore-mentioned issue with tea-steeping temperature suggestions and, more importantly, b/c it is basically impossible to see the water level unless the backlighting has come on (when in operation the buttons & water gauge glow blue). Not a huge deal but slightly annoying and I have used less fancy tea kettles where you can always see the water level. I have to check, pretty sure there is no floating bauble so you need the backlighting to see where the water rises to. Ok, still really happy with it and would suggest it.

I chose this over the 1-L Bonavita Gooseneck Variable Temperature Kettle, figured that having the capacity needed for guests outweighed the pour control of the gooseneck spout. The Bonavita also allows for more temperature customization but the presets on the Cuisinart are sufficient for me, and I am quite particular about water temp so that is saying something. Last several years I've just used a stovetop kettle and have added a bit of room temp water to my tea before pouring in boiling water, that was fun and artful but this is much easier.

This is the third kettle we've tried in a month and will be keeping it! So many of the "smart" kettles are pretty dumb.

One thing I particularly like is that the electronics are in the handle, not the base. This saves real estate on the counter top (a premium in our tiny kitchen) and also it means there's only the power connection in the base. We had a Breville that would constantly turn itself off before it boiled because the rocking motion of the water would disconnect one the many contacts in the base.

I was a little concerned about the plastic "window" but it's BPA free and there hasn't been a plasticky taste or smell in our tea. I boiled two full pots and discarded them before making tea the first time. Even the glass kettles we tried have plastic components that contact the water or steam.

I had looked at many products similar to this one and I just really liked the look and the reviews of the product so decided to give it a try. I was not disappointed! I love that it had different temperature settings. Like a reviewer said, it is a little noisy for a brief amount of time but I don't find that to be a problem. It heated the water quickly and it is a nice looking pot on my counter so I am a satisfied customer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love my Perfec Temp - (Edit: slightly less than my initial review due to a couple problems)
reviews.reviewText:
I love this Cuisinart Perfec Temp Kettle. Only wish it was came in a 2 liter model as I typically make 2 quarts of ice tea at a time.

Only 1 very slight design flaw... when pouring the last cup from the kettle, the water comes from the lip of the spout (where it should) and also from the upper edge of the hole in the kettle where the spout is located. It all goes in the cup, so no problem. But if I were working on the next improved model, there are a couple easy ways to fix this... lower the top edge of the spout hole or put a baffle inside the unit to prevent water from getting to the top of the unit when tipped to get the last cup.

June 2017 edit: My initial review was 5 stars. I've lowered it to 4. I was going to lower it to 3, as I was having an issue with my new one, but I begrudgingly give it a 4 as the problem seems to be getting better with time.

So, I'm on my 2nd CPK-17 now. My first CPK-17 developed a leak at the bottom of the handle. And, leaving it filled overnight resulted in a small puddle of water below the base in the morning. I really liked my first kettle, so I purchased another. Unfortunately, I'm having a problem that others have mentioned in having difficulty opening the lid. While my 1st kettle only rarely did not open on the 1st press, it always opened on the 2nd. My new kettle has not been as cooperative. And *one* time I had to SHAKE it while half full about 10 times while holding the button, before the lid finally popped open. I've only had this new one a couple weeks now and, so far, that has only happened once, but it frequently takes more that one press of the button before the lid will open. This problem is improving with use so I'm hoping the lid will loosen up further over time.

2nd edit: So it's been over a week now since my previous edit and it looks like the lid has loosened. I've been using my 2nd CPK-17 two times a day and the problem experienced with the lid failing to open hasn't occurred once since my previous edit.

I feel like I fell for gimmicks. Yes, this is an attractive device. It looks nice sitting on my kitchen counter. The blue illumination is actually sexy.

But it's harder to see the water level when filling than the simple hot pot it replaced. I don't really need to be able to heat water to six different temperatures and have it held there. I can't do any actual timings, since the pot it replaced finally died after several years of daily service, but I don't think it heats the water as quickly.

Think about what you want. If you're looking to dress up your kitchen, this will do it. If you really need six different temperatures and/or the keep-warm function, fine. If you're looking to heat water, you can accomplish that task with a cheaper device that will likely last longer because it is less complex.

What a disappointment. After using a Breville water heater for almost 6 years, I decided to give the Cuisinart a try. My wife drinks tea every evening and liked the ability to heat water to sub-boiling temperatures. She also liked the look of this unit.

When it worked, it did a great job. But after five months of very casual use, it simply stopped heating water (the lights still work!). Given the premium price of this unit, I'm shocked. I rarely write reviews as most products generally align with their ratings--but felt like folks deserved the heads-up here.

reviews.reviewTitle: It will break...Sooner or later, but likely sooner than you hope! VIOLENTLY!
reviews.reviewText:
All the reviews with 5 stars are from the people who just bought it or owned for a little while.
All the bad reviews are from the ones who owned it till it broke.

Well, I took the bullet, hoping it will not happen to me, but, alas, it did, of course.

While kettle worked, it rated 5 stars. Temp control, all blows and whistle. The only complain I have about its operation is that often times it switches to KEEP WARM setting, but that might be due to user error - I'm not the only one using it, and KEEP WARM button is right under START so it's very easy to push both of them if you are not careful.

Goodness lasted only 8 months. From other reviews I gathered none of them lasted more than a year. So, if you find it acceptable to shell out $100 or so for this long, good for you. I certainly do not. The rating drops down to 2 stars right there for me. Customer service gives the same story as to the others - ship it to us, we ship you replacement. I pay for the postage both ways. No, thank you.

It gets worse. A friend of mine bought this kettle recently, and when I visited him, I noticed the differences between his and mine.
He dug out the box, and his version is Rev2 of this model, supposedly better and longer life.

So I bit the bullet again (I never learn, do I? :) But I REALLY loved it when it worked)

Well, the second one worked only 3 weeks! (luckily, as I was still in Amazon return window)
What was not so lucky, is that it burnt, leaving a foul smell in my whole kitchen and a nasty burnt ring of some fetid black resin-like residue on my counter which I installed just a couple of months ago! And of course it would not come off! Now who's going to pay me for the new counter?

Don't walk from this kettle, RUN!

I recently purchased this kettle because my old kettle stopped working. I did some research on different types of kettles and decided to purchase this one. Here's what I found so far.

The look:
I really like the look except for the fact that the window is hard to see so when pouring water into the kettle, you actually have to be very close to the window. This morning I had hard time even seeing the amount of water because the window was all steamy. Even though we haven't used it over night. They should definitely consider moving the window to a side.

The feel:
This kettle is made of metal and feels a little heavy. After a few minutes of pushing the "start" button, it gets real hot and makes it impossible to touch (even the lid), but the handle stays cool.

The functionality:
When I plugged in the kettle to the outlet and put it on base, the blue light in the window turned on and stayed on for about 10 minutes. There's no way to turn it off other than to take the kettle out of its base. I guess the light is useful if you want to see how much water you have in the kettle, but it is only useful when the kettle is on the base. I poured water all the way to the max, set it to "boil" and started the process. The buttons are not easy to press, sometimes it takes me a few times before it responds so I have to push the buttons harder. In a software age where gadgets like touch screens make it so easy to touch and expect an immediate response, I'd say this is a big flaw in the kettle. It took about 7.5 minutes to boil water at which point the kettle beeped softly three times and stopped working while the temperature "boil" and "start" buttons started blinking. If I was in the next room, I wouldn't be able to hear the beeps. I poured a cup of water out into my cup and pushed "keep warm" button a few times until it was lit. About a minute later it turned off so I wasn't sure if it was still working so I pushed it again a couple of times so the button lit and then it turned off again. I poured all water out and wanted to test "boil-dry protection" feature. It took maybe half a minute for the kettle to realize there's no water inside and it shut off and all the buttons started blinking. I took it off its base and put it back on hoping it would reset, but it didn't. I started pressing "start" button (according to the manual, pressing "start" will either start or stop the boiling process), but it didn't help. So I took the kettle of its base and left it on the table for about 10 minutes after which point I put it back on the base and it magically reset. I guess the two minute memory feature prevented the kettle from being reset.

Overall, I would say it's a safe to use kettle if you don't touch it while it's hot. It definitely boils water fast and signals when it's done.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works fine...unless it doesn't this time and you come back to cold water in 5 minutes.
reviews.reviewText:
This is a pretty nice kettle in that it has 6 pre-set temperatures that pretty consistently get water to the same temperature.

It feels pretty nice, but overall quality is kind of dubious--the steel top pops off its plastic lid pretty easily, the lettering for all the buttons wore off in less than a year, and, well, it frequently just doesn't heat the water.

What happens is you press the "Start" button and the kettle will just sit for half a minute and then emit 3 beeps and turn off.
It does this just frequently enough that I don't ever trust it to actually start, and usually stand over it to make sure it is actually going to work this time, which kind of ruins part of the point of being able to select a temperature and come back to hot water.
It has done this since new.

I also wish the temperatures were just a little different, but, with so many other things wrong with it, I won't press my luck.
I will probably keep it until it breaks (probably soon, as has been my experience with other Cuisinart products), and hope something better is on the market by then.

reviews.reviewTitle: Died after a year... Cuisinart replaced it.
reviews.reviewText:
I absolutely loved this tea kettle... of course, until it stopped working. I do have to say though, that even when the kettle worked, I wished that the spout had a lid, 'cause the spout's pretty sizeable, and I can imagine a lot of dust settling into the kettle. Plus, my sister once found a boiled ant in her cup. Apparently it had crawled into the spout at some point...

Anyway, I drink various different teas and coffee everyday, so the preset temperatures were a huge convenience.

Unfortunately after a lot of research, it seems apparent that the biggest weakness of electric kettles, is that they just don't last that long before something blows out.

I really enjoyed the preset temperatures, so I'd love to buy another electric kettle with those features, albeit one that'll last longer than a year... but in this day and age, there aren't many options. At least on Amazon, it's either this kettle or the one by Breville, but it appears that even the latter suffers from a short lifespan.

Sucks, but I might have to return to conventional stovetop kettles, until one of these companies can figure out something with more durability, 'cause shelling out $80-120 for one of these is not worth it if it can't last more than a year. Maybe $30, tops.

Stovetop kettles practically last forever. I might invest in one with a thermometer on it, although it's kinda tedious constantly checking the temperature to make sure it's on the money... since there isn't any shutoff feature or alerts, like the electric kettles. I know there are separate thermometers sold that alert you, but again, the options are slim, and the most popular brand seems to have more design flaws than I care to overlook...

Perhaps I'll give the Zojirushi water boilers a shot, although they feature less preset temps. I wonder when an electric water boiler/kettle will offer the ability to customize temperature settings...

EDIT: I've upgraded my review to five stars, after Cuisinart sent me a new one. So far, the new one has held up for a year.

This is my first ever Amazon review, because I am so frustrated. I would post a zero star review if I could. After 8 months, this kettle stopped working. It lights as if it is on, but the water does not get hot. As others have said, the only fix Cuisinart has is to send you a new one for free, but you must pay shipping both ways for a total of at least $30. These are the terms of their "limited" warranty.

I asked the Cuisinart rep. what the history of this problem is. She said there is no history of this complaint and no recall. So I said "Do you mean that no one has reported this problem to Cuisinart in the history of this product?" and she replied "that's right." That's an absolute lie, as evidenced by many other 1-star reviews complaining of the exact same problem.

It's back to the old-fashioned on-the-stove kettle for me. I thought Cuisinart was a reputable brand, but it is not. They make a $90 kettle and you have to pay to replace the product when you report a common and known problem. They should issue a recall and replace them instead.

reviews.reviewTitle: Beautiful, fast, 6" counter footprint- perfect green tea
reviews.reviewText: I learned the hard way the reason I didn't like green tea was the fact I was burning it when I used boiling water. With this kettle the temperature is perfect, and green tea tastes great. I combine heated water and loose tea in my Bodum French Press (which is supposed to be for coffee) and brew a perfect pot each time.The footprint is only 6"., The finish is elegant enough to sit out on the counter full time. The coffee drinkers in the family appreciate it as well with the boiling water option as well as french press temp. Heating is very fast. The pour spout seldom drips. Seeing the water level is helpful. It measures liters- I do wish it was cups. Ocasionally the reset to turn off fails to work, and the kettle tries to keep my pot warm instead; I unplug the pot to reset.

reviews.reviewTitle: This pot rocks! Sleek design, amazing heating, well built
reviews.reviewText:
When our coffee maker died I decided to try a French press. I was not about to heat up water on the stove. That was a deal breaker. I discovered this here and bought it hoping it would fit the bill.

I absolutely love this device! It rocks! I haven't looked closely to figure out how on Earth the heater works, but it so cool. Instead of having a cord plugged into the pot the base is plugged in and stays put. The pot simply lifts off without any hassle or latch to work. There's a single connection point or whatever it is that the pot sits down onto. Seriously, it's super sleek, simple and well designed.

As for heating, this baby gets rocking very quickly. I have me 200 degree water in just a few minutes. It beeps to let me know when it's ready.

My only complaint ... and it's not really a complaint ... is that it's too big for our needs. I'd love a smaller version of this with smaller level markings for coffee making. Because even the French press has lousy markings we had to use a measuring cup at first and then scratched markings on the press for our needs.

reviews.reviewTitle: My daughter introduced me to this pot and I love it. This is my second time purchasing it ...
reviews.reviewText:
My daughter introduced me to this pot and I love it. This is my second time purchasing it as hers died after about 6+ years of continuous use. She wanted the same, exact pot. It looks attractive in the kitchen, is sturdy and has several settings. Besides making americano style coffee and occasional tea, we keep the kettle going when cooking to provide constant hot water for cooking.
I treat it with a vinegar solution every few months to get rid of any hard water build up. The finish stays nice with just a wipe down or simple soapy wash if the outside becomes greasy from cooking.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you need kettle, get this one because it's awesome. Check out the ratings.
reviews.reviewText:
Really, it's a kettle, so what's to write about?! Yes, it boils water, though it does it well and you get a great cup of tea/joe. There seems to be a couple of tricks this kettle has, a heavy plate for gradual and precise heating where others just blast away scalding the water, and it uses a sensor for accurate temperature while other kettles have an awful bimetallic switch that guarantees the water is over boiled. Result, a really great cup of coffee or tea.

Is it worth four times the price of a cheap box store kettle? Well, after a year of a box store kettle made everything taste metallic, cooled off so fast you had to be there or miss out, and always smelled of plastic when it boiled, this kettle is a prefect solution.

If you need a kettle, can take the extra cost, then this is there kettle to get.

October 2016 Update: Just started getting a nasty burning rubber smell when using the kettle. So that's a little over 2 years into the three year warranty. I will admit, this kettle gets used 3 - 5 times a day and rarely more. I'll try for a warranty replacement... but I'll just get another. Yep, this kettle is that good.

I searched and searched for the perfect kettle and found it with this Cuisinart model. I hesitated at first because yes it is a little pricey compared to tons of other kettles on the market, but it's true...you get what you pay for.

I'm a huge tea drinker and run this kettle practically all day long. I typically stick with black teas so didn't think I'd use the other temperatures but I do all the time. Once the kettle boils I can use the 160 option to get a perfect drink immediately tea. The keep warm was also important to me but I have to admit I don't use that too often as it runs the kettle again to maintain the temperature and I may not need another cup within that time so it feels a bit wasteful.

I love that it's stainless so there is no "taste"except the water and the beep when it's done is perfect. I can hear it from my office yet it's not so annoying that it disrupts you if you're watching TV. it's also fairly quiet compared to models I've had in the past. Those models wold be so noisy that you'd have to turn up the volume on the TV or music, not with this one.

The design is beautiful. It fits in perfectly with my kitchen and looks very high-tech.

Nothing bad to report.

If you use a kettle every day this is the one to buy.

What a piece of garbage. We had a $20 kettle before with no fancy features. Worked for almost 10 years and it finally developed some rust, so we wanted a new one. This new fancy one for almost $70 has developed mold in less than one month. This tells me the metal is lower quality and/or it was somehow contaminated at the factory. Total junk. DO NOT BUY!

Similar to other complaints here, my kettle has rust on the hinges and what looks like peeling along the bottom of the pot. Albeit, I've had it for 3 years now, it's not something I'd expect from a pot that cost considerably more than others you can find on Amazon. I will be looking for another kettle and any suggestions are greatly appreciated!

I bought this kettle 5 years ago and it's still going strong! As an avid tea drinker, this was one of the best purchases I've ever made. The only "defect" at this point is that I've rubbed the temperatures off from how often my husband and I have pressed the buttons. I think in those 5 years it's definitely paid for itself!

Edit: Update, it's now 7 years old and it STILL works. I actually did just order a replacement, though, because it's just reached the point where it doesn't always turn on. But up until now, it's given us a steady 7 years of service! I do agree with other reviewers, however, that the button writing rubs off pretty easily. Other than that, I love this kettle.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is the best electric kettle that I have found.
reviews.reviewText:
This is the best electric kettle that I have found.
It has buttons for heating the water to different temperatures for different types of tea, which is great.
It heats water as fast, or faster, than any other kettle I have used.
The kettle shuts off when it reaches the proper temperature, and will shut off if empty. This is a reliable kettle.
One word of warning- don't over fill it. If the water boils over and gets into the base, the kettle may break. My last one died after having over filled it a couple times, but I immediately replaced it with the same model. It had seen a lot of use. I use it to heat water not only for tea, but also for quinoa, pasta, rice, and so forth. It is so much faster than heating water on the stove top.

It is worth the money.

I'm so glad that I replaced my old pot with this one. I like the fact that the lid is attached and can be easily opened without getting my fingers scalded. If some water spills down the side, it isn't caught in a seam that catches all the drips. And best of all, I can choose the proper temperature for the type of tea I'm making. The lowest setting is great for herbal teas. They taste SO much better brewed with water that isn't boiling. I'd recommend this pot to anyone!

I've had this for around 2 years now. I'm actually shocked (SHOCKED, I TELL YOU!!) I haven't written a review earlier than this. This is a really great electric kettle. I use it with my AeroPress and it works great for pour-over coffee (I work from home and use it ALL morning EVERY day). It replaced a gooseneck kettle when the spout started leaking. Very quick, quiet operation. Easy-to-read level in blue LED. The kettle is well insulated so if it has timed out, the water is still very hot. I only use reverse osmosis water in it and I have had zero issues with rust, discoloration or any other problem I've read in other reviews. I used to use spring water. I wouldn't recommend using unfiltered tap water.

I bought this kettle for my office (after reading many of the Amazon reviews). Its fantastic. The only reason I give it four stars is because the cable is very short and unless you are using it on a kitchen counter top you need an extension cord. If the kettle is positioned on a desk or table it won't reach normal wall-socket height.

The kettle is attractive and looks and feels expensive;unlike a lot of other kettles it has a keep-warm setting, and features a very legible and beautiful blue LED water level indicator. Also special is that there are multiple temperature settings according to the type of tea or beverage you are going to prepare. Its large enough that I can sit in my office for hours drinking tea and don't have to refill it. The handle does not get hot. I am glad I got this kettle!

Worked great, until it didn't. Attractive design, appreciated the keep warm and auto-off features. Used it for the past 3 months, then it suddenly stopped working. When I press the start button it beeps and lights flash, but it won't start. This was a xmas present and my son purchased the protection plan with it, but I can't submit a claim there because it is still under Cuisinart warranty. Tried to reach customer support by phone, but was on hold waiting for a rep for a long time and eventually had to hang up. The manual says I will need to send $10 for shipping and handling, which suggests I will also need to pay to ship it to Cuisinart. The thought of spending time and more money for an already expensive pot so soon after purchase is disappointing. Hope my next attempt to reach customer service is faster and they have a solution that won't cost me more.

I absolutely love my electric kettle. I am an avid tea drinker and especially enjoy loose tea and matcha. This tea kettle has been incredible for both. For green tea I usually use the delicate setting, as I prefer my water a little cooler than the kettle suggests for green (160 instead of 180). That may be because I usually drink jasmine pearl green tea, which I feel is a little more delicate in flavor than most green teas. For other green teas I use the usual green tea setting. For herbal teas I use the boil setting and they always come out wonderful. Matcha is the only tricky one. Its recommend that you use water at 80 degrees for this type of tea and the kettle does not have this setting. I drank a couple bitter tasting cups before I figured out a solution. Now what I do is I add a little bit of cold water (about 1/4-1/3 of the water I want) to my matcha powder and mix well. Then I add the hot water from the delicate setting. Makes perfect matcha every time and actually makes mixing it significantly easier.

Tea is a ritual for me and this kettle has made the experience so much more enjoyable. No more microwaving water or boiling it on the stove leaving me to guess if it is the correct temp. This machine is quick and looks beautiful on my counter. Some reviewers complained about the noise, but it really isn't bothersome. It sounds just like boiling water and I actually find it sort of soothing. No complaints whatsoever.

This is one of my favorite things that I have ever purchased! I use it every single day to make tea in the morning, and occasionally in the afternoons as well. It heats quickly, is relatively quiet (a bit noisy when getting up to a boil, but the noise doesn't last long). The little beeping at the end is nice, not too loud.

I originally wanted the pricey tea maker from Breville, because I liked the idea of setting the tea maker just like a coffee maker and having the tea ready to go in the morning. However, I usually only drink one cup of tea in the morning, and it seemed a bit too expensive for my one cup. I decided I could live with pouring the water over my own tea and brewing it that way. I've been very happy with my decision.

One of the best features is the "Keep Warm" function. I like this because I don't have to go running the second I hear the "I'm done" beep, the way I used to have to run to the kitchen to calm down the shrieking stovetop kettle. If I don't hear the beep, or just can't get there right away, no problem! The kettle will periodically reheat to keep the temperature up. For multiple cups of tea, however, I don't use the "Keep Warm" function. I just shut off the kettle and then get it going again when/if I want a second cup of tea. It reheats so quickly that I don't bother keeping it warm and listening to the reboil over and over.

I haven't done any testing of the temperatures to see how accurate they are, but all of my different types of tea taste great when brewed at the preset temperatures. Unlike some previous reviewers, I have not had any issues with the words wearing off the preset buttons. The kettle still looks brand new, nothing fading or peeling after about a year now of daily use.

Buy it, you won't regret it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Over all I am happy with this product and would recommend it F
reviews.reviewText:
I have been trying different loose leaf teas (green, black and oolong) and discovered that the brewing temperature really does matter. So I was heating water in a microwave and using a thermometer, adding cold water to bring the temperature down before brewing. What a pain and needed a solution.

Enter the Cuisinart CPK-17, not only does it heat the water faster than our 1200 watt microwave but to my pleasant surprise the carafe will maintain the water temperature long after the timer has shut off the heating element, thus when returning an hour later to brew another cup of tea the reheat time is reduced significantly!

The auto shut off feature is actually welcome since I have been know to leave the office without turning off the coffee maker.

The preprogramed buttons seem to work correctly for the different teas (I have only used the green, black, oolong) I have not used the delicate, French press, or white tea buttons, however I am confident that they work just as well.

Over all I am happy with this product and would recommend it

F.Y.I. The Black tea button equals boil

reviews.reviewTitle: A product I want to love, but feel just kind of "meh" about.
reviews.reviewText:
Ahhh where do I begin. I love Cuisinart products and I wanted a stainless steel kettle that would match the rest of my appliances. Before this, I had a Black&Decker kettle that had a digital screen that would tell the temperature, along with presets for different teas. Unfortunately that one was discontinued, so I bought this one and took the old one to to work. I saw this Kettle and loved the design, the reviews were pretty good, so I got it. After about 3 months, all ink on the preset buttons started to rub off. Luckily I remembered most of the buttons temperatures, but if I forget I have to look the product up online and look at the pictures (kind of a pain).

Next, the kettle beeps to let you know that the water is ready. A lot of the times the temperature is not right, especially when you select boil. The water clearly isn't boiling, but the beep go's off and the kettle shuts off. For other temperature settings I've taken a meat thermometer to check he temp and it's usually way off. Either too hot, or not hot enough. This became extremely frustrating and I took this kettle to work, and brought the old Black&Decker kettle back home, since I tend to make tea more at home. If you want precise temperature for tea, look for a kettle that has a digital thermometer built into it. I really wanted to like this product, but it's just okay.

reviews.reviewTitle: Select the right temp for the right tea, and very attractive
reviews.reviewText:
I love an electric kettle for tea; I've tried ones for the stove but I run around the house, distracted by this and that, and my hearing is such that I can miss even a loud whistle if I am upstairs. The electric kettle heats the water to the right temperature, then shuts it off and holds it warm for a while. Nice.

This unit fits on a base with a short stem; no cord on the kettle, just on the base. It has a level window, and setting for temperatures from white or green tea up to boiling-hot for black tea. You can choose temps for making press-pot coffee, in short, very nice to be able to heat water to your desired degree.

The stainless steel is attractive, as is the blue-lit control panel on the handle and the blue-lit level indicator on the body. It's a handsome unit.

One funny thing; when you plug it in and hit the "on" button, it defaults to the lowest temperature. I would love it if it was customizable to choose your default temp because mainly, I boil water for English style tea, not Japanese or Chinese tea.

That's a minor quibble. I just have to remember to hit the second button after "on" to choose my temperature. I've had a number of electric kettles over the years--sometimes they give up the ghost so this may be my third one--and I don't want plastic so I did get rid of a perfectly good one that was not BPOA-free, sad to say. I like this unit a lot. By the way, a trick some people use is to fill it to the brim, set on hottest setting and pour out the hot water into the pasta pot to speed up heating a large pot of water for boiling noodles.

reviews.reviewTitle: Like It But It's Not Always Accurate
reviews.reviewText:
I really love the look and function of this kettle, which I got for Valentine's Day, using a gift card. It's sleek-looking and the button presets are excellent. It's certainly not like the Breville One-Touch in the way of efficiency, but I certainly love the Keep Warm, which you can shut off and on, along with other benefits. I previously used (and still have as backup) the Aroma kettle, which was pretty decent and reliable for the price, but lacked the ability to control the temperature. It was always too hot.

While this kettle provides those wants and more, I have to say that, during the times I've checked the temp immediately after it's beeped "ready", it hasn't always been at the temperature of the present selected, but rather well under. My thermometer is pretty consistent and professional-grade, so I don't think that is an issue, but it could be my particular kettle or other factors, and I'm waiting to purchase a better thermo later to confirm the issue. For now, it's not a big deal; I just set it a little higher for my delicate teas to reach 175, 180, etc., and have since gotten it down pretty well. It also brews slower than the Aroma I had. I do love the delicate beep (I hate beeping lol), but could see some people complaining about it being too quiet in loud households, and I also appreciate the light that makes it easier to see how much water you have.

With that said, while I love the kettle, I'm not sure I would repurchase it again at just around one hundred dollars, should this be an all-around or ongoing issue with the kettle and not just my own. I just don't feel it's worth it in that price range, though perhaps a bit lower. I tend to find it a little overpriced as it is, but it is a great piece otherwise and I love at least being able to have it stop at a certain point, even if it's not completely accurate, sometimes being off by 10 degrees or more. I just recommend checking your temp if you're into temperatures while making tea.

You can also find plenty of product reviews on Youtube if you want to see how it works.

I still own the original Cuisinart food processor. I have a newer Cuisinart food processor and many pieces of their cookware. I love the brand. I was looking for a kettle for my morning cuppa tea, and ordered one of these. Initially, I was delighted with it. I've had it about a year, and can now tell you what's wrong with it.

The first issue that I had does not apply to many people. I live at 8,300' ASL, so water boils at a lower temperature. If you set the kettle to "Boil", it will not turn off at high altitude. It will finally shut off when the water level gets low, so it's not the end of the world. A minor issue, specific to a tiny fraction of customers.

The big problem with this kettle is the construction. There is something about the seam at the bottom that does not take the heat cycle well. The kettle can sit cold, for days, and will not leak. If I fill it, and turn it on, after it comes to a boil there will be a half dozen drops of water between the base and the kettle. That would not be a big deal, except that the kettle has circuits that worry about water being where it does not belong. Ten minutes after you turn it off, it will start beeping and flashing and misbehaving, to warn you that there is water where it should not be. It's annoying. About all that you can do is to set the kettle on the counter, next to its base, rather than on it.

I would not buy another one.

Purchased this item in October as a gift for my mom and it no longer works. Quality is not what I expected from this company. I contacted customer service from this company and they are giving me a hard time. I would expect better service when paying for a premium for a water heater. I do not recommend this or any Cuisinart product

I bought this in November of 2011. This gets nearly daily use and is still operating. It has worked flawlessly for just short of 8 years. Recently, I've noticed that it seems to take slightly longer to bring water to a boil, but we just moved, so there might be other factors contributing to this. I would highly recommend this kettle. It has exceeded the lifespan i expected.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does one job and does it well
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this about a month ago and so far it's working out well. I like that it only beeps 3 times (softly) when the water's ready so it doesn't wake the whole house. I'm giving the kettle 4 stars instead of 5 just for a few reasons:

* The window to see how much water's in the kettle is blocked by the handle (and your hand) when you're filling it up, so you have to do a pause-n-peek.

* It's kinda loud when the water's heating up, but this might be more of a chemistry thing than a product one.

* I know there's been some confusion about the controls and the Start button, but it's not a big deal. I think they could have just called labeled it "On/Off" instead of "Start" and it'd be more clear. Takes 10 seconds of trial and error to figure out what to do, so it's really not a big deal.

Hope this helps!

reviews.reviewTitle: I absolutely love my Cuisinart water heater
reviews.reviewText:
This is such a great water heater. It takes like 30 seconds to heat up a cup of tea now, and I think it's much more efficient than heating on the stove because when you do that you lose a ton of energy to heat. It's also so nice to know that it will heat it to the right temperature, even if it's not perfectly exact as some people have complained about here. I always make sure it's empty when I'm done and leave the top open after I'm done so it dries out completely. I think that will extend the life of the product.

In response to reviews that people said the numbers on the buttons wear off over time, I push the buttons with my two fingers, one on each side of the numbers. It's a simple technique that avoids touching the numbers, but isn't very hard. I absolutely love the convenience of my perfec temp water heater, highly recommend!

Pros-Quality materials and a great look. The ability to heat to different temperatures is key if you like different types of tea or different brews of coffee. The 'keep warm' feature is great if you are sitting around having tea or coffee with company and want more than one cup.

Con-The kettle gets extremely hot to the touch. You can burn yourself if you touch it when you have it on the 'boil' setting. This is really the only issue with the unit, otherwise it would be 5/5 stars.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect water temp control, excellent electric kettle
reviews.reviewText:
If you drink a lot of tea then you should treat yourself to this wonderful electric kettle. Very well made and easy to use, it comes with a fine grill at the spout to catch water impurities and has a convenient cord length for your kitchen counter.

Different tea types do best when steeped in the correct temperature water and this Cuisinart Perfect Temp kettle gives you all the delicate temp increments you need to make the most of your expensive teas.

Not only does it bring the water up to your chosen temperature but it has a hold feature that will keep the water at temperature for another 30 or so minutes. Your water is ready for you when you come back for your next cup !

The base has a good gripping surface, the kettle rests securely on the base and the different temperature buttons are nicely lit with a blue glow. The water gauge is very easy to see and read, it holds 1.7 litres of water, it turns itself off automatically and has an easy open lid that releases with a button on the handle.

Water temps for particular teas are :
160F Delicate
175F Green teas
185F White teas
190F Oolong
200F for French Press coffee, grain beverages etc.
Boil for black teas

Green, white and oolong teas really do turn out differently when you use the right temp water.
I have never had a problem with any Cuisinart product and their appliances last a long time. When you buy a Cuisinart appliance you're paying for better heating elements, motors and technology.

Worth every penny !

reviews.reviewTitle: Best temperature selectable kettle on the market.
reviews.reviewText:
This is a great kettle in that it heats water quickly and precisely. There is a metal screen mounted in a plastic frame that is supposed to filter out the hard water particles as you pour. That doesn't work as well as I had hoped so I still have to wash the kettle regularly with vinegar water to manage that issue. But, it cleans up more easily than other kettles I've had.

At this price point, I was hoping for double walled construction to make the outside touch safe. It is a little counter intuitive for me to select the temperature and then remember to press start. I would prefer to just press the temperature button and move on. Similarly, it is a little counter intuitive that I have to press the keep warm button to turn the kettle off if I don't want it to automatically go into keep warm mode.

If Cuisinart reads these reviews, fine tune your product to make it an even bigger success. Figure out a way to heat the water silently and you'll be the only kettle people buy in the high end of this market.

reviews.reviewTitle: A perfect wedding gift for tea-lovers
reviews.reviewText:
My son recently married a young woman from Japan and I included this kettle in the assortment of kitchen gifts that I chose for them. Like many Japanese people that I have known, Kanako is used to having green tea readily available both for herself and to offer to guests. My son perefers black tea as well as French pressed coffee. When I discovered this item I was very excited to see if it works as advertised. They liked their's so much that I purchased one for myself. Here is my take on it:

Like many other Cuisinart products, this one is fairlly attractive. The controls are very intuitive and exceptionally well defined. The proper temperature for several different beverages are printed on the handle right next to the button that brings the water to that level of heat. I don't know if tea experts would agree with these parameters but it seems to work well for me. My only complaint is that the "beep" that alerts you as to when the water is at preset temperature is pretty quiet. I really have to strain in order to hear it. Other than that I am very happy wifh this product. My new daughter-in-law told me that it is perfect, but she is well known for being extremely polite. :-). However,I think that she too is happy with this cordless kettle.

We have hard water is this part of the country and it causes a lot of problems with products like this. I use filtered water in my kettle and I have not had a problem with scaling in the many months that I have been using mine. So far this product delivers all that I could hope for in a cordless kettle.

*** UPDATE ***
My original review of the Cuisinart CPK-17 purchased in 2011 can be found below this updated review:

Recently the CPK-17 purchased in 2011 stopped working when I accidentally splash water on the handle control . We've loved the product and immediately bought a new one. The current product on the market is rather inferior to the one I reviewed originally.

* Boiling water is 30% slower. The 2011 CPK-17 brought 1L of water to 212°F in 4m 30s, the current one does it in 5m 50s under similar ambient temperatures and starting water temperatures.
* The newer model has black lettering in the water window instead of white, which is more difficult to read.
* The water window itself is more difficult to use. It often has condensation inside the window that makes it difficult to gauge the water level.

If you've never used the earlier model, there is still plenty to like in the CPK-17, but if you have you are likely to be somewhat disappointed.

*** ORIGINAL REVIEW ***
My fiance were originally considering buying a Japanese style water boiler like this one Zojirushi CD-LCC40 Micom 4.0-Liter Electric Dispensing Pot, but changed our minds when we couldn't find one that had a metal interior -- most are plastic -- nor one that could be set to go directly to the desired temperature without boiling first. I'm glad we decided on the CPK-17, because it is a great kettle and perfect for our needs. We drink a lot of tea, so it's nice to be able to set the temperature for delicate tea, green tea, white tea, oolong tea, french press coffee, or black tea.

As I mentioned before, the kettle will not boil the water first and wait for it to cool down to the correct temperature like all of the Japanese dispensers I've seen. This is important to me, because it can take quite a while for 1.7L of water too cool from boiling -- 212°F -- to the correct temperature for green tea -- 175°F. In addition, there are no plastic parts that touch the water, so there isn't any off-taste you can sometimes get with kettles with plastic interiors.

I use this kettle all day long, almost every day, and have had no issues with it. It's well-built and looks great in our kitchen.

For those interested in heating times, here are some quick measurements I took to heat water coming from the refrigerator dispenser which is approximately 50°F at sea level in a 75°F environment:

0.75L to 175°F : 3m 5s
1.00L to 212°F : 4m 30s
1.70L to 212°F : 7m 55s

reviews.reviewTitle: This Cuisinart electric kettle is not stainless steel as it claimed it was.
reviews.reviewText: We dislike this product after using three months because it started rusting interior/exterior. We worry if it is safe to drink the water. Cuisinart should be a good brand, but it needs to be re-evaluated for this particular product.

I LOVE this kettle. I knew I wanted this kettle after using it at work, and loving the functions it has. I am an avid tea drinker, and I drink tea from leaves, not tea bags, so to be able to change the temperature is wonderful. It's as simple as pushing the right button, and off it goes. I've always wanted to make my tea with the water temperature that the tea containers mention, and with this kettle, it's easy.

The water boils fairly fast, but one thing I did notice is that it is pretty loud. Maybe it's just me, but when I have this on in the kitchen boiling water, I can hear the bubbling in the living room. I live in a 2BR apartment, but it shouldn't be so loud that it bothers me! Other than that, I have no complaints. It's very user friendly, and I love that it is cordless - it makes it very easy to fill up.

I've been using it for 8 months now, and it's going strong. Good construction and great product. Highly recommended if you are a tea drinker! (or a french press coffee snob!)

I use this thing daily for things including herbal, green, or black teas, oatmeal, or french press coffee. Okay, I admit I have used it for ramen noddles when I didn't want to cook. So far, I haven't had any of the lettering rub off like in other reviews. It has always been consistent in temperature and can reach a boil surprisingly quickly. Before I had this, I would boil water on the stove like a barbarian. After having this kettle for almost a year, I don't think I could go back to the stove or even a lesser model. It makes mornings easy because I don't need to babysit it. It beeps at me when it's ready and screams at me when the water has boiled out. Not that I emptied it and put it back on the stand without turning it off and went into the other room. That never happened, but if it did, it would have screams at me.

I like this product enough to give it a second chance as the first one died 3 years and one month after purchase, one month past the warranty. I bought the extended warranty for an additional year this time. I like the various settings and the fact it will keep water warm for a period of time in the event you want a second cup. I drain it at night and if if develops the water stains, I find that a soaking in vinegar and water removes them. Just rinse adequately before reuse. Unlike a kettle on the stove top, I don't have to worry about becoming distracted as I know it will turn off automatically.

When it works, I love this kettle. High capacity, sleek, multiple temperatures, beep when it is ready? Great! I got a year and a half out of my first kettle before it just stopped heating water. It did that at pretty awful timing, and I was a mess. I needed tea and it failed me. Warranty replaced the kettle (at a $30 processing fee!!), and I got a new one. The new one worked functionally, although the lid mechanism was slightly broken. I suspect it was a refurbished one that had been previously returned. Nonetheless, it heated my water and I was happy. It lasted 9 months, and now it too has failed. It doesn't heat water. Hit the buttons, it lights up, nothing happens, then it gives 3 beeps before giving up.

For $100 (+$30), I want a product that is going to last a damn long time. I'm a college student, I can't keep throwing money at kettles. It should be my one big purchase and live a long and prosperous life after that. This is not the case. It lives a beautiful but short life. I will be seeking a different kettle in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: My water heats fast and to the perfect temperature
reviews.reviewText: I bought this because I used it at a friend's house and loved it. I hate heating the water for my tea in a microwave and it can take awhile to heat it in a kettle on the stove. Now I get my water fast! But, what I especially like about this is that it heats to the perfect temperature for each different kind of tea! And, it stays at that temperature for a half-hour so that I can relax over breakfast and refill my cup several times, always getting the same mouth flavor.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worth $70, not necessarily the best choice at $90
reviews.reviewText:
We liked this kettle so much that when a family member wanted one we ordered the same one. However, when searching for it the price was normal, but every time we tried to put it in our cart the price mysteriously rose significantly. As it was a gift asked for specifically and no one was planning on being near an actual store to buy one that way, we gave up and paid $89.99 for a kettle that if you pull it up under an incognito/private viewing tab goes for $67.71.

Basically, this is absolutely a good choice at under $70. Once the price goes up to $90, however, you've got enough other options that this isn't necessarily the best choice. So make sure to check what the price is once it gets to your cart before deciding.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Gold Standard of Electric Kettles
reviews.reviewText: Stop. Just stop. Buy this one. That's all you really need to know. Multiple accurate push-button temperature settings, ability to keep warm up to 30 minutes. Large kettle holds 1.7 liters of water to keep the most avid tea drinker hydrated. It is easy to fill, easy to see how much water is left, and attaches/detaches from its base with ease. If you're looking for the best kettle you can get - this is it. The end.

reviews.reviewTitle: I drink a lot of tea now!
reviews.reviewText: I like drinking tea, but I just sort of stopped over the years and I realized it's because it was such a hassle and the whistle of our old teapot gave me anxiety. Enter this lovely little thing, which I originally bought for my boyfriend but am definitely using it all the time myself. I love how I can set the temperature to such a degree that I can drink my tea right away. And it heats up so quickly and just beeps gently when it's done. Love it! The sides do get hot, so be careful there.

I received this kettle a week or two ago and have used it for french press coffee and tea steeped in a mug and in a teapot. So far everything is excellent. I love the keep warm feature, as I don't often jump right up to get the water when it says the water is ready. I love how the pot itself is wireless so I can take it across the kitchen. My tea and coffee are perfect! No more thermometers to make sure the water is the right temperature!

The only things I don't like are that it's not as quick as I'd like, that's not to say it's not faster than boiling water stove-top or in the microwave, but I've had kettles that heated faster. Also, the outside of the kettle gets very hot, keep things away from it when heating water. The handle is no problem, that's quit cool, so no worries about burning yourself, just make sure there are no other items touching the kettle and that young hands stay away.

Great kettle for the price!

A few years later and the kettle works as it always has, it’s just the temp labels on the buttons have all but worn off, leaving me to either remember what they are or look up a picture of the kettle. It also left some rust stains on my counter, but that’s partially my fault for not wiping underneath it when fluids are on the counter, HOWEVER, it’s a high traffic kitchen counter... it’s going to get wet, I just wish the base were as rust resistant as the rest of it.

Been using this every day - I am retired and my wife and I drink green tea all day. Works great.

Only "failure" was the top release which broke. Now have to open it by hand. Just one of those junky plastic pieces that was mis-engineered.

If we ever have to replace it, I will get the same thing again.

12/11/14 Just bought another. Bought the first one on 04/14/12, nearly 1,000 days, and it has spent almost every day from 7 AM to 10 PM more on than off. I had hoped it would last longer but... These are expensive - the biggest drawback - but they are also really great to have. Don't see any other I would consider. So it's one of a very few items I splurge on. Hope they fixed the cheap top opener.

04/14/16 Second one now has a leak. As much as I like this pot I will be looking at others because I feel the quality has slipped on this Cuisinart and I cannot justify the cost with questionable quality. Wish I had a better experience as I like it - just does not live up to its price. Should last more than two years.

My husband hates this water kettle and begged me to keep using our "old reliable" Braun with only one temp setting (boil). I bought this kettle because I am a tea drinker and the temperature of the water you use makes a HUGE difference in flavor. For that reason alone, against my husband's wishes, I am keeping this kettle. I will admit that there are some very irritating aspects to this kettle though:

1) As others have said, the water does not pour smoothly out of the spout. I'm not sure why. It makes it seem like something isn't right and hurts the overall feel. You don't have a lot of control over how big the stream is or how smoothly it pours. I've never experienced anything like that before.

2) When you heat to a boil, it boils for quite a while before turning off. I defend it by saying that it must not be up to the right temperature yet even though the water is fiercely bubbling. It will feel like it is boiling too long though. It is enough to make me worry about my cabinets getting so much steam on them - so I try to keep it pulled out and away from my cabinets.

The adjustable temperature feature is huge for me, so I'm willing to put up with these annoying quirks. However, if you find a competitor at a similar price with the adjustable temp feature, I would recommend that you try the competitor.

reviews.reviewTitle: It was good as long as it was working except the plastic smell and taste till i take that part off.
reviews.reviewText: Even if it says no plastic parts there is the plastic filter part which makes the water smell like plastic when it boils. After using 6-7 months this kettle it is not working anymore. I purchased the third party warranty through amazon when purchasing this product but there are no numbers to call or eamil to reach anyone.

So this made it 1 year 3 months before it started to fail with varying frequency until it failed all together.

The lights are on, it's descaled regularly, its never been abused or dropped and used maybe once a day or so.

But after doing nothing for 2 minutes or so - it shuts off and that is that.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great until it breaks, no support
reviews.reviewText:
Fabulous Kettle, use it multiple times a day. Until it suddenly stopped working, 10 months in. Doesn't heat, and starts beeping incessantly. Cuisinart refused to tell me what is wrong, only that I have to ship it back to them and they will send a new one - both at my cost. This adds up to approximately half the cost of the unit. That's insulting, and given their current scandal regarding broken blades (we're also affected by that, thank you very much) you'd think they'd bend over backward to keep customers happy.

Rather throw it in the garbage (actually tear it apart and recycle bits) than give them any more money.

Because I depend so much on other reviewers' comments for products on Amazon, it is my turn to catch up and give back.

I bought this kettle on Dec 25, 2010, and, within a few days, I fell in love with it. I used the kettle at least 4X daily, and all was well until Jan 30 when it malfunctioned. The blue lights came on, but the water did not heat, and the unit shut itself down after 30-45 seconds.

Normally, I would give a product a 3-star rating because of the above problems, but due to the amazing customer service from Cuisinart, I'm giving this 4-stars.

On Feb 1, I called Cuisinart CS and talked to a LIVE person within two minutes! I explained the problem and they asked me for more details, including if I had purchased the unit less than 90 days before. Without any proof of purchase, they told me to pack the kettle and base up for shipping and issued a UPS Pickup Order. Two days later, UPS picked up the box and it did not cost me anything! On pickup, UPS gave me a tracking number and I was a little perturbed that it took five days to get the broken kettle back to Cuisinart in NJ (from FL).

Fast forward, I received my brand new PerfecTemp Kettle today (Feb 21). According to the packaging, it is not a refurbed unit.

So, in summary, I'm hoping that the first one was just a lemon and the new one will last me for years because I have so missed having it around for the past month for my tea and coffee.

Off topic note for those of you that love French Pressed Coffee, check out the $25 AeroPress Coffee and Espresso Maker. Someone's post on the thread for that product pointed me to this Cuisinart Kettle.

AeroPress Coffee and Espresso Maker with Bonus 350 Micro Filters

I'll update this post if I encounter any more problems with the new Kettle.

I use my French press coffee maker every day, and I bought this to save time boiling water for that. I really like that I don't have to estimate the water's temp post-boil, and instead can precisely select a desired temp. I've also been making a couple types of tea, which require different water temps for steeping, so this kettle is great.

I haven't had the kettle long enough to comment on long-term durability, but it's well-made, easy to use, heats water quickly, and looks great. I really couldn't be happier with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: This product is very bad. I bought it in January and after a ...
reviews.reviewText: This product is very bad. I bought it in January and after a little more then 2 month of very gentle use it stopped working.
