I’ll update this review after my warrantee customer service experience.

reviews.reviewTitle: Loved the kettle - perfect temps and truly the best ...
reviews.reviewText: Loved the kettle - perfect temps. However, this weekend - 11 months after I bought it, the top stainless disk of the lid came off - which it seems controls the locking mechanism...and the whole thing is now kaput. I'm English and have owned my kettles for years and years - and was honestly concerned about the amount of tech involved in this kettle. However, since it was Cuisinart I thought I'd give it a try. Surprisingly, it wasn't the temperature or buttons that failed, it was the lid. No lid, no kettle. I'll be looking for a different model now.
I bought one for myself and one for my mom. We have been using it for months. The quality is great.

My wife she love it , and she can accept any other brand at least this one.
High quality and amazing product.
The kettle heats up quickly and has several choices of settings. I like that the water stays hot for 30 minutes.

After seven months of daily use using both low and maximum temperatures, the only wear that has been observed so far is on the button labels for the most used settings. The kettle still consistently heats up quickly even at full capacity, and all settings operate properly. No electrical issues in either the kettle itself nor the base have been seen, and all of the lights and alert sounds behave as expected.

The kettle is sturdy and stable, and easily held at low to medium capacities, though the buttons are in an awkward spot once it gets full and heavy. It also doesn't have the surest grip when full; it can start to slide somewhat as the handle is pretty smooth all around. The base holds well to the surface it sits on, and a full kettle may need to be lifted prior to moving the base lest it skip if slid.

The filter is easily removed and cleaned, and we've not noticed any unusual cleanliness issues in the interior. Cleaning is a simple process and there is a reasonable amount of space for a brush to get in and scrub if necessary.

I'd recommend it for anyone who wants a solid, sturdy, well-performing kettle that allows temperature control. I'm not sure it would be ideal for a true tea or coffee aficionado, but for anyone else it is both flexible for particular tastes and reliable if you just want some boiled water in a hurry.

Never thought heating up water is this fast and easy. Great product and the most thing i enjoyed about this item is that it's programmable and you can heat up water to different level which makes convenient for some people. So if you ask me, do i recommend this product? i highly do :) FYI, i've been using this for just 2 weeks since this post/review was written.

reviews.reviewTitle: They break eventually on a long run...beware!
reviews.reviewText: Bought two of them and both broken, one within 3 years and another one last only 1 year. Control buttons do not work at all. You have to pay for the shipping both ways over $30 for the warranty replacement! I'll go with another competitor / product.Cuisinart CPK-17 PerfecTemp 1.7-Liter Stainless Steel Cordless Electric Kettle

Not easy to get a good cup of "proper tea" these days so I chose this electric kettle because of the different temperature levels for different teas, as well as the Keep Warm and "cordless" features. One kettle full of water will warm the tea pot and mug and brew enough for 2 cups of tea. Don't forget to make or find a tea cozy - essential :-). Some reviewers have said it makes too much noise, but at this age that isn't such a bad thing. Quicker than my previous electric kettle (replaced after 20 years because the plug got too hot) and looks nice on my counter. I would have given it 5 stars, but I always leave room for any improvements of modern technology.

This is the best electric kettle I’ve ever had so far! It boils water so fast. It has options to make different kind of tea and coffee. I also love the design, it’s so sleek and pretty. Very recommended!

This is the perfect electric kettle. I bought one for work and loved it so much I bought another one for home, even though they are 80-90 bucks.
It heats up water 10 times faster than a kettle on a stove, and even better, it keeps the water at that temperature without whistling or boiling over. Until you're ready to come over and use the water! I use it for my oatmeal, then for my coffee press, and then in the afternoon for my tea. Everyone near my cubicle is used to the sound of it now.

I needed something at the office that would heat water for tea. This allows me to heat to different temps and the option to keep it at that temp for 30 mins is great. Getting to the temp isn't too loud -- it sits only a couple feet away from me and I actually find it to be quieter than other kettles I've tried. It also gets to the temp quickly which reduces the noise. Assuming it continues working like it has, this was well worth the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Function good, first one only lasted a few months.
reviews.reviewText: I like the temperature functions. I ordered a second one after the first one failed after a few months. Will see if this one lasts longer. The sound when it reaches temperature varies from almost nothing to something you can actually hear. The plug failed on the first one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use. Heats up fast. Love the preset temps.
reviews.reviewText: Heats up fast. Useful temp settings for different kinds of tea.
It’s a lovely kettle - it’s just that to turn it off you have to keep pressing the button until all the lights go out. That’s a pain
Great while it lasted but broke under less than 2 years of light use

I purchased this for my office so that I can make tea and meals that require boiling water while at work. I have a collection of quality loose teas, and really appreciate the fact that this kettle heats to different temperatures depending on the tea variety. It also heats within a minute or two - much faster than I had anticipated! I use it to make easy-mac or instant oatmeal on the boil setting, and have had a good experience with that, as well. If you are thinking about this model, I say go for it!
Love the preset temp options and that it reheats the water for you- great for our coffee and tea!

reviews.reviewTitle: we are content with our purchase and would recommend to others
reviews.reviewText: We have been using this kettle for about a month now. It is very aesthetically pleasing and heats quickly. We appreciate the 30 minute stay warm feature and the boil dry protection. To prevent rust, we try to empty the kettle and leave the top open for it to air dry. The one drawback to this kettle is that the pour stream is not smooth, particularly in the last 10th of the water capacity. Since we try to empty the kettle when we brew this happens frequently. Otherwise, we are content with our purchase and would recommend to others.

It's a very good kettle. Lots of functions and it's very light for a stainless steel kettle. We used to have similar Krups kettle and it was very heavy. The only reason I did not give 5 stars to it is that there is no water temperature indicator and I am used to it with our old kettle. Otherwise, I highly recommend it.

Update after one year of usage:
Temperature info on the buttons faded away in about 6 months.
Kettle stopped automatically shutting itself off in about 7 months.

Disappointed. Reduced the rating to 2 stars.
By far one of the products that has most positively impacted my life! I drink a lot of sencha tea and the 160-degree setting is awesome! I use it mutiple times per day.

Tea snobs dream! I've had this for over a year & has worked perfectly every time. The water temperatures are exactly what is needed to make different teas & coffee. It's worth the investment to always have water at the right temperature. If you use water too hot it will burn & water not hot enough won't fully steep.

Make sure you always use distilled water!

This electric kettle is good, but it's finicky. There are several steps to getting it to boil water. If you miss one of the steps, or accidentally press the wrong button, it can be a real bugger to get it to reset itself.
So happy with all the options and with how quickly it heats the water!

reviews.reviewTitle: Wonderful kettle, it has a feature to keep the ...
reviews.reviewText:
Wonderful kettle, it has a feature to keep the water warm and this works in our household of four adults with competing schedules.
It is easy to clean and easy to operate.
I loved this kettle at first, but before it's first birthday, it has rust at the bottom and the lettering on the buttons is rubbing off. It still heats fast and well, but RUST- no thanks.

Liked this kettle until it started leaking after about 1 year. At first it was a tiny bit, then my counter top and floor flooded today. Seems like a major fire hazard to have water leaking from kettle while turned on. Will not be replacing. Disappointed in another poor quality small appliance.

My daughter in law had one and I used it daily while visiting them. Ordered it before I left Duluth, Mn and it was waiting for me when I got back home to Kentucky. The water is perfect to make my tea!

I've owned the Cuisinart PerfecTemp electric kettle for 18 months and use it several times a day with various temperature settings. It works reliably without any problems. I bought this model because of the variable temperature settings and it's the best teakettle I've ever owned.
Bought this for my daughter. Heats up fast. Great quality
I use this multiple times a day! Worth every penny. Just hard to clean my hand is too big. I bought a baby bottle brush to use to clean it

reviews.reviewTitle: A Year Later and Still Kicking
reviews.reviewText: Very happy with this product. Does everything it said it would and that makes me a happy camper. Cleans easily, looks good, love the different temp options. Light in weight. Just great.

The wife loves her tea.The last one lasted five years...Same model(older).
We use it a lot....

reviews.reviewTitle: Get one for half the price it will actually last
reviews.reviewText: Started out just fine but all of a sudden just stopped working. Just after warranty of course. I have had other kettles for years and I went with this one because it was supposed to be the best. So disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: great product as I used it but it broke in 2 years of use.
reviews.reviewText: Really like it but it broke after 2 years of normal use, good it has 3 years of warranty, hope I will get it resolved easily. I still like the kettle and functionality of multiple temperature options.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very nice item - but it stopped to work after 6 ...
reviews.reviewText:
Very nice item - but it stopped to work after 6 months of a use. I don't understand how a company like CUISINART can sell such unreliable a product.

I contacted a Cuisinart customer service, as this is their most expensive el. pot - and they don't even bother to respond. Will post any reactions.

I love cuisnart products, and I was very happy to find this stainless steel electric water kettle. However, despite the reviews I have read here, I bought the item, and I was disappointed. It looks very chic on the counter top but the water it boils smells like plastic. I boiled 5 pots of water before I actually used it and the smell still didn't go away. On the website, it says the plastic they use is BPA free so thats not the issue but I hate the smell. I will be returning the item for sure.

But if you don't mind the smell, this kettle boils the water in 7 min if you fill it to the max amount (1.7 Liter) - which is pretty quick. Also, when its boiling water, the outside surface is hot to touch. when I was cooking, my arm touched it by mistake and now I have a minor burn on my arm :/ yeah I know thats my clumsiness, but if you have kids around the house or if you are clumsy like me, thats another issue to watch out for.

I gave 1 star to this item because 1) the water it boils smells like plastic, 2) I would rather to have all stainless steel and glass compartments rather than plastic compartments for the price I paid, 3) I will burn myself with this item
- But on the plus side, it looks fancy and boils water fast.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not the most perfect pouring - I can see why not recommended for ...
reviews.reviewText: Not the most perfect pouring - I can see why not recommended for pour-over. Love the settings though. Does sometimes get confused if not enough water and won't reset without unplugging and plugging back in. Overall though love this.
Love it, glad to have and we have been using it for couple months on daily basis
After 3 years it started to leak

This kettle is everything I wanted and more. The versatility of the six temperature options is great - I've been drinking nonstop tea! The handle is very grippable, the speed with which it heats very quick, and the blue lighting over the water that lets you check how much water is left with much ease - all great.

My only concern is leaving the kettle sitting for a couple days without use. It could just be that I'm really sensitive to the taste of water in general (and I know it's not just the city I live in because I've brought this with me to a number of other cities and had the same problem), but I find that when I do this, the taste is kind of mineraly and stale... I think this happens to most water when you let it sit, though, and since I often drink 1.5 liters of it within a day or two anyway, it's really not that much of a problem!

Some people say they've had trouble with it overheating, but I've had no problems whatsoever and would strongly recommend this to any connoisseur or newbie of the tea world alike :)

So... My husband killed my leCreuset tea kettle about a year ago. When I went shopping for a replacement I discovered (much to my dismay) that I couldn't find just the right thing. So I started shopping for an electric tea kettle. Like other reviewers I wanted one that was not entirely plastic on the inside and out. This is for two reasons - exterior aesthetic and toxicity. It is entirely impossible to get entirely away from plastic in our environment. But after reading various reviews about plastic taste and weird smells I decided to look exclusively at stainless steel interiors for my electric kettle. This, of course, greatly increased the potential cost of my future kettle and narrowed my options considerably. I have been visiting this particular model on amazon for about 8 months. It seemed like a lot to spend and my 1 qt stock pot and electric range were doing the trick. I didn't NEED a fancy electric kettle. I kept dropping hints, hoping someone would get it for me as a gift. No one did. Seems like no one thinks kitchen electrics say "I love you" quite like accessories and spa treatments. Those people are wrong! Thislittlemagic machine says I LOVE YOU every morning afternoon and evening when I push it's little blue backlit buttons! WHY didi wait SO LONG?!

Everyone is happy. You'll be happy too. This thing is solid.

reviews.reviewTitle: Liked the fact it has multiple temperature settings
reviews.reviewText: Liked the fact it has multiple temperature settings. Perfect for tea drinkers. Auto warm setting is also useful, it just re-boils the water after it senses temp goes down. The kettle has decent insulation and keeps water warm for a while.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hard to see where the water line is but best kettle out there yet
reviews.reviewText: Hard to see where the water line is but best kettle out there yet. Great for being able to have different temperatures. Takes a few tries to remember to not push "stay warm" when I don't need it to stay warm and to push "stay warm" when needed. But that's my personal problem!

This was a great convenience for our morning beverage rituals...for about 2 1/2 months...at which point it stopped working...and it's past the 30 day return window. Not happy blowing almost $100 for a short lifespan. I'm going back to the ol' (reliable) stove top kettle.
Works great. Is everything the web page says it is. The lowest temperature setting is still too hot for me, but it cools off fast enough. I'd buy it again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Liked it while it worked, broke down after 1 year of use
reviews.reviewText: This tea kettle looks great and I liked it when it was working, but after one year all the lights started flashing constantly, the only way to turn it off was to disconnect if from the power supply. There is also a design flaw - liquid measurement display is behind the handle, so you can't see it well when puring the water in. Due to high price and short service time, I do not recommend this item.

I absolutely love this kettle. I've read the reviews carefully, and my main concern was the rust. So, what I do is everytime I use it, I take a blow dryer and dry the heck out of it where it leaves no water spots. It looks new as ever.
Wow This is a very nice addition to the kitchen. Works great

As a water heater this performs fine. It is far inferior to the tea kettle it replaces. The original was glass, not so heavy and had a function that timed the specific tea you were brewing. Very disappointed

Bought this as a gift for Father's Day. The first one we received did not beep when it was done and this was a feature we really wanted. Amazon gladly replaced it within the same week. The second one works perfectly. Nicely made and easy to use. Look forward to using this for a good while.

reviews.reviewTitle: Comparing it with KRUPS, there are highs and lows.
reviews.reviewText:
Comparing to KRUPS BW730D Breakfast Set Electric Kettle with Brushed and Chrome Stainless Steel Housing, 1.7-Liter, Silver.

This kettle performs exactly the same - when set to Boil, it boils 1L of water in exactly the same time as the KRUPS.

Ergonomically, the handle is less comfortable than KRUPS - you can't reach the Open button as easily.

I like that it turns on to the last setting when you pour some water in it and put it back on the base - no chance of forgetting to turn it on, which I do on occasion. I also like that it beeps when it's done - 5 quiet chimes. I definitely like that the lid is insulated, and doesn't get very hot.

I don't like that the scale is on the back - when you pour water into it while holding it in your hand, it tends to read low (the kettle tends to lean forward, due to the handle not very well designed). Have to adjust to pour less water into, in the hopes that it'll be correct when it's back on the base.

But there is a problem: the lid sticks when the kettle is hot. Sometimes it takes a few seconds to open, sometimes it doesn't open at all, and you have to wait for it to cool down (or pry it open with something - when is risky if you choose your fingers or nails). I ordered a replacement.

/edit Replacement arrived today, and I see the problem. There is a slight difference in alignment of the lid. My first kettle has the lid shifted off-center maybe about 1mm toward the front of the kettle. This is enough to make it bind when it's hot. The second kettle lid is right on center, so it doesn't bind. Buyers beware.

reviews.reviewTitle: Terrible experience - after amazing reviews I got it one ...
reviews.reviewText: Terrible experience - after amazing reviews I got it one for my flat ( I live in Switzerland). First two trials - blackout in the whole appartment. Then I started working for couple of usage and then game over. The blue light is still working but this is all. And be aware IT'S NOT CORDLESS
Love the flexibility of choosing the water temp and it heats up very fast!

My first electric kettle was a simple Cuisinart that I received as a gift about 10 years ago. I believe it lasted about 5years. I used it about 3 or so times a day. After that I have purchased several misc. branded kettles. The other kettles I purchased were around the $30 range. None ever lasted very long. Some rusted. After my latest Kettle debacle, I decided maybe I wasn't investing enough money in a kettle. I remembered how great ,and pricey, my original Cuisinart was and decided to research those. Amazon had a great price on the CPK-17. It was the lowest I was able to find. the CPK also had almost 5stars. I was sold.
It does everything it says it will. One reviewer said Green Tea heated to the appropriate temperature no longer has a bitter flavor. They were right!! I am no longer force feeding myself green tea. I actually enjoy the taste! I have had fun trying out the settings. Coffee and teas heated to their recommended temp taste better than they did before.
The CPK-17 is definitely well worth the investment!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for making a wide variety of teas
reviews.reviewText: Great for making a wide variety of teas (white, green, oolong, etc--and even coffee)--press the appropriate setting, and you are alerted with a beep when the water is done. Easy. Life transforming for a tea lover like me!

heats to 200 for coffee with push of a button- no more watching to catch before it boils
Just great

Fast, convenient, easy to use. I bought it for our office. The first Cuisinart kettle we had, in use daily by mulitiple people lasted for 10 years. This one is nicer, better. The only quibble is that the handle is very wide and awkward to hold when the kettle is full. The work around is to use two hands when pouring.
5/22/17, I had this for a few weeks and use it all the time for tea, sanitizing, boiling water for pasta (as to save on gas and time when cooking) and well just cleaning items. Great so far.
Poor design. The display Is misleading and confusing. Overall not good value.

Glad I have it... I've used this every day for two years now to make my coffee in the morning. Only critique is the numbers rub off after only about 1-2 months I really only use the 200, boiling and start button so not too big of a deal for me. Tea lovers may have a bigger problem with it thought.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for a while - started leaking 4 months after the warranty ran out.
reviews.reviewText: started leaking after 3 years and 4 months. Was wonderful until that point. As I remember, this was the longest warranty I was able to find on an electric tea kettle. I think we've gone through at least half dozen different ones, from a variety of different companies, over the years. They're all wonderful until they fail, and it seems that they all do.
We had an electric kettle for 10 years (RIP). This is to replace.... so far very good & easy to use. May it live for 10 years like the previous kettle.

I have owned electric kettles before, and they were "good enough" to boil water, but this one is far superior. I originally saw this kettle in an article in wired magazine. I then checked out Amazon reviews to see alot of positive feedback. It is as promised. While I do not often use the other temperature settings since I mostly drink black tea, when I do, it is spot on. If I had to think of a negative, it would be that the kettle gets hot. I know...so do all the others, and so does a pot. My only concern is that it can be deceptive. You can shut it off and it will still be hot. It is not an issue for me, but might be for someone with small kids.
Perfect tea kettle. Can't imagine life without it. Use it to make tea, boil or heat water quickly, and it works super well and looks beautiful on my countertop.
Don't usually buy single-use appliances, but this one is well worth the counter space. I use it all day.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love the different temp settings on this electric pot
reviews.reviewText: Really like the heat settings as I drink green and white teas and you can't tell if your water is too hot and burning the delicate leaves. Have had the pot for several weeks and it works consistently and well. Would recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome kettle....makes coffee and tea taste great!
reviews.reviewText: Awesome kettle...really easy to use and great functionality....heats water to perfect temperature for coffee or tea...keeps water warm to set temperature....awesome price and quality for this kettle....you will really enjoy it with your next cup of coffee or tea.

After having many kettles over the years, this is the best. It is fast, heats to specific temperatures and keeps the water at the right temperature for a good while. We had it for almost five years before it stopped working. Would be nice if it worked longer than five years. Note that I live where the water is very soft and pure, so we never had calcium build up or any issue with sediment.
I would give it 5 stars had it lasted longer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not the Same Company it used to be...
reviews.reviewText: Less than a year of occasional use to make 2 cups of tea and this Lousy Kettle is already leaking water from under onto the wireless charger !!!

reviews.reviewTitle: I have had it for a year now and it operates just as beautifully as it did new out of the box
reviews.reviewText: I am an avid tea drinker and this has proven to be absolutely necessary in my kitchen. I have had it for a year now and it operates just as beautifully as it did new out of the box. I have noticed that it's a little difficult to clean the inside. We have hard water that creates calcium deposits on the inside, but that is my only complaint. I love the different settings! I highly recommend!

Loved this kettle because of all the choices of temperature settings. Bought one for both sets of inlaws. Ours and my mother-in-laws were bought in summer 2014. Now in October 2016 had to replace one becauase the hinge on the top broke. Now have to replace a second because, as many reviewers have complained, the kettle stopped working suddenly. Lights up but does not heat up. I suppose 2 years is not bad, but it seems it should last longer. Will probably purchase another because we did like it a lot while it worked.
Love this kettle to heat water for my tea. It's fast and has several water temps.

I had the old style Cuisinart electric tea kettle from 10 years ago. A friend of mine was using a stove top tea kettle when I convinced him to buy an electric tea kettle. My old Cuisinart was still working like a charm so I told him to buy the same brand.
He received the NEW model and when I saw it, I ordered it for myself. I love to drink green tea and this model had multiple temperature settings and for green tea, the water can not be boiling or it ruins the benefits of green tea and makes it taste bitter. This is the best tea kettle I have ever used. I also ordered it for my Mom who loves her tea. If you are a tea drinker, this would be the ultimate. You can see the water level at a glance, use the "keep warm" setting and have another cup of tea in seconds. Not to mention the great blue neon light.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very good for nonstandard (i.e. non-boiling) temperatures
reviews.reviewText: I love this kettle. I've had it for about a month and a half and it's great. If you don't turn it off, it will hold the selected temperature for you (it will keep re-heating as needed to maintain that temperature). If you take the kettle off the base during the heating process, you can use some water and then put it back on the base -- without pressing anything, it will resume where you left off and continue until the desired temperature. If you drink and hot drinks at temperatures other than just "boiling", this kettle is worth its price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Would definitely recommend. Great for making tea
reviews.reviewText: Been using this for years. Would definitely recommend. Great for making tea. Much easier to know when the water is the perfect temperature for white, green etc teas. Now I just need to time actual brewing. Perfect tea every time.
Pretty efficient and good-looking machine! Love the temp control for various infusions.
this was a gift for a friend

I had to give this 4 stars instead of 5 because the BASE is flimsy. If you rock it a little bit, it loses power. When you lift the pot, the BASE raises with it... Never had that problem with Breville.

The 4 stars come from how quiet and fast the machine is. The temp. is perfect so far. The machine really shines when it comes to tea. I use it for coffee as well, French Press, and it is perfect amount of heat. It is hot but still drinkable, it is not cold...

I bought this product because the controls are on the handle which saves a lot of space. It is very simple, you hit the button for what you need the water for and press start. If you feel like your going to be distracted, you press the keep warm button and it holds for 20 minutes. LOVE IT!

The pro is that it is quiet, the con is that you have no idea when it is done. The machine will finish heating up the water and you have no idea.

Great Machine, I DO RECOMMEND. I believe 3 stars are for what is advertised and I gave it 4 for being quiet and space saving. Looks great. It lost a star for having a flimsy base that is very light weight and sensitive.

I bought this product mainly, for the convenience of the push button lid opener, which hasn't worked in over a month, I couls have bought a similiar product for half the price. Is it still returnable?

A lot of good things about this electric teapot. Well built. Easy to use and fast to boil. You do need to clean it out carefully when you first get it. After that it is good to go. Does green teas at the perfect temp. Short cord however. Looks great on the countertop and the blue backlight is snazzy.

This worked great for the purpose. Water got to the desired temperature quickly and the stay warm feature is great. It does not have a large footprint to be left on the counter. I appreciate the different water temp options.

Only had this pot for a couple months-so far I really like it. I like the various temp. selections for types of teas, aside from "boil".
I use it about 8 x's per day, seems well made, love how it looks, less bulky like some of the others, well designed, esp. compared to my last pot, "Chiefs Choice", which was looked hunky, less streamed line, and not as well balanced-also did not like the vulnerable on/off switch on that Chiefs Choice.

UPDATE: I've now owned this for 4months-the damn thing quit working this morning! Yesterday I had smelled a slight plastic or electrical burning/melting odor-now I know why! It turns itself off and nolonger heats.
Now I'll have to go through the hassle of packing it up, go to post office, & sending it back to Cuisinart-I'll be at their mercy not knowing how long it will take to replace. Errr.

Buyer Beware.

My only complaint is that it specifies a temperature of 185 degrees F for white tea, which is much too hot for a typical white tea. The "delicate" setting provides the proper temperature for every white tea I drink which require 155-165 F water, but this is sort of thing is easily handled with a bit of tea preparation knowledge. Overall, a solidly built product which has removed the burden of personally checking the temperature of the water with a thermometer. Now I can start water for tea, shower, get dressed, and have everything set to brew my tea by the time I am ready to drink my morning pot. reviews.reviewText:
We are a family of tea drinkers and purchased this item to replace a traditional stove-top tea kettle. We are extremely satisfied with it and wish we had bought one years ago. It takes up about the same counter space as a coffee maker but is sleek and stylish. You can easily see the water level so you know with a glance whether you need to add water before you start heating.

The controls are very easy to see and use and it is great to have choices for the temperature relative to the type of tea (white, green, black, or French press coffee) you will be making. It does make some noise as the water heats, but no more than a regular coffee maker or espresso maker or regular tea pot. And it is fun to watch the water start to bubble.

My only complaint is that the little beep that tells you the water is ready isn't very loud; you can't really hear it from another room. However, since the water heats up so fast, you don't need to go do something else while you are waiting. By the time you get out your tea cup, preheat if and select a tea, you are almost ready to pour. If you do walk away to do something else, the unit will shut off automatically after 30 minutes and will not boil dry.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Kettle, Unfortunately Electronics are Defective!
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this electric kettle because the one I had prior (though otherwise wonderful) just started to leak one day. This seems to be a chronic hazard of this category, unfortunately. I also have started drinking tea so thought having a device that would heat to different temps might be a good thing. (At the moment, I'm not entirely sure that this is important or necessary.) For these reasons, it seemed as if this, more expensive than I would normally want it to be, high quality kettle would do the trick and it is a different design than most of the others so didn't think leaking would be the problem and, so far, it's not.

I've only had it for a few weeks and it is a pleasure to use and wonderful to have a kettle that doesn't intermittently leak all over the counter top at unexpected times. The problem is, as has been noted in other reviews, that the electronics in the kettle are defective. This manifests in it staying turned on long past the short time it's supposed to once it's returned to the platform. Even after I get it turned off, it will turn itself back on (as in the light) after that, at unpredictable times. Most of this is easily solved by simply not returning the kettle to the platform but alongside it, I discovered. (even when it's hot, the bottom is not hot so this can be done). I'd be willing to keep it and live with it that way if it wasn't for the fact that sometimes the electronics malfunctions in a different way, as in not turning on at all or turning itself off in the midst of trying to boil some water.

For the price I paid, seems as if this should not be an issue within weeks of receiving the kettle. It was 90 something dollars. Seems to me nothing about these things is likely to improve and it's more likely to get worse until the kettle doesn't function at all. Given that it's not a manual or simple electric connection and depends on the more complex electronics, I will sadly be returning it.

Now I don't know what to get.

reviews.reviewTitle: The best electric kettle on the market. Needs a tweak or two.
reviews.reviewText:
Fantastic kettle. Great design, a wide range of choice temperatures, stainless steel interior. I'll let the others speak for those. This is the best electric kettle on the market without exceptions. But you can make it better, and the next version of it could use a few changes:

1) Totally eliminate all plastic components that contact the water.

The scale filter is removable. Thats in the product literature. But the scale filter bracket is plastic, and it still touches the water when you pour it. It also messes up the flow of the water. Fortunately, that can also be removed! There is a single screw that attaches it to the wall of the kettle with a hex nut. Unscrew it with a pair of pliers and it's done. Be sure to remove the hex nut and the two washers - you dont want to be swallowing those by accident. I've attached pictures of the removed bracket. In the future, this kettle would benefit greatly from a metal scale filter and bracket that can be totally removed.

Fortunately, once you remove the scale filter bracket, it pours like a dream.

The lexan water height meter leeches BPA. That is a damned shame about this kettle. And the water there gets HOT. This should be made out of glass, or simply removed totally. If you want to know how much water is in the kettle, you can open it! Look, I agree it's pretty, and it reflects blue light when theres water in there, but it's unhealthy. Health is more important than the little lexan window! And it's pretty enough already!

Bottom line - remove the window completely. Put markers on the inside of the kettle indicating the volume if you must. This lexan meter is a real spoiler.

Finally, the silicone nubs. I don't care if people think they are safe, get them out. You dont need a silicone nub to measure the temperature of the water, and you should take out the nubs related to the water level window. Fixed.

2) The kettle is a pain to carry for long distances. There is no handle to hold the weight of the kettle from the top. So if you have to walk with a full kettle for more than a few feet, it's rough on the wrist, because you're holding it from the side. And you can only hold it one handed. There should be a long rotating handle over the top that can fold down out of the way when not needed, but can be used to carry the kettle from above. Again, we can see the product designer getting in the way of a proper device. Sure, you want clean and modern. But a little old lady cant walk very far with these things, and a rigid swiveling handle that rotates down under the pour spout would also let someone hold the weight with one hand while pouring with the other. How is that little old lady going to have her tea parties now?

3) The stainless steel exterior is great, but (a) it's a fingerprint magnet, and (b) it gets too hot. For (a), the exterior should be clearcoated. We see lots of clearcoat stainless steel appliances today, and they are good with the fingerprints. not perfect, but good. Also, they feel much nicer than the metal. For (b) make the kettle's walls double layered stainless steel with air in between. This will allow it to retain heat longer. Also, it wont damage the clearcoat. The kettle is not too large, and it could reasonably be made slightly larger in order to permit a double layer. Also, you dont need the fill guage, so the double layered walls arent stopping anything.

4) The pour spout is FANTASTIC once you eliminate the scale filter. Do not mess with that!

reviews.reviewTitle: Despite its sexy design and high price tag, this ...
reviews.reviewText:
Despite its sexy design and high price tag, this is a very low quality product. Truly unforgivable is the faulty temperature sensor, which resulted in steam damaging my kitchen cabinets. Other reviews indicate this is a common problem.

Pros:
- Appearance & design.
- Multiple temperature settings.

Cons:
- After a few months of light use (once-twice per day), the low-quality temperature sensor fails to turn off the unit until several minutes of boiling. The released steam envelops the cabinetry above the kettle, which I discovered has damaged my kitchen cabinets. Given the cost of this kettle and the cost of replacing kitchen cabinets, this is absolutely unforgivable and makes me reluctant to ever buy from Cuisinart again.
- The labels on the buttons smudge off after a few months of light use. Not only does this look ugly, but you have to guess which setting corresponded to which temperature.
- The lid started jamming when I push the button to open it.

Overall, a cheap made-in-China gimmick marketed and priced as a fancy European product.

Pros:
*Attractive
*entirely stainless steel
*convenient easy to operate light up buttons (one each for 160 degrees= delicate, 175=green, 185=white, 190 = Oolong, 200=French Press, Boil=black, start, and keep warm printed on each button) and stay warm feature

In summary, I'm very happy with this purchase and recommend it.

Purchased this kettle on January 27, 2012, used it as much as several times a day to as little as 1-2 times a week, and by mid-April it stopped heating water entirely. The unit powers on and programs as usual but after about 3 minutes, it beeps three times and shuts off leaving cold water in the kettle. Please note: I was very careful in my handling and care of this kettle. I did not get the controls wet, the unit was never washed in soapy water or submerged (I only wiped it down inside and out with a well-wrung out damp microfiber cloth sans cleansers of any kind), I did not utilize the "keep warm" feature nor leave the unit plugged in or on after use (it was always returned to a cabinet (carefully!) after it cooled), it was never dropped, banged, manhandled or otherwise mistreated. In fact, I babied this kettle. The thing still broke.

When the unit works, you will love it. When it fails so soon after purchase, you'll be kicking yourself, probably saying (as I did), "Something told me not to buy this! Why the heck do these types of things always break so darn quickly nowadays?"

While this product does come with a 3-year limited warranty, you must pay $15 s&h to Cuisinart to ship you a new or repaired unit as well as pay to return the broken kettle (approx. $15). So, you're looking at spending $30 to get a functioning kettle which is roughly 40% of the intitial purchase price.

Reading through the low-star reviews, I see that it's common for the kettle to stop working within several months of use so I won't be spending another $30 for a replacement given chances are good that the replacement kettle will fail in a few months time as well.

In my opinion, to have an $80 tea kettle fail after three months is wholly unacceptable, and due to its high failure rate within a relatively short period of time, I cannot recommend this product.

Caveat emptor. Seriously.

Terrible design. Cannot turn the *&%^$#$ thing OFF!!! Wakes everyone up. Incredibly annoying.

Here's how it works. Pour in water, press temp button, press start, water hits temp quickly and kettle beeps like ten times really loudly (which you can't turn off by the way so it wakes up everyone within earshot) , pour out hot water, replace on base, try to turn of by pressing start button as it says in instructions --- but it won't turn off! It just continues to flash and flash and flash at you. Start button has no effect at all. To get it to turn off after you pour out the water, you have to leave it on the counter, still very hot by the way, and not replace it on the base for a while. Finally after enough time has passed you can put it back on the base and it remains off. Stupid design. Every electrical appliance should have an OFF switch that turns off the item immediately - for safety's sake -- it's only common sense.

Do not buy if you have to use this early in the morning and someone in your family sleeps near the kitchen. It sounds like a really loud alarm clock when it reaches the target temp and it wakes them up. I now have to take it to a bathroom, and use it with the door closed to keep it from waking my kids. My other dislike is the beeper that signals when the water has reached the set temperature. It needs to be louder. Of course if it were louder then some other folks likely would complain that it is too loud. So it would be nice if they would incorporate a variable loudness setting.

I have noticed that in a few reviews people are blaming scaling (mineral deposits) that forms in the kettle on the kettle itself. Scaling is an issue that depends on your particular water chemistry. No kettle can prevent scaling if your water is hard. If your water is hard then any kettle will form scaling if you do not rinse it properly. If you frequently pour to the very last drop of water do not just set the empty kettle back on the base. Fill it with a cup or two of water, give it a quick swirl, empty that and then fill it back up for next time. Doing that will help keep that last thin film of water in an empty kettle from completely drying. When that thin film of water dries that is when minerals are deposited.

If you do get scaling occasionally pour a cup or two of white distilled vinegar in the kettle , heat it up, let it cool and then wipe out the insides with a cloth.

After buying it as a Christmas present for myself, I have thoroughly enjoyed it and have used it all day long every day. I read the bad reviews before and after I bought this kettle. Here are some observations from what I read in the 1 and 2-star reviews. For those of you that have had the kettle only last for a few months, to a year... I know that this kettle is expensive and should last longer. I would bet that after you pour a cup out of your kettle, you just set it back on the stand and walked off. This will put it into the hold temperature mode for about 30 more minutes. I know this is a feature but do you really need it to hold 212 degrees for an additional half hour? If you turn it off and then go back 30 minutes later and heat it again, it only takes a minute or two. Leaving it on puts unnecessary extra wear on the product fuse and heating base. I'm not defending it for burning out early, just suggesting a way to extend the life of the kettle. Next, I have read that after a month, a man and his wife still couldn't figure out how to use it. Really?! You push the temperature you want and hit start, it beeps and stops blinking when ready. Got to wonder about that poor rating. Another one complained that it didn't boil water any faster than their kettle on the stove. This is the one that gets me the most. If all you want to do is boil water, then save your money and boil water on your stove. This kettle is designed for tea lovers and press drinkers where a more precise temperature is required. This is what it is designed to do. If you throw boiling water over say, green tea, you have destroyed it. Press is best at 200-205 degrees. I, personally, got tired of boiling water then standing there with a thermometer waiting for the temperature to drop for my press coffee. If you just want to boil water... skip this and save your money. Another complaint was that the bottom was flaking off the inside of the kettle. It's called "mineral deposit", from your water. A little vinegar boiled once a month will solve this. If you have a coffee maker (it's the number one reason it will quit working) or a tea kettle on your stove, it's in there too. Another complaint was it was hard to fill and see the level. If you pick it up off the base and set it back down, it will light up and it becomes the easiest item you'll ever own, to refill. And lastly, several complained it was hard to keep fingerprints and dirt off of it. It's 'STAINLESS STEEL', wipe it with a damp sponge and dry it off. I have enjoyed it so far because it does what it is designed to do. A little preventive maintenance (turn it off when not needing it), routine cleaning ( as you should be doing with your coffee maker) and common sense ( the biggie) then hopefully you will not regret purchasing this kettle. For those that have treated it correctly and still had problems, you have an actual right to complain, but those other reviews, like described above, c'mon guys... common sense.

I love this kettle. It's very attractive, it's very easy to use, it heats quickly (1.7 liters of room temperature water to a boil in about 7 minutes), and those temperature settings really do matter. It's well insulated so it tends to hold heat well even without the 30-minute stay-warm timer turned on.

I drink French press coffee and green tea, so this kettle gets used a lot (at least twice a day), and I can attest to the difference that the various temperature settings make. 200 degrees makes for wonderful French press coffee, and 175 takes the "bite" out of green tea while preserving all the delicate flavors. Although I typically only use those two settings, they are REALLY nice to have.

You can't get your hand inside this kettle, but then again you shouldn't have to. The sight glass is pretty much covered by your hand on the handle when you are filling the kettle. I think that's an acceptable design compromise and not an issue as a practical matter. I use the time-tested method of looking inside as I am filling the kettle to see how full it is getting. The sight glass *looks* great - it is illuminated along with the buttons on the handle - and it is easy to read when your hand is not wrapped around the handle so you can tell if you need to add water before hitting the start button. That's all I need from a sight glass.

Ease of use is excellent - one handed operation in a dimly lit room is a snap. Thumb the desired temperature, thumb the start button. Soon you will hear 3 beeps (audible without being annoying) that let you know that set point has been reached. Aside from the beeps, the light on the temperature select button goes from blinking (heating) to solid (at set point temp).

This kettle draws 1500W, so be mindful of what circuit it is plugged into and what else is on that circuit. Also consider whether you need to heat a full kettle for a cup of tea. The less water you heat, the faster it gets to set point temp and the lower your power consumption.

There is a removable fine screen filter in the spout - I found it made pouring tricky and I removed it.

All in all, this kettle has worked its way into my everyday routine in a way that no other kitchen appliance has (and I have quite a few). If and when it dies, I'll replace it with an identical unit. I'm more than pleased with it. It looks great, works great and is easy to use.

I would recommend this kettle unconditionally were it not for the 1- and 2-star ratings that reveal a high manufacturing defect rate. I suggest reading those reviews. I'm giving it 4 stars instead of 5 due to the nagging fear that the kettle will fail in normal use. Cuisinart really should take a look at the manufacturing defect rate on this product. It has a nasty tendency to cease working. Some report failure not only in the kettle received, and also in the REPLACEMENT that was sent to address the first failure. That's a clear red flag ... but I was prepared to take the risk in light of the features offered for the price. Hopefully I won't be revisiting my rating on a product failure.

I looked for a long time for the kettle that was going to be the best fit for me, and I am so glad I finally found it. This is just what I needed.

Pros:
- Easy Setup: Just open the box, give it a quick rinse before filling with water, plug it in, and you're good to go.
- Easy to use: The intuitive design makes it quick and easy to see if the kettle is on or not, how much water is inside, and what temperature the water is.
- Multiple temperature settings: No matter what kind of tea you are brewing, you can get the water to just the right temperature to bring out the best flavor of the tea.
- Tea in minutes: No more waiting for water to boil and then cool to the right temperature, or starting the water boiling and forgetting to turn it off. The water is quickly heated to the correct temperature, and the kettle keeps it at the temperature for up to 30 minutes. You can turn it on, walk away, and when you come back your water is perfect for whatever tea you are making.
- Light weight: Easy to pick up and pour, even when it is full.
- Cordless: The cordless design and swivel base make this work a lot like a traditional stove-top kettle.

Cons:
- It's louder than I expected while heating the water. It doesn't disrupt other activities, but it was a surprise the first time I turned it on. It's also only noisy while the water is heating, so just for a few seconds at a time.
- The outside of the kettle gets really warm. The handle stays cool, so I didn't notice the heat until I accidentally bumped the side. No injuries, but I would definitely take care to keep it away from small hands.
- The small top opening makes it hard to get clean. Luckily, my hands are small enough to fit in there to dry it out between uses, but I don't think my husband could clean it.

Overall, the few problems are relatively minor compared to the ease of use and overall design of this kettle. I am sure this will stick around for a long time and see a lot of use in our home.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fool me once - shame on you; fool me twice - shame on me...
reviews.reviewText: When it works - it's great. The warranty looks 'great' as well - on the surface. The problem is - I'm on the second one of these and it no longer works as it should. The first one failed within 10 months of daily use. Cuisinart's very courteous customer service replaced it for me at 'no cost'; MINUS my shipping cost to them and MINUS their shipping cost to me. Which ended up being about half of the original purchase price. I used the second unit for about 6 months before it starting experiencing problems as well. While the first one failed outright (you set the temperature, hit start, it beeps and does nothing); the second one simply does not heat any more to the selected temperature. A few examples: you chose a setting and it runs for about 15 sec, then beeps and stops. To get it going again, you have to select the temp one step below what you actually want, let it warm up to that temp and stop, then select the temp you REALLY had in mind, and it will warm up some more and produce the desired temperature. When it's in the mood to do so... From time to time it shuts off within 10 sec no matter what the temp selection. Other times, but not ALWAYS mind you, when you set the temp to 200 F (which is what I use most of the time for green tea), it brings the water to boil instead. And when you set the temp to Boil - it sure does bring it to boil (whenever it is not in the mood to shut off after 10 sec that is); then keeps boiling and boiling and BOILING for a good 10 minutes before it finally shuts off. It looks to me like either the control unit or the temperature sensor(s) are not built to last. The bottom line is - the purpose of this water kettle (brining water to desired temperature) is not fulfilled. It works for a period of time, than breaks. Not worth buying. I bought a replacement multi-temperature kettle from ALDI for $9 for when my Cuisinart dies. If the ALDI unit fails, I don't care. It was $9. Plus I kept the receipt and they WILL take it back at REALLY no cost to me. None of the $30 spent shipping back and forth for yet another piece of junk. Needless to say, I think I will be staying away from the Cuisinart brand going forward. And most definitely - I will never EVER again be gettin one of their water boiling products.

We boil 1.5L of water for tea pretty much every morning with our old trusty copper tea kettle on a gas cooktop. I was eager to get this pot so that:

1) I didn't have to wait as long to pour up my tea on those days I forget to come downstairs and put the kettle on before I get in the shower, and
2) If I turn this one on before getting in the shower, it should keep the water warm till I'm ready for it without the annoying tea kettle whistle.

Well goal #1 is a complete bust. I measured 1.5L of cold water from my tap using the CPK, then poured it into my copper kettle. Then I added another 1.5L to the CPK. I pressed Boil on the CPK, then turned the gas burner on and pressed Start on the CPK simultaneously. I started my kitchen timer and waited.

The copper kettle on the gas stove whistled at 6:30, +/- 3 seconds. The CPK took a full minute longer, reaching a boil at around 7:30. It didn't beep and switch to warm mode until 7:46. (Test was performed at about 300' above sea level.)

I was quite surprised, not to mention disappointed. So I waited a while until both kettles had cooled off and repeated the test. The results were identical to within just a few seconds.

Despite my disappointment, here are a couple of other quick pros and cons:
Pro: Large spout pours quickly.
Pro: Easy to fill through spout - don't even have to open lid.
Pro: Easy to operate the buttons and seems like quality construction.
Pro: I overfilled it a little, but it still didn't boil over. I probably had about 1.9L. The water level was still on the indicator, not above it.

Con: Although the first 95% of the water comes out quickly, the last 5% takes forever and streams out in three or four different directions.
Con: The fill indicator is difficult to see behind the handle.

Sadly, I'm probably sending it back.

The temperature settings on this kettle are open to question. The "boil" function is accurate; the water boils. But the lower temperature settings seem to be lower than advertised. For the green tea setting of 170 degrees, my cooking thermometer said the water had been heated to only 155 degrees. Since I brew green tea, I tried the other settings and found that 190 degrees gave me 170 degrees for my tea. So that's what I use. Is my cooking thermometer right or the tea kettle? I don't know, but I had a second cooking thermometer that agreed with the first, so I'm betting the kettle is off. This means that your boiling water always passes through nasty smelling plastic each time you pour. Horrible. Also, the kettle has no insulation, so you'll burn your hand on the exterior if you touch it after it has boiled. If the kettle was better insulated the 30-minute "Keep Warm" feature wouldn't need to use as much electricity. In fact, we have turned off the "Keep Warm" feature as having a kettle with a super-hot exterior sitting on the counter for 30-minutes is bound to end up in a burnt hand one day.

reviews.reviewTitle: Emperor's clothing or a disguised space rocket from the 1950s?
reviews.reviewText:
Looks the part, but has gone up over $10 in price since we purchased it 17 months ago. I certainly wouldn't get it again. It looks nice, and the blue glow is pleasing enough, but for what it is and seeing people struggle with it, nahhh.

It comes down to poor design, not the functionality of being able to change the temperature of water. For an old tea-bag like myself, I have to wonder whether the designers actually ever used it to make something as simple as a cup of tea.

Once the kettle has more than a teaspoon of water in it, people tend to hold the handle much higher up due to the displaced weight and the required manipulation, combined with wrist strength when holding it in the middle or lower end. You won't want to hold it near the bottom, it's hot, and that makes for a burny-burny boo-boo.

Having over 30 years experience of kettle manipulation for lots of "cuppas" (tea), the weight balance is very poor. I can cope, but my wife, her mother, her father, and any visitor (welcome or not) clearly struggles to not hold the handle at the top when it's not near empty. And guess what? The top is where all the temperature and keep warm buttons are. I.e. anyone that isn't the spawn of Xena and Hercules is going to constantly be crushing the buttons while they move or use the kettle. Which means putting it back on its phallic charger base protuberance with undesired settings EVERY TIME!

The actually container shape is also complete rubbish. When it contains plenty of water, the pour is fine and consistant, but as the water depletes, the water doesn't pool sensibly inside when poured. The top is thinner that the rest, this creates a reservoir of water below the regular pour-line. Bionic individuals can anticipate what's going to happen and react the femtosecond in question, but puny mortal humans will discover a 0.00001° change in inclination at this point will transform the escaping water from the mere dribble to a torrential deluge shaming Niagara, and over-filling the desired live in the mug.

tl;dr: it boils water, it's ergonomically challenged. I like the blue illumination.

I didn't expect much out of this kettle, but it fell a bit short on one critical point. The only thing that I was looking for was that it was primarily stainless steel on the inside (minimal amounts of plastic or rubber). On that note, this kettle did fine. There is a small rubber piece (presumably where the temperature control feedback thermocouple is), and then the plastic on the back that displays the volume of water. There is also a bit of plastic near the spout, but that doesn't touch the water until you pour. The temperature control is nice, and it holds ample water.

Here is my disappointment: If you only heat up one person's worth of water (~8oz), you cannot pour the water cleanly. The first time I poured water out, probably 1/3 of the water missed my cup. Note that this is not a lack of hand-eye coordination, but a poor design. The small piece of plastic near the spout somehow prevents water from exiting cleanly. It ends up coming out of the edges of the spout. This does not seem to be a problem when you fill the kettle full - only when you fill up a small amount (1 serving) of water. In order to avoid spilling now, I have to pour tremendously slow (10 seconds per 8 oz cup).

Will I return it -- probably not. I usually feel bad about returning used equipment that still functions. That said, if I had to purchase again, I would buy a different product. The temperature control is nice, but not worth the difficulty in pouring.

reviews.reviewTitle: In The Event Your Cuisinart CPK-17 Has Ceased To Function
reviews.reviewText:
After about 8 months, mine stopped working in the same way it seems others' have - still makes lights and sounds but no heat. I was able to revive it though by disassembling and cleaning the bottom of the circuit board with rubbing alcohol. I'm not an electrical engineer and have no idea what I'm talking about, but this is what worked for me. It is probably very dangerous though, so don't do it.

With that said:

you will need this screwdriver h[...] (in case this link is removed, search amazon for "triangle screwdriver", first result)

remove the 3 screws from the bottom of the kettle

gently dislodge the plastic bottom piece - there are fine short wires connected to it, so be careful you don't yank it

there are 3 white connectors attached to the circuit board - carefully slide them off, trying not to bend the long thin contact wires

now that the bottom piece is separated, you have to get the circuit board off - there is one screw in the middle and 3 (or 4) plastic tabs that must be broken

the back of the circuit board will most likely look grimy and corroded - try to clean it with a cloth and rubbing alcohol

ok, now put it all back together

of course the circuit board is just going to dangle in there now, since you've broken the tabs. I didn't even worry about it.

You can test it on the base plate before completely reassembling, to make sure there aren't loose wires. I mean, I did, but it's probably dangerous, so understand you alone are responsible for your health. Hope this helps. Wish I would have taken pictures, but it's really pretty self evident once you start, as long as you've got some intuition for these things.

reviews.reviewTitle: As pleasant to use as the tea it brews
reviews.reviewText:
I recently ordered this kettle and another one for comparison sake. This stainless steel kettle was about twice the price of the other one, which was plastic. I had had a plastic electric kettle for seven years and was very happy with it, so I thought I would try one again due to the very good price. (The Philips ordered in 2003 is no longer available). I would also try this one because of the high rating and many features.

The plastic kettle had higher wattage and did boil the same amount of water about 30 seconds faster, but this kettle wasn't far behind. It was really a tough choice because both kettles had good features the other one didn't necessarily have. Unfortunately, they are both a bit heavy - especially when filled - and both their exteriors get hot, but I guess that is to be expected.

Ultimately I chose the stainless. It is very quiet and emits no unpleasant smell or taste. It had lots of features I didn't have to have, but I am enjoying very much: settings for different types of tea, pretty blue l.e.d. indicators, and a pleasant beeping sound that indicates the water is ready.

Today I'm returning my second CPK-17. I really wanted this kettle, but I'm not paying $90.00 for a kettle with a visible discolored mark smack on the front of the kettle. Cuisinart placed an adhesive sticker (2.5"x4.5") on the front of the kettle to highlight some product features. The sticker is supposed to be removed before you use the kettle. When I removed the sticker (both times), it left a dark discolored mark where the sticker had been affixed to the kettle.
I would love to try this kettle, but I don't want to look at a brand new product with a large discolored mark on the front. Sorry Cuisinart, you are screwing this one up. The really silly thing is that the kettle comes wrapped in plastic, the instruction booklet is wrapped in plastic, the cord and base is wrapped in plastic. Maybe some bright person at the manufacturing plant could think of placing this sticker (which is meant to be thrown away) ON THE PLASTIC and not on the kettle where it ruins the beautiful stainless steel.
I've called Cuisinart twice and they don't really seem to care. I've told the customer service rep to pass on the message not to place stickers right on the product. I'm not hopeful things will change.
The kettle might be good, but I didn't even try it. It's going back and this time I'm asking for a refund, not a replacement.

I orderd this hoping it would replace an old GE unit that started to leak. Based on the previous reviews My wife an I were hoping that this unit would provide years of service.

While we were sure that it would not deter from it working performance we felt that for a $100 teakettle it should be in better condition. It was returned for a replacement with Amazon.

Unfortunately, the Krups discontinued that model and was looking for a replacement. I think that European brands make better kettles because tea is more popular in Europe than in the US. reviews.reviewTitle: Great features, poor durability and service
reviews.reviewText:
The features of this kettle are great, especially the keep warm feature and the easy temperature control. The insulated carafe is wonderful, too. However, I've had two of these. The first began leaking a couple months after purchase. I actually paid the shipping to return it and have a replacement sent to me, about $30 all in. When the replacement came, it didn't leak and I was overjoyed. However, within a few months it malfunctioned and would no longer operate. SInce I use a kettle several times a day this is not good.

I threw the kettle away and bought a cheap one which has functioned flawlessly for over a year now. It doesn't have all th bells and whistles of this kettle, but Cuisineart really tarnished their name with me with this product and their poor customer service. When I started looking for toasters and toaster ovens and other appliances recently, I avoided their brand because of this experience.

I like this product for its speed and for the keep warm function. I mostly drink black tea so don't often use the lower temperature controls, though they have been nice to have a couple of times. So, why four and not five stars? It just failed a couple of days ago. I don't recall when we purchased it, but my love tells me it is less than a year old.

Short story: Keep your receipt attached to your product manual so you can return this product if it fails within three years. Do not fill out the registration card as it is for marketing and privacy invasion. Product support does not have access to the information and it does not help you if you need a warranty repair or return.

Long Story:

Cuisinart customer service just said to me that the registration card is for marketing and they do not have access to the information I already gave the company, so they had to go through taking all my information and use the serial-number to confirm it was still under the warranty. The product manual says, "We suggest you complete and return the enclosed product registration card promptly to facilitate verification of the date of original purchase."

They have printed a lie. Customer support, managing the return process, does not have access to this information. The warranty card has nothing to do with your warranty, so do not fill it out or bother to register on-line. Just keep your receipt and product manual.

Second issue. They did try to charge me $15 for shipping and handling. The product manual says, "California residents may also, according to their preference, return nonconforming products directly to Cuisinart for repair, or if necessary, replacement, by calling our Consumer Service Center toll-free at 1-800-726-0190. Cuisinart will be responsible for the cost of the repair, replacement, and shipping and handling for such products under warranty."

When I protested they pretended to look-up something and said it was an "Early warning product..." so I would not have to pay shipping and handling. I believe it is actually California law that says they are fully responsible for the failure of their products. No one anywhere should have to pay any cost of return for a product under warranty. That cost is built into the price of the product when you purchase it and an incentive manufacturers to not skimp on quality.

Evangalizing:
I recommend that if you live outside of California you start contacting your elected representatives and demand they adopt a law that requires manufacturers that sell products in your state to support you when the product fails. Things that fail within warranty ought to be repaired or replaced without charging you for it. If this does not include all the costs of doing the repair/replace (including shipping both ways) then they just use failed products to take your money when it fails, gives companies incentive to make low quality products, and shifts quality control to the consumer making your life harder.

Nice design, but had ordered the wrong one. Doesn't fit for our 220v! Trying to send it back.
Best regards.

Got this about a month ago and have used it nearly every day since, usually multiple times a day. The water heats quickly to the desired temperature. In addition to heating cups of water for tea, I also use it to quickly bring water to a boil for cooking pasta, etc. I love being able to heat the water to specific temperatures for different types of tea, and this was the main reason I selected this kettle.

While I was also looking for a stay-warm feature, I now find that I hardly ever use it. The water retains its heat for long periods anyway, so I usually find it is easier to just quickly reboil the water when I'm ready for more than to keep it heating for a half-hour straight. I think this feature will be much more useful for entertaining.

As some people have noticed, this kettle is pretty loud when boiling water. I use another electric kettle at work (also Cuisinart) which is quieter, as is my good-old-fashioned stove-top kettle. I find it's louder when boiling smaller quantities of water, but I still love the kettle. This is just a heads up.

One other small annoyance is that the water level guide fills slowly, so if you're trying to be precise you have to pour slowly, pause, and wait for the guide to catch up. I'm assuming it is designed this way so most of your boiling water isn't touching the plastic guide, which is nice, just something to be aware of.

Overall, this is a fantastic kettle which is absolutely worth adding to your kitchen!

UPDATE: I've been using this kettle multiple times a day for nearly a year and I still love it. As some others have mentioned the text rubs off on the most used buttons. I've found this mostly happens if you touch them when your fingers are wet. Love this kettle!

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice kettle but has a few cons that might negate it's pros...
reviews.reviewText: This is initially a very nice looking kettle with a wide range of options. As tea is the most commonly used drink in my household it's used every day many times. It's very solid with metal construction and filter is not breaking up like most of cheaper versions I had before (and this was a reason I got this one). I mostly use highest temp setting for all kind of teas so that's the button I use most. It's a bit heavy but you can expect it. What I didn't expect is that labels on the kettle started to wear out in the very first year. In the next year or so the mostly used buttons practically had no labels visible. On the third or fourth year lid won't pop up when you press a button to open, you have to push it open which could be a bit tricky if your kettle is still hot from the previous use. I thought about using lubricant like wd-40 to lube it but afraid I wouldn't be able to use water from it for some time:) So unless you really need special settings for different teas simple plastic electric kettle would work as good as this one and cost much less, even considering you have to replace it every couple years. It would also much safer to a touch and easier to lift (if we have guest and kettle is full I'm usually the one who has to pour water from it as it's too heavy to do it safely for everyone else). So when I'll have to replace mine I would probably get one for under 20 bucks like I have now at work.

reviews.reviewTitle: Would have loved this kettle if not for the cheesy labels on the preset buttons.
reviews.reviewText: Cuisinart still has not updated and fixed the problem with the Set Temp labels??? HUH? Yes, what a surprise that such a nice item still hasn't been redesigned since the time I bought mine nearly 7 years ago. Doesn't Cuisinart know that this is a great tea kettle with just one, easy to fix flaw. If only. The labels for the presets all wore off within one year of ownership. I did use a premanent ink marker to fix but that wore off again after a year. So the spring load mechanism in the lid finally broke and it won't open unless I pry it open with a fork. Time to find a better mouse trap. To replace it, I looked and looked for something that had the same features and maybe improved upon the label problem. And what did I find, but a great kettle at half the price of the Cuisinart. Yeah, it's not quite as nicely built, but I like the design way better. My best kettle in the past was a very inexpensive Krups which lived on and on. Sometimes the aesthetic build quality becomes less important to you if the item can't deliver on functionality. So this time I purchased the Gourmia GDK340 (btw, never heard of this company before). It's not flashy like the higher end GDK380, but it's a bargain price, half the price of this Cuisinart. Added bonus, Gourmia uses a glass bowl so I can see from across the room if I need to add more water. So far I really prefer the Gourmia to the Cuisinart. We'll see if it can keep chugging along for 7 years. LOL

reviews.reviewTitle: Falls short of the Cuisinart name!
reviews.reviewText:
I like to buy most things only once, so don't really mind paying a premium for quality, and this kettle promised to be something more than a twenty-dollar cheapo. Bad call on my part. Here's what went wrong with my 6-month old teapot, from someone who's been using electric teapots since they were invented:

This teapot is incredibly noisy, and became progressively more noisy as time went on; in fact, became noisy to the point that one day I thought my neighbor was at it again with his leaf blower early in the morning. I realized as I took out the garbage the other day, that I can hear this teapot some 200 feet away! The other problem is that the numbers wore off the push butons, so I no longer have any idea what temperature I set. It doesn't matter if it's "programmable" if you can't see the numbers.

When I called Cuisinart it was apparent that they were familiar with both problems, as the customer service representative asked, "Like the howling of a wolf, right?" With regard to the numbers disappearing, she suggested that maybe I used a strong citrus-based cleaner to clean the pot, which I did not. (Forget that it's the numbers I use most often that wore away, it must be the detergent, sayeth them.) They offered to replace the pot---despite none of these issues being my fault---but only if I paid a 15-buck return shipping fee, plus shipping it to Cuisinart. Heck, I might as well buy another teapot!

I can assure you this time it won't be a Cuisinart!

A followup: I stand by my negative review of this item, but here's a very positive one for BED BATH AND BEYOND. Before throwing the kettle away---or shipping it back to Cuisinart to pay their ransom, which they jokingly call a warranty---I stopped by BB&B just for the heck of it. They were more than happy to replace it with a brandy-new one and ship the old one back to Cuisinart. What a terrific store! I was in and out of there in less than 10 minutes! I'll buy from them again and again!

reviews.reviewTitle: Overall great, but the lid began to "stick" after one year of use and will not open
reviews.reviewText: This is a great kettle, love the different temperature options. Really no going back from this luxury if you're a tea drinker! Unfortunately, after less than a year of ownership, the lid "sticks." Nothing happens when pushing the "open" button, and prying it free seems impossible or likely to break things all together. I was busy at the time and didn't take advantage of the warranty, so I suppose we're stuck with it now. A bit disappointing in an $80.00 product. Everything else has worked great though, so I give 4 stars as perhaps if exchanged, I would not have this problem again. A workaround is to pour water in through the spout and heat that way, but it's just a short-term solution as there's no way to clean inside the kettle. When we do replace, I think we'll likely switch to KitchenAid.

reviews.reviewTitle: This will burn your hands at worst and is poorly designed at best.
reviews.reviewText:
I cannot recommend this for four reasons: it will burn you if you brush up against the side, it will burn your knuckles when you try to pour when it's more than half full, the LEDs don't backlight the temperature selections on the buttons, and the lid release button doesn't open the lid wide enough to fill.

1. It will burn your hands. It's a nice shiny metal appliance, but very hot water is on the other side, and metal conducts heat very well. Don't brush up against the sides or you will get burned.

2. The design is not practical and I seriously doubt was ever tested by a human being who actually used it for its intended purpose. If you fill up the kettle, the awful design of the handle means that you either burn your knuckles (see #1 above) trying to hold the handle to balance the kettle, or you hold the handle too far down to be comfortable, and possibly needing two hands.

3. It's full of LEDs, but they're not useful. If you sometimes make hot water early in the morning and don't turn on the lights so as not to wake anyone, you would hope all of the LEDs lighting this thing up would be helpful. Unfortunately the numbers and text printed on each button are not backlit, which means you're blinded by lights around each button and can't see which button is for which temperature.

4. It's awkward to fill. The lid is made of metal and has a button to release it. But when you push the button, it only releases about 45 degrees. When it's cold it's not a problem to open the rest up with your fingers, but sometimes I add more water when I need more even if there is a little hot steamy water inside. Then I can't touch the lid or I'll burn my fingers but I can't fill with such a small opening.

I wanted to love it, because sometimes I'm lazy & I want to be able to have multiple cups of tea or warm up my cup without getting up (in which case I could have it on the end table.) I'm also impatient, & the thought of being able to hold the water hot so I could go back for a second cup without having to wait for water to heat was also appealing.
