But, like so many of the people writing negative reviews here, I found that the cost of my laziness/impatience was-- what is it now? $75? This kettle worked like a dream... a few times. Then the water was not quite so hot as before. I started using the "boil" button as the only one that got even warm water... Turning it back on several times, trying to bypass whatever was telling it to beep & indicate that it was done heating when it hadn't even begun. Realizing that frustration had become an inherent part of my tea ritual, I gave up & threw it away.

In the last 2 years I had three of these units, love the look and functions of it, favorite kettle I had in terms of that. Each one though, after about a half a year starts to leak at the bottom of the handle, even the ones they sent me s a replacement.

For warranty Cuisinart wants you to pay for their shipping of the replacement product to you, and as well shipping of the defective one to them. Replacing it became a hassle.

reviews.reviewTitle: Thrilled with kettle, hope the replcement goes as planned. - It did!
reviews.reviewText:
UPDATE:
I am VERY pleased with Cuisinart's Customer Service. I spent $20 at UPS and sent the kettle back to them on a Wednesday. They received it the following Tuesday and Friday afternoon of the same week I had my replacement. It is brand new and even included the documentation. It works perfectly and I couldn't be happier. All in all, this kettle is a winner. Read below for my original review.
ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I have very much enjoyed this variable temp water kettle for almost 3 years. I received it as a gift in Feb 2014. I read the reviews stating the lettering on the buttons had work off for some people, and have been careful about how I pick up the kettle making sure I don't rest my hand on the buttons. So for me, the temperature buttons on the handle have never work off in the slightest. The handle is actually designed for your hand to be placed below the buttons when picking it up so that's never bothered me at all. I drink white, green and black tea mostly, and the temp difference (especially for the green and white teas) makes a HUGE difference in the tea flavor. About 5-6 weeks ago, I noticed the kettle when set to heat to 200 degrees would bring the water to a full boil. I tested the other temps using a digital thermometer, and only the lower 2 temps ( 160 and 175) were accurate. The other 4 higher temps heated the water to 15 - 20 degrees higher than the called for temperature. I was going to live with that but then the kettle starting boiling the water and never shutting off. I figured that was a hazard: would it boil itself dry and catch fire? I didn't want to find out, so I called Cuisinart support (manufacturer warranty is 3 years). They were extremely helpful and quick and are replacing the kettle with a new one. My cost is the $20 to ship them the defective kettle. So far, so good.
Assuming the replacement process goes as planned and the replacement kettle lasts as long as this one did, I can say I've been thrilled with the product. I'll update this review when I receive the new kettle.

I am looking for a kettle that can boil water to 200* for french press coffee. I thought this kettle was the answer, unfortunately, it is not. The presets do not reach the posted temperatures. I tried several times with different amounts of water in case that would make a difference. I tested with two different thermometers and the 200* setting never gave me 200* only 190*, additionally, the boiling setting never gave a 212* reading, the highest was 205*.
Yes, I could have kept the kettle and let the 205* boiling setting cool a bit before pouring, but then why buy a kettle for this price when I can do the same with a cheaper model?

reviews.reviewTitle: First one was a bust, second one is great! (Updated)
reviews.reviewText:
I bought the first one at Sur la Table, but they only had one, and it was an open box unit. Took home and alas, wouldn't get over 80 degrees. Still had stickers on it and everything, so I wasn't sure if someone else had returned it for the same issue. I returned the unit the same day to a very apologetic Sur La Table employee. It all worked out okay because I received a 20% off coupon from Bed, Bath, Beyond and discovered that it would be valid for this item (and is $99.99 retail at their store), so I figured it would be in my best interest to secure it for much less than offered on Amazon, even with my free Prime shipping. (Also of note: their coupon works for Breville brand items as well - including juicers!) Not trying to send people to other retailers, but just saying... usually Amazon blows away even sale and coupon prices, but not in this instance.

The unit is so easy to use. I brew a lot of tea and I have quite a variety. I also brew a lot of French press coffee. This unit takes the guesswork out of heating the water to specific temperatures. I was actually using a water thermometer clipped to the side of my pot to heat water to the correct temp. Only problem is that I have to watch it. And if I want a refill I have to repeat the process. This carafe eliminates the hassle and is just a major convenience.

The settings seem to be accurate. I have measure the temperature with my water thermometer and it's within a degree or two when it's done warming. The unit lights up when it is heating, so it's nice to know when it's on. The carafe is stainless steel, which is a huge plus. Many other units have plastic parts. There is a plastic piece holding a mesh strainer, but you can remove it. The plastic is BPA free though. But the strainer confuses me since I only brew water in the carafe and the mesh is not so fine as to trap small particulates. Perhaps if one put in a charcoal filter in that insert (I think Cuisinart sells them), then the filter would work properly, but would likely cool the water down as it filtered through. I prefer to pour filtered water from the faucet or from the Brita pitcher instead.

So far the unit has been working great (the second one that is). I will update if anything changes. I know that Cuisinart has inconsistency with their products. I have a small food processor that has been great for years, but bought a larger one that stopped working within two weeks. So I'll keep everyone posted. But so far so good.

Update (8/17/2012):

Still works great. Temperatures are all VERY accurate, within 1 degree using my manual water thermometer to test. One small issue is that cleaning it is a pain. There are instructions for removal of water stains. But when the unit is hot, I hold it over the sink and try and get all the excess water out, then let it sit out with the lid off on top of my stove (so the moisture goes into the hood vent and does NOT create Oregon mold). But you can't really wipe it out when the inside is 160 - 200 degrees. =) My only minor quibble, but it is very minor. Note: when holding upside down, it seems there is a lip that catches some water, so be sure and tilt it quite a bit to get the excess out. Then you can wipe anything excess once it's cooled off a bit.

Oh, baking soda works for water stains and freshening. Just either put some on a paper towel with a bit of water and wipe, or soak it briefly in a diluted water/baking soda solution. Then rinse clean. It's what I do occasionally to my plastic food containers or my Nathan or Amphipod water bottles.

reviews.reviewTitle: It works but don't expect it to last forever
reviews.reviewText:
I've had the CPK-17 for a little over four years. Two years in, all the markings on the buttons rubbed off, and even lab-grade permanent marker won't stay on - so it's hard to to remember what temperatures are available. The bottom right is boil, and that's all I really know I guess. About three years in, the filter just fell out. Today, the lid completely fell to pieces and the kettle is no longer usable.

I can confirm the inner workings of the lid are almost entirely plastic, which probably isn't great for longevity.

I need to replace this now, and I think I'm going to go with the Bonavita, which I use in my office for pour-over coffee and has been much better. The bonavita is made entirely of metal and you can choose an exact temp on the base. The spout also gives way more control.

reviews.reviewTitle: very fast, great item I would recommend to anyone in the market for an electric kettle
reviews.reviewText: this thing is excellent. we've had it for a while in storage. wasn't used. now at work I like to use it to not have to deal with the kitchen staff, lol. it is great. the temp settings are great and it is FAST. I don't know why people are complaining about noise, it is boiling water after all, lol. once it gets close to temp there is a sound like, uh, boiling water. it is great and worth the money. it is steel so it's like a regular tea kettle.

reviews.reviewTitle: Clear nail polish on the buttons to prevent fading
reviews.reviewText:
Some reviewers have mentioned the writing fading/ erasing from the buttons. As a prevention, I put clear nail polish over the writing. With use multiple times a day, I have no problems with the writing going away.
9-14-2016 UPDATE
After about a year and a half of daily use the numbers have not worn off and I still love using it! I sometimes use it to heat water for boiling to use in a pot (ie for cooking noodles) as it heats up faster than my stove- and we have a pretty decent stove.

Got this from a friend who wasn't using it when we said we needed a new kettle.

Pros:
1. The lower temperature settings are actually quite nice for things that don't need boiling water.
2. The empty kettle overheating override - an absolute necessity with the "keep warm feature" which you might forget to switch off.

Cons:
1. The opening is a lot smaller than most electric kettle so it's a little harder to fill with water.
2. Like most modern electric kettles, it has difficulty detecting when the water is boiling. Does it rely on temperature? If so, how stupid. A little error in the calibration or operating at higher elevations, means it'll never shut off.
3. The "keep warm" feature is a big energy waster and takes a while to get used to remembering to turn off.
4. It's actually quite hard to see how much water is in it, there just isn't enough contrast. The handle in front of the scale contributes to this problem.
5. Like all metal and glass kettles, it is loud. But then no one wants a quiet plastic kettle... sigh. Ignorance is bliss sometimes.

We'll keep this till it breaks.
We had 2 of these Cuisinarts with 3 breakdowns...just after the warranty expired. For the price we paid, this product is a DO NOT BUY EVER AGAIN.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stopped working after 3 months of use and costumer service is AWFUL
reviews.reviewText: This is by far the worst costumer service team I've dealt with. My kettle simply stopped working after around 3 months of use. I reached out to costumer service and they barely answered my question, then forgot to follow up and I've been constantly reaching out reminding them to answer me. It's been a constant back and forth of a single person answering then not following up for weeks and me reaching out again and getting an answer from someone else and having to explain everything over and over. The kettle was great while it worked but this is absolutely not worth it. Go buy one from somewhere else. I'm never buying from Cuisinart again.

reviews.reviewTitle: 7 Reasons My Cuisinart PerfecTemp Isn't Perfect for Me
reviews.reviewText:
1. It's bad for my eyes. The numbers and letters rubbed off the handle after a few months. I don't think I ever cleaned the handle--it just rubbed off from being grasped.

2. It's bad for conversation. This thing is loud. Not boiling-kettle-on-the-stove loud or doing-dishes-in-the-sink loud or even window-air-conditioner loud. Almost-vacuum-cleaner loud. All conversation stops before tea.

3. It's hungry for attention. If I empty the pot, it beeps furiously until I put more water in. I've learned to unplug it after pouring.

4. It has anger issues. It is capable of boiling exactly 1.7 liters, and not a drop more. If I add so much as an extra drop, it hisses and spits with rage. It hasn't seriously burned me, but whenever an unsuspecting guest fills it, it ends up spitting a couple of feet.

5. It's needy. Since the gauge in the handle has a sort of built-in time delay, filling it to almost-but-no-more-than-1.7 liters is next to impossible. I have to rest it on a level counter and wait for the gauge to stabilize to read how much is in there. And it can only be read in a brightly lit kitchen. (See #1.)

6. It's incontinent. After almost two years the seal around the handle seems to have aged on the inside of the pot. When I kept finding water running down the cabinets near it, I assumed I must have overfilled it, but now the handle leaks slowly and constantly, even when unplugged and cool.

7. It's bad for my marriage. My wife bought me this pot, and for a long time, I pretended to like it. This sort of deception is bad for a relationship.

Ok, I want to say some nice things about it:

1. It never actually caught fire.

2. For two years it boiled water.

I know two comparable pots at the office, and neither of them irritates me in any of these seven ways. The CPK-17 and I are just not right for each other.

reviews.reviewTitle: You will see rust occur inside on the bottom plate. Cuisinart will dismiss it.
reviews.reviewText: See the ring of rust in the photo. Cuisinart dismisses the fact that their kettle rusts. Customer services told me to get some Bartender's friend or Bon Ami. and scrub it. Nice drinking that. And it's very difficult to get a sponge brush in down to the base. But seriously this kettle should not rust the price it sells for. Yes I understand hard water but this is greatly disappointing. And when you contact customer service they act like all kettles rust. Again hard water but not rust near the screws that you can see when you look inside at the bottom of the base.

reviews.reviewTitle: When someone called this An Expensive Mistake, that person was right.
reviews.reviewText: First, the buttons are too small and too close together. You press the Keep Warm button when you don't intend to. The biggest problem is the lid. The spring dies over time and it does not want to open when you press the Open button. So you pour the water into the kettle via the spout, and no matter how careful and patient you are, you spill water on your countertop. Then, to add insult to injury, when you pour the heated water into your cup, some of the water sprays onto your countertop. Tries really hard to ruin your cup of tea, this device does. Don't do it....

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent kettle. One star removed for minor issues.
reviews.reviewText:
I am a tea drinker and this has great features. If you don't know why you would need all these settings, they you don't need this kettle. (A darjeeling from full boil can be bitter and overly astringent, but at 200 or even below it's not). So it fits a need for me nicely. I've been using it for a couple months.
Pro:
-The spec sheet is accurate and it's great for all the reasons other people have listed.
-I used my iDevices iGrill Grilling/Cooking Barbecue Thermometer with Dual Probe, White to verify the temp settings. All were consistently within +- 2 degrees F (beeped and turned off 2 degrees before listed temp, and then settled down 1-2 degrees higher on the "keep warm" mode).
Con:
-Execution/assembly issues- the screw on the lid fell off in the pot and needed to be fished out and reattached. For the price, I would have expected a slightly more robust "feel" to it; I get my general impression is that this will need to be replaced in a couple years under heavy use (which it gets at 3-4 times a day).
-The pour spout design isn't flawless. With or without the "scale filter" in place, water can splash when you get to the end of water in the pot. So fill higher than you need.
-Takes a little longer to get water to a full boil than my "one setting" Aroma AWK-115S Hot H20 X-Press 1-1/2-Liter Cordless Water Kettle. So I actually use both now- the Aroma for preheating boiling water for cooking (faster and cheaper than going cold to boil on the stove) or to pre-heat my teapot, and the Cuisinart for the tea itself.
-I prefer the "keep warm" feature off, but after sitting for a while I think it turns itself back on. Minor issue but irritating.
-----------------
Update 12/21/13
I've since bought another electric kettle for work but didn't want to spend the $$ for this one. I got the Oster variable for $40 at Target. It allows for temp at 10 degrees (so doesn't dial in the preferred tea levels quite as well), and it doesn't have the keep warm feature- but at half the price it makes me almost want to take another star off the Cuisinart for being so expensive.
-----------------
Update 03/24/15
The Oster variable died. This one is still going strong.
Overall a good water kettle, but for the price it is disappointing that the numbers wore off and the water meter on the side doesn’t accurately show the amount of water in the kettle.

I have tried several models of these temperature control cuisinarts and they are just fabulous. Being able to control your temp for tea lovers is a must. It's also nice to heat up baby bottles. Overall, it heats fast and has great capacity and is "mostly" stainless steel. But in my search for a no plastic kettle, it has come up short. I have reduced plastic in my home to the point that I can smell plastic from a mile away. Unfortunately, there is plastic in this kettle, although not much, and it's supposedly BPA, but it's still plastic. Cuisinart, please make my favorite kettle without plastic and i will be forever your customer.

I did not like it in the beginning because when it finished boiling and you took it off the base and then placed it back, the lights would stay on for a long time. It seemed that it would not shut off automatically, so I had to press the "START" button to stop it. Finally, I got used to it, but suddenly it stopped boiling. The lights are on, but nothing happens...So it's going back... Very poor quality to have worked for less than a month!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great features but plastic inside and it breaks
reviews.reviewText:
We loved this kettle for its features. Convenient, beautiful cool looking, light in weight, not loud, cool blue lights, very easy to use, buttons easy to press, way more convenient buttons on handle than on Breville variable temperature model, which are on base of unit. However, the inside has plastic parts that come into contact with water, which raises health concerns with plastic parts and silicone seals leaching chemicals into the boiling water. To reduce plastic parts, we removed the removable filter, but still the water front window, heating element and a few others remain inside and make contact with the boiling water. 5 starts for ease of use, convenience, aesthetics and functionality. 1 star reduced for plastic parts in contact with water.

And while we decided to accept the great kettle even with its plastic parts (as scary as it seems), we couldn't ignore the off-putting smell that would come out of the kettle and water. It smelled metallicky - like chlorine and metal together. It was mild, but distinct. It did not go away after 2 months of use. Mild but worrisome smell, another 1/2 star removed.

The kicker: for a $100 kettle (which it was when we bought it in November)it broke in 6 weeks. It actually stopped working on Christmas day, and since all stores were closed, we had to boil water in a soup pot for tea and coffee - NOT COOL ON CHRISTMAS. It took about 1.5 weeks to get it replaced and a new one shipped out. I'm hoping it was a fluke, but seeing that the price dropped significantly (20%) from when we bought it, and the other reviews indicate high percentage of defective units, I'm guessing its a production flaw and not a random event that it broke. We liked it enough and it looks so cool and is so convenient that we're giving it another try, with the new unit, which seems even better than the first, but no way to tell whether it will continue to work and for how long.

Ultimately, 3 stars, as I still have hope for the replacement unit. Smell still there.

reviews.reviewTitle: Defective design-Parts detach affecting water quality & safety
reviews.reviewText: Caution! Appears to be a defective design - suggest you check the crevices inside the kettle every time you refill. Worked fine for 6mo, but 2 Internal screws and a rod became detached during normal operations (see photo), and went unnoticed until water tasted metallic and poisonous. I’d recommend looking for another design

The black filter on the inside rusted and fell off after 9 months of use.

They have the worst customer services ever. Everyone facebook post's are all complaints too. I bought the PerfectTemp Kettle, in less than a year it broke. I have to pay to ship, or physically visit the location and waste my time and gas money.

That is not honouring a warranty. Many other companies have way better warranty services. Don't by the Perfect temp kettle, if you don't want to have to replace or repair it.

If you don't mind risking it breaking down on you (I don't recommend it) than don't get it.

Edit: After contacting them twice, and then posting a negative review on their facebook page, they finally resolved my issue and replaced it. If there is no further posts from me, it means this new one is still working. It seems as that I got one from a defective batch. My sister has the same model, but hers has had no issues.

reviews.reviewTitle: too bad stopped working after 8 months
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this in September and loved it until April when it stopped working. Since it was still under the 3 year warranty I called Cuisinart to return it. They told me no problem they will ship a new one but I would have to pay the shipping on the new one and the shipping on the return.Not a ton of money but really!!! Eight months old and they won't pay the shipping? For such a big company the only thing that tells me is they don't think their products last and they would loose too much money in returns? After much discussion the rep agreed to pay for the new item to be shipped but not the return (unless I live in California apparently there is a law the must adhere to). Let's hope the new one lasts longer. I don't think I will be buying anymore Cuisinart products.
They sent me a new one in April...October broke again!!!!!!!!you would think with a brand like Cuisinart the quality would be there:(

reviews.reviewTitle: Lousy Customer Service for A Kettle that Breaks
reviews.reviewText: Customer Service at Cuisinart is deplorable. This was a wedding present, which I loved when I got it. After one year the lid broke/rusted off and when I pushed the "open" button the silver lid, a screw, and a some black plastic came off. After this it was almost impossible to heat water with the lid closed. It was still under warranty so I emailed them about this. They take 3-5 days to respond to the email, and each time they do they are adding on questions as if they want to find a reason to stop my exchange. Then they said I can't exchange the product because it's used at a business. I never said that-I only use this at home! Then when I called customer service they said that it was impossible for the kettle to break in the way it did, that it must have been ripped off by force. I assume that all customer support people at Cuisinart must be a) mechanical engineers or b) coached to say that because I am not the Hulk and there is no way I could have ripped it off. Then they told me it would cost me $10 plus shipping to exchange it! I told them forget it, I will go with the Sunbeam Hot Shot, which I used for years and is 1/5 the price, or a regular kettle. Anything is better than their horrible customer service.

This kettle is probably a great idea if you have a specific need to heat water to temperatures other than boiling. If you want a kettle to boil water, don't get it.

What's good: It's durable. We have had ours for three years and it still works. (We use it a couple of times per week.)

What's not good:
The main gripe is that the kettle defaults to "keep warm" mode. This means that after the water has boiled, the kettle will boil it again, and again. Even after you pour, the kettle will reboil. You can disengage reboil mode, but sometimes you'll forget. And when you have guests, they won't know to disengage reboiling.
It is sad to see the print on the buttons wear off quickly. After a while, you have to remind yourself which button does what.

I received this kettle as a Christmas gift, and I have used it nearly every day since. I have no real complaints at all. It is quick, accurate (I measured with a Thermopen), and easy to pour. It maintains the temperature well. What more can you want, really? While I have used it primarily for making tea or coffee, this kettle is handy whenever you need a couple quarts or less of hot or boiling water for any reason.

When I say "quick," I mean "QUICK!" I have not timed it, but it is far quicker than my stovetop kettle.

Unlike some other reviewers, I have had no problems at all with the bottom. I've found it sturdy and fairly easy to use. It has not come up when I lift the kettle, and it grips my countertop well.

If I could improve this product, I would add insulation. It is uninsulated stainless steel. That is great for weight and bulk, but you must rely on the heating element to maintain heat, rather than insulation. Also, since it is uninsulated, the outside surface (not the handle) does get HOT--far too hot to handle. However, it is a kettle, so you can expect it to get hot. The handle is large enough to handle easily, so just don't touch the sides.

I really like this kettle, so much that when my first one died after a couple of years of daily use, I figured it was just us, or a bum one, and bought another. So sorry I did. It worked awhile and then same thing: stopped doing everything except boiling water, then a few months later, died completely. I will never buy a Cuisinart electric kettle again. I expected more from this company, especially for a hundred dollar kettle. Nice features, doesn't last.

It's okay but I bought it in July 2016 and January 31, 2017 it stopped working. I used it approximately 2 days each week for one brew then turned it off and unplugged it. Getting a new teapot costs $30 approximately to send and get replacement. Not worth that after paying $79.00 for it. I do not recommend it. If you can something cheaper of a plain old tea pot, I would just do that. Note : because my teapot was not working I banged the bottom on the counter I banged the teapot on the counter, then I banged both again. I felt I had nothing to lose. It's still did not work however. But, When I plugged it in this morning it heated.

reviews.reviewTitle: Looks great, but did not work for me
reviews.reviewText:
I returned this product and here is a summary of what happened just in case anyone else experiences the same issue:

It seemed to be working just fine when I first bought it. But after it boiled the water, I removed it from the base, and replaced it back, it was beeping for a short period of time and all lights were blinking. The beeping stopped, but the blinking did not even after 30 minutes. So, I asked a question here and it looked like no one else was seeing that. And the same thing happened every time I used it. So, I also asked Cuisinart and they said:

"The kettle should not flash after heating the water and replacing it on the base. The lights should be solid, unless the control has been hit or reset. Unit should light up on the setting you used to heat the water. After about 5-10 minutes, the unit turns off the warming feature."

They also asked for my shipping address (probably planning to replace the unit) and the e-mail was really nice, detailed, and helpful.

The next day, it stopped working completely. When I pressed Start, the Boil light was blinking, but the water never came to a boil. I did not want to deal with a replacement unit, so I simply returned it.

I know this does not happen to everyone, but in case you experience something similar, either return or replace it.

Worked great... for a week. Attractive design, balanced feel, easy to use. I drank a lot more tea this week because it has been so nice having hot water ready so quickly.
The issue started today (after using for one week)- after pouring my water for french press coffee (note: NOT boiling) and put back on the base, it went to a rolling boil. Within a matter of seconds of replacing on the base, it was rolling, bubbling and shaking on the base. I took it off for two minutes to reset the memory. When I put it back, it immediately went back to rolling. I then took it off the base and unplugged it for about 15 minutes. Again, when I put it back on the base WITHOUT PUSHING ANY BUTTONS, and no buttons lit up, it went back to a rolling boil. I called Cuisinart customer service to see if I was doing something wrong and was told to return it to the store (purchased locally). She said that was totally not normal.

I don't think we'll be getting another one of these. If I had walked out of the room for even a few minutes, the thing probably would've burned up. It showed no indication that it was going to shut off on its own. Will probably try the Zojirushi if I can talk my husband into spending the extra money on it.

reviews.reviewTitle: A Safe Way to Make Hot Water
reviews.reviewText: I have been using a stove-top tea kettle to heat water for tea. I have a gas stove. Unfortunately the steam whistle doesn't work anymore. After having a few panic-inducing moments having stepped out of the kitchen to complete a task and returning to the kitchen to see the tea kettle boiling on the gas stove (one time to completely empty) after having forgotten it was on I purchased this kettle. I reviewed some of the customer pictures about the ink wearing off the buttons and decided to use a small foam painting brush to apply waterproof/heat resistant silicone very precisely onto the buttons. I removed the filter to expose the screw that seems to rust easily so I can leave the top open and let the unit dry when the container is empty. This should resolve any problems people have had in the past with the unit. I am relieved to have something safe to heat water in my kitchen and have it heat the water to such a precise, drinkable temperature. This is a very attractive and useful kitchen appliance. I'm happy to have it. So far it works perfectly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wonderful for all my hot water needs!
reviews.reviewText:
Just wonderful! I use it mostly for teas of various types and french press coffee.

I did a lot of research on kettles, bought 4 different brands, and this is the best constructed, most flexible in temperature, accurate in temperature (yep, I checked!) and fastest heating. The price is also great considering the construction and features. The temp-hold feature also works best than any of the others.

I also love the look of this unit on the counter!

The kettle is not so easy to fill directly from our fridge filter, so I end up using a smaller measuring cup. Some reviewers mentioned it finishes the heat cycle with a loud BEEP but mine is extremely quiet and I never hear it unless I'm in the kitchen. Evidently there's a manufacturing issue or a change in design.

Keep it clean - don't let the residue (lime / calcification) build up! Just mix 6-12 C water with 1/8 to 1/4 C white vinegar and boil for 10 or 15 minutes, rinsing it out a few times to cleanse the vinegar flavor out.

reviews.reviewTitle: this is one of the best products available
reviews.reviewText:
For those of us who are tea lovers, this is one of the best products available. This kettle is easy to use, works flawlessly, and is a great addition to any kitchen.

This kettle has many features that put it above its competition. First of all, it is stainless steel, which always looks sleek and on top of that Cuisinart added blue LED lights as an indication that the kettle is on and working properly. It has the ability to hold close to 2 liters of water which is more than enough for a few cups of tea.

The heating element is hidden so it is perfect for dorm rooms. There is also the option to keep the water warm for up to 30 minutes. It is so convenient to just press the keep warm button, drink my tea, and then, if I want more, just pour another cup! The only complaint I have is that it is unable to go in the dishwasher. But this isn’t a big drawback because the only thing that goes in it is water, so all I have had to do is use a washcloth to wipe out the inside. And the filter is removable and washable so that is easy to take care of as well.

My favorite feature is the different temperature options. Until recently, I never knew that tea needed to be steeped at different temperatures. I like tea, but I will admit, I’m not an expert. After doing some research, I discovered that only black tea was supposed to be steeped with boiling water. Green tea always tasted bitter, but that was due to the leaves being burned by the boiling water.

After using the green tea preset button on this kettle and making it properly, I learned green tea is one of my favorites. The temperature of the water makes all the difference in the world. And it is so easy to just press the button and the kettle does its job and heats to the perfect temperature. It will beep when it is ready and then you are just minutes away from a comforting cup of tea.

Overall, this product is wonderful and I highly recommend it to everyone who loves to drink tea.

Works just like it says it does, and I have no complaints other than one, which is what keeps it from getting a fifth star. Pouring out the last few ounces of water is a pain. I use this mostly for a french press, and usually I just heat a large mug's worth of water at a time- which means I want ALL that water out when it's done. It starts off pouring smoothly, but when you get to the last quarter cup, you have to tilt it quite a bit to get it to pour the last bit out, and it comes out disjointed- not one steady stream of water. I popped the filter out to see if it helps with the stream, but without much luck. You just have to be patient and hold it almost upside down for a bit to get it all out.

But overall, it's great. A definite recommend because it's fast and efficient. Makes my soup-making so much easier, quicker and less wasteful of energy too.

UPDATE: I'm upgrading this review to 5 stars, because it's nearly 3 years later, and this thing still works like it did the day I bought it. One or twice I boiled white vinegar in it to clean it, and it's held up like a charm. That alone makes it worth the fifth star.

Junk. Don't waste your money. Purchased two years ago and in 10 month was discoloring (rust?) on the bottom. We bought it at another store with a good return policy so we were able to exchange it for a new one. The replacement also started discoloring almost immediately. We continued using it, now it's malfunctioning and no longer beeping/shutting off properly. Never again.

We ordered this product twice. The first time, within 6 months, the control buttons ceased working. We ordered another, and again, within the year, the top stopped opening. Nothing would open it. Please do not buy this tea kettle, as the craftsmanship, and customer service leave alot to be desired.

I did some research on kettles and requested this as a Christmas gift. 3 months later, it is not functional. The pouring spout has detatched from the main container, spilling water through the hole every time you try to pour out of the spout. There is a 3 year warranty, but you have to pay $15 each way (and not have your kettle for a period of time) and that just seems like sending good money after bad. Boo Cuisinart! After their food processor blade recall (I'm still waiting 5 months later for my replacement blade), I won't be ordering from them again.

Just bought this the other day at a brick and mortar store using their nifty 20% off coupon and snagged it for 80. So far I've only heated water to 200, but I checked the temp and it was a perfect 200! After heating to 200 I then needed water at 175.. (yes I now realize I should swap my tasks) and it was taking longer than I needed for the water to cool down so I just poured it into the cup and waited a whopping 20 seconds and voila! I had 175 (ish) water. Next time I'll heat to 175, use then heat to 200 and see how fast that goes. I am happy with how quickly it gets to 200. I fill the kettle, get it started and then prepare my coffee fixings. The kettle is usually ready before I am, but thanks to the nifty 'keep warm' feature, I don't have to rush. I've recently redecorated my kitchen, which offers me more counter space. It's such a nice looking kettle I'm happy to keep it right on the counter. I bought it specifically for the variable temp as I need both, 200 and 175. Because of the different temps I may even dabble in loose leaf tea. Seems perfectly sturdy to me, however I've only had it for two days and haven't beat it against a brick wall either.

Absolutely love the quick heating of this kettle. It holds enough water that I was not constantly filling it. All the different temperatures have come in handy and originally when I bought it I didn’t think I would need them. It is an exterior hot kettle so little hands reaching up on counter can get burned. If used safely and properly it is a perfect kettle.

The kettle is great when it is new. You can't believe water can boil so fast. But within a few months the electronics started to malfunction. It would shut off as soon as it was removed from the base. Sometimes it wouldn't turn on. It took longer and longer to heat water. Occasionally it wouldn't automatically shut off when it came up to temp. We've had half a kettle of water boil away waiting for it to beep. The last straw is now having to pry open the lid as the open button no longer functions.
We used the kettle 3-5 times a day for about 6 months and it just could not stand up to doing the job it was designed for.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wanted to like this more but design flaw
reviews.reviewText: I wanted to like this kettle more but there's a design flaw: The 'keep warm' function is right next to the 'on' button and people press it all of the time by accident. You are sitting down enjoying your hot drink and you can hear the kettle starting up again. This happens time and time again. The kettle is good but this is annoying.

I got this for Christmas and I have to say I absolutely love it. I am an avid tea drinker and as all tea drinkers know, you need to brew different teas at different temperatures. This wonderful item has saved me countless minutes/hours hovering over the stove with my thermometer waiting for the perfect temp to brew my tea! With this ingenious item, you just press the type of tea you intend to brew and it heats it to exactly what you need. I have even tested it with my thermometer and the temps are spot on! I have only owned and used it for a couple of months, but I have to say that it would be hard to live without at this point.

I'll add my voice to the chorus of customers who had it fail within weeks of purchase. I have zero interest in pursuing warranty repair because I refuse to spend more of my time and money to end up with the same junk in my kitchen.

I thought, incorrectly, that Cuisinart was a quality brand. Not so. I feel like I have been robbed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Made in China piece of over-priced junk
reviews.reviewText:
My sister sent me one of these & I loved it. Shortly afterwards the print on the buttons wore off and, unless one doesn't memorize which button is which temperature, you have no clue how hot the water will be.

After less than 1 year it would light up as if it was going to heat up but, after a few minutes, would beep then shut off & the water is stone cold. My sister urged me to buy one from a local retailer, wait a few months then return it to the store but the new one didn't even make it two months!

Looked and looked and cannot find either an electric percolator or electric kettle made by conscientious U.S. workers. This seems to be the norm these days. Made in China? You can be certain it is a product of planned obsolescence.

This purchase was a real treat to myself and I've generally been very happy with it. It's not only attractive, but it comes off from the base, which is convenient (no dragging a cord around to fill it). I do wish there was a way to get to choose how long you want the "keep warm" /auto shut-off option to last because a half hour doesn't quite do it for me. I'm working at my desk for hours and want a constant supply of my tea! I do use the different temperatures for the different types of tea that I drink and have noticed a difference in flavor. But have I considered the Breville? Yes, but the price is far more than this electric kettle and I don't think it would be that much better.

reviews.reviewTitle: The lid lasted for only one year
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this kettle in a store but I'd like to share my experience with others on Amazon since I'm currently searching for another kettle on the website.

It worked well for exactly a year and the lid wouldn't open all of a sudden. I was trying to open it with a butter spreader carefully but the entire lid just fell off. It's still doing it's job but without a lid, which is ridiculous. This one has 3-year limited warranty but since I couldn't find the invoice, there is not anything I can do.

I have to buy another electronic kettle but I'll pick a different brand. You would think a pricy kettle like this would last a little longer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Need an electric kettle? Buy this, and you'll be satisfied for years.
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased one of these (elsewhere) after going through three (3) other electric kettles from a local chain. The first of those died after six months - just stopped working. The lid on the second broke two weeks after purchase (wouldn't close). The last one stopped turning off after a month and a half.

At that point I decided it was time to get something better - which was this product.

In the nine of so months that I've had this I've had zero problems. I normally drink black tea. It takes about eight and a half minutes to boil. I also have a french press for coffee, this has a temperature setting for that which works wonderfully.

Bottom line: I use this multiple times a day, every day, and have yet to have any issues with it. Well worth the extra money.

reviews.reviewTitle: we loved it since we drink a lot of tee af ...
reviews.reviewText: We had 2 of these over the years. Both of them had the same problem. After about 2 years of use the lid will stop opening up. Our second one just broke. We were able to live with sticking lid for some time but today the lid just fell apart and dissent open anymore. I will be getting something different this time. When this kettle worked , we loved it since we drink a lot of tee af different kinds . Different temperature setting are very convenient when the unit working.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works for the first year or two then....
reviews.reviewText: My brother bought this for me in January of 2017. I went to the hospital soon after and did not use it for about eight months. It gave up the ghost yesterday. So I had about sixteen months of one a day use out of it before it failed. Use this info as you see fit.

reviews.reviewTitle: Warranty does not cover pot-heads up!
reviews.reviewText: Mine just pooped out after 2+ years. Under warranty so called customer service who happily sent me a new base after verifying warranty. Received the new base today and plugged in to find that it was not the problem. Called again to report and learned that the pot itself is not under warranty. She said to throw it in the garbage and get out my teapot for the stove. Hmmm.... If 2-3 years is a satisfactory life for an electic appliance used once a day then this is an acceptable purchase and warranty. I think it should have lasted twice as long for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Like fundamentally holding liquid is now beyond the scope of ...
reviews.reviewText: Boiling water streaming out the bottom seal of this unit is okay with Cuisinart customer service because its out of warranty at 4 years old. Like fundamentally holding liquid is now beyond the scope of this device. So really, you're not buying a kettle, you're renting it. Garbage customer service. Will never buy Cuisinart again.

reviews.reviewTitle: an unnecessary and annoying feature for me
reviews.reviewText: It boils water well enough but it emits beeps when it's done, an unnecessary and annoying feature for me. It stays lit up for a while after it's done - why? And if you pick it up before it's done and replace it on its base, it will start up again until you press the start button again. Some people might like this feature but I don't. (If I pick it up off its base that means I've decided it's "done enough"!) We've also had some trouble in that scenario if the pot is empty - seems to not want to turn off unless I put more water in it and then press the start button again to turn it off. UPDATE: this latter feature is really terrible. I actually am going to replace it because I'm afraid that it wouldn't prevent overheating/fire, which is the main reason for getting an electric kettle with an auto shut off.

This item was purchased as a gift for my mother. Less than a month after my mom received it, the kettle stopped working altogether. We contacted the manufacturer who were going to send us a new kettle, but were going to make us pay $15 for shipping for the new kettle, and also we would have to pay shipping to send the old kettle back to them. We found this completely unacceptable for a kettle which my mother used for less than a month. We paid a lot of money for a nice gift, and when the product failed the manufacturer refused to take responsibility.

Thank god for Amazon. I called them and told them about the manufacturer's less than helpful return policy. Amazon said no problem, they would replace the item for us at absolutely no cost to us. Amazon also gave us free one-day shipping on the replacement item- unlike the manufacturer, who told us the replacement kettle we would have to pay over the odds shipping in order to receive wouldn't arrive for 7 to 10 business days. Amazon really went above and beyond to help us, especially when the problem wasn't their fault at all and didn't have to be their responsibility.

I hope the replacement kettle works out. It seemed like a really nice kettle for the brief period of time it was used. We have very little faith in the manufacturer after all this. I'm only leaving this review because I wanted to let everyone know about Amazon's excellent customer service.

First off, I loved this kettle. I received it as a Christmas gift after I began to life in the dorm and it worked flawlessly. Then, after two years, I pressed the "boil" button and the kettle began to blink blue and beep. It had never done this before so I looked it up and other reviews said something with the heat controls had broken within the wires of the kettle. Needless to say it could not be repaired, so I had to throw it out. It was amazing while I had it, but that's also $70 down the toilet.

reviews.reviewTitle: It wouldn't shut off after 6 months of use
reviews.reviewText:
Hi.
I almost never write reviews but I believe this one deserve it.
I purchased this kettle from Amazon 6 months ago for $99. I really like the thermometer and could live with the stainless steel look. It worked like a champ until about 2 wks ago when I begin noticing how unusually long it is boiling. I use my kettles a lot for tea, hot water...pretty much 5-10 times a day. One time the water was boiling for close to 3 mins with scalding water splattering out of the spout. My husband suggested I wait no longer for it to shut off automatically and do it manually before it blows up.

That's when I contacted Cuisinart Customer Service only to learn that the only thing I can get from them is an exchange with me paying shipping both ways....NO thanks, I am not interested in spending any more of my money on something that may fail again.

So I called Amazon and begged them to take this kettle back and give me a refund. Amazon came thru and I got $79 back today.

I did lose $20 and my faith in Cuisinart products but at least Amazon didn't fail me. Thanks Amazon.

PS: When I took the base of the kettle off to ship it back to Amazon I noticed that it has been leaking under the base.

I made this purchase on 8/21/2013 and now its 1/21/2014. This kettle is still working good. My roommate uses it everyday. The inside of his mug turned dark brown because he drinks too much tea (eww). Anyway, it's still working perfectly and still look good as new. I tried to save some money and bought a $60 one. It stopped working after 1 month, so I got this one. Seriously, just spend those extra bucks on this kettle and you will not regret.

Ok now it is September 20 and my kettle is still working perfectly! My roommates have been abusing them everyday to boil water. They really do love tea. And my kettle is still working well!

reviews.reviewTitle: but also love to cook and thus have many occasions where the ...
reviews.reviewText: I am an avid tea drinker, but also love to cook and thus have many occasions where the need for hot water (in varying degrees) rather quickly is helpful. The Cuisinart CPK-17 has not disappointed. I especially find the 'keep warm' feature and automatic shut-off handy. Periodic cleaning of the interior base is necessary. I have small hands, so I can fit one inside and do a quick wipe, but otherwise, the average person might have to approach this differently. I don't think that should be a deterrent to purchasing this pot, however.

reviews.reviewTitle: Started to leak after 4 months and terrible customer support
reviews.reviewText:
ok product while it worked. Worst customer support ever.

This product worked wonders for about 4 months and it started to leak and the base.
The Cuisinart customer support is terrible. They will charge $30 for shipping even though the product is defective.

I just purchased this kettle after using a plastic Sunbeam electric kettle. For anyone who wants to really compare a quality versus a cheap one I recommend this highly. This is a fantastically engineered appliance. The stainless steel really improves the water quality over plastic. The hinges seem to be high quality (I've heard other kettles are made cheaply) and there is a three year warranty versus cheaper models. The controls are very easy to use and I really enjoy being able to instantly select the temperature of the water. The light to indicate the water level is also excellent. I can't fault one thing about this kettle. Once again, Cuisinart lives up to their name.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good idea, but poor quality and terrible customer service
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this kettle at the end of November 2016 and it was great while it worked. It lasted about 5 months and then it started leaking. Cuisinart gives a 3-year warranty for this kettle, BUT there is a catch. You have to pay to ship the broken kettle back to them and then pay another $15 for them to ship it back to you. I tried calling customer support and reasoning with them that to pay 35% (shipping cost + $15) of the item price for a warranty repair on an item that is not even 6 months old is just unreasonable. However, they stood their ground and would not budge.
I will never purchase another Cuisinart item again, unless it's something that is cheap enough to just throw away when it breaks. With this type of warranty service, Cuisinart is only good for disposable items.

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent kettle; the pour is atrocious
reviews.reviewText: I've had my kettle for a few months now. The temperature settings are convenient, but the pour on this thing is the worst I've ever seen. Because of the shape of the mouth of the kettle, and the shape of the filter inside near the mouth, when you pour the water it always comes out in 1 or 2 main streams, with 1 or 2 *additional* streams coming out at odd angles near the top of the mouth. It's bonkers how bad the pour is.

I was disappointed with this item and had to return it the very same day. I bought this kettle because I liked the idea of being able to boil water at different temperatures for different teas such as black, green, white etc. A problem that I found almost immediately was the Open button. On the kettle I bought this button worked fine while the kettle was still cold, it would open the top lid to allow the kettle to be filled with water, however the problem arose after the water was heated. At this point if you tried pressing the Open button to add more water for instance, the button would not so easily open the top lid. After boiling water I would have to press the Open button 4, 5 or 6 times before it would work again. I'm thinking the heat & steam inside the kettle was somehow keeping the lid too tightly closed and in addition to this issue, I did not feel the kettle was good quality. No doubt about it, Cuisinart missed the mark on this one! After quickly returning the item, I made another kettle purchase (T-fal Thermovision). This kettle offers the same choice of different water temperatures for different teas and is much superior quality, great looking also. Super happy with the T-fal Thermovision purchase and would recommend it for sure.

This electric kettle is great. I have owned it since January 2016 and am very pleased with every feature. I use it multiple times every day, so the warranty on it is one of the things I really like. It holds a lot of water, which is useful if you want to get cooking water heated quickly. It is very quiet and has a quiet beep to let you know when the water is hot. If you don't hear it, it will reheat the water so that it will be the temperature you want it to be when you return to it. That would not be a good feature for someone who forgets altogether that they put the water on to heat.

I have been using it for about 6 months and it works really well. I use it daily for coffee and tea though I've only used the keep warm function a few times. I like that the kettle is separate from the cord. I haven't had any issues with labels peeling and I've been maintaining it pretty well with recommended cleaning methods. My only issue is that it's started to rust at the bar that runs across the hinge to the hood and no where else. It's still under warranty but it'll cost $15 plus shipping to have the unit replaced. It would also be nice to be able to turn off that blue light that turns on every time the kettle is returned to the cord.

I would have loved to give this a 5 star but can't because I haven't even had it a year and metal pieces started peeling off from the bottom ON THE INSIDE!! My family and I could have been drinking metal pieces without even knowing it before we realized what was happening. It was a great kettle until this started happening.

I received this kettle as a gift. I cook well and often and this kettle has quickly earned it's place on my counter (which is precious real-estate in my kitchen). I use it constantly for a variety of uses and I'm very pleased with it. I have used similar kettles in friend's kitchens. This one is superior to all of them.

Pros:
- Hot water in practically no time
- Well balanced, cool, ergonomic handle
- Calibrated, lighted water level indicator (metric)
- Multiple temperature settings for tea
- It's nice to look at

Cons:
- Base is not flat. It has a "male" centerpost that fits into the base of the kettle. This takes getting used to; you can't just drag the kettle off the base the way you would the carafe of a drip coffee maker, for instance. You must lift the kettle up off the base. It's a minor complaint, I know, but I've dragged the base across the counter on more than a few occasions. I'll learn.

- I wish there were an "Off" button. The keep warm feature is nice, but it's also nice to definitively turn something off. Fortunately the wall outlet is very easy to reach.

reviews.reviewTitle: We live in an area where the water is pretty soft, so we don't have scaling issues
reviews.reviewText:
After more than 2 years of daily use, this kettle has more than lived up to expectations.

We were looking for a kettle that could heat quickly and handle a multitude of user requirements. I drink french press and tea, she drinks chemex coffee. We also wanted something that could be toted around the house without being anchored by a cord on the kettle itself. This kettle has surpassed all of those expectations. Be advised that the base is still corded, so if you want to reheat, you will have to place the kettle back on the corded base.

We live in an area where the water is pretty soft, so we don't have scaling issues. If you live in a hard water table, you will have to take care to remove any scaling on a regular basis, as with any device that heats water.

I love that it has a temp setting for whatever beverage type you desire, and it maintains that heat level until you are ready to dispense. The water level is easy to read and it gives an audible beep when the temp has been reached.

My biggest complaint about this product is that the lettering on the buttons wears easily. The Start button is now completely blank, as is the Keep Warm button. They were faded after only a month of use. Embossing them would have made more sense, but by that time, their use was second nature anyway. That being said, this makes the product finish seem shoddy, and more attention should have been given to the buttons' durability over time.

If you are willing to maintain this kettle and don't mind the lettering coming off the buttons as you use it: I think this kettle is a great value for the sheer number of temperature ranges it can achieve and maintain, and its overall aesthetic.
Bought as a birthday present, I've heard nothing but great things about this kettle. I've even used it, and am impressed with how quickly it gets to temperature! Great quality!

Very disappointed in this, have had it less than 6 months and it is already having issues. One is that the lid does not open with the "open" button, it has to be pried open. The other is that it will boil forever unless you stop it. My previous version of this kettle would shut itself off when no longer in use. Used to think Cuisinart was a good brand but this will make me look around for another kettle. Bummer.

Bought this for our office. We have 2 Zojirushis at home, but decided on an electric kettle for the studio. Loved it, but it lasted less than a year. Extremely disappointed, for a $100 kettle I would expect it to last for many years. Our 2 Zojirushis are 7 and 6 years old and both are working like a charm. Going to buy a new Zojirushi for the studio. Every product I have bought from Cusinart has turned out to be a major disappointment. This was no difference. I relied on the reviews, but unfortunately this one let me down.

Where has this been all my life! Absolutely LOVE IT! Fast, clean, convenient and you can set it to your preference temp of liquid! I read about the "bell" ringing was a distraction? I do not have the same experience! Only rings when you set the temp. and when the temp has completed. Still it is a decent and pleasant chime.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'm super jealous and will eventually buy one for myself
reviews.reviewText: I bought this as a gift for my uncle. He loves it. This kettle takes the guess work out of getting water to the proper temperature for a variety of teas or coffee. It will also keep the water at a temperature you select (it will automatically begin to heat it back up when the temperature drops). I'm super jealous and will eventually buy one for myself.

reviews.reviewTitle: Absolutely perfect for a tea lover.
reviews.reviewText: I've been putting off writing a review of this kettle to make sure it would withstand many, many uses. It has now been in daily use for about nine months, and by "daily use" I mean that I'm using it anywhere from two to four times a day for multiple infusions of loose leaf tea, and I couldn't be happier with it. It heats the water quickly and accurately, and has enough capacity that I can heat my little 2.5 cup teapot with hot water, drain it, fill it again to infuse my tea, and have enough hot water left over to jump start my oatmeal. The fact that the hot water isn't in contact with any plastic is also lovely; even when I've gone out of town over the weekend and accidentally left water in it, there hasn't been a hint of plastic smell or rust. Speaking of accidents, the automatic shut off and dry boil prevention are a blessing for the scatterbrained, and have probably prevented me from burning my house down more times than I care to admit. My only caveat is this: if you live at a high altitude and set it to "boil," it will keep trying to heat your water for several minutes after you can hear it boiling away in there, because it's trying to get it to 212º, which is rather impractical at 5000 ft unless you're using a pressure cooker. Keep an ear on it!

reviews.reviewTitle: A cronic tea drinkers dream!!! LOVE IT!
reviews.reviewText: I love this kettle. Brew the perfect cup of tea every time! The temp is perfect every time, I drink a variety of teas on a daily basis so the many temperatures are fantastic. The fact that it keeps the water warm is wonderful too; sometimes I forget and get sidetracked until I hear the beep again that the water has heated to the right temperature. My husband uses it to make his instant oatmeal in the morning and I use it daily for tea so it gets used at least once to twice a day and has yet to disappoint me. I love the fact that it is cordless and I can use it in another room if I need to. I have had this product since October 2010 and am very pleased with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cuisinart is not the quality brand it used to be-Was nice while it lasted.
reviews.reviewText: I have had two of these kettles. Loved them while they worked, but after going through two in about 3 years, I am going to change brands. Pros: heats quickly and has the different temperature settings, nice looks, large capacity. Cons: temp settings literally wear off the buttons within short amount of time, reliability/longevity issue. Cuisinart used to be the go to brand for me and I would pay a bit more for the quality it offered. However, paying more for this kettle and having the paint rub off the temp buttons very quickly was very disappointing. First one died after about a year and a half and I got another right away. Again, paint rubbed off buttons quickly. And the final clincher: second one died after just over a year again. I am currently looking for another brand, probably the Kitchen Aid kettle. I may just go to my warehouse store and get one for a quarter of the price that they will gladly replace if anything goes wrong. At the price Cuisinart charges, I would expect the quality to be superior, but it is just not the case any more. Seems they are just resting on their laurels. I even wrote the company after with my praises for the product but suggestion for a remedy for the disappearing paint, and never received a response from them.

-The open button to open the lid stopped working. I got it replaced and the new one failed within a month.
-The beeping is quite annoying and the kettle is not intuitive to use
-It doesn't feel easy/sturdy to carry when full, the balance/center of gravity is off somehow
If you're between this and Breville's kettles, go with Breville even the simple ones without options are better than this over-engineered-but-doesn't-quite-work kettle.

reviews.reviewTitle: EXCELLENT UNTIL IT BROKE IN LESS THAN 6 MOS. CHARGED $15 FOR A REPLACEMENT.
reviews.reviewText:
This kettle worked flawlessly until it stopped working in less than six months (boiling mechanism shut down). To my shock and disappointment, I had to pay $15 in shipping and handling for my replacement of a unit that went defective on its own. So, not only did Cuisinart make money from my original purchase, they're profiting off my warranty unit. What actually needs replacement is the company's customer service policy. NOT COOL

As evidenced by countless other reviews, this product has a shelf life of 3mo-2yrs max. PLEASE SAVE YOUR MONEY AND STAY AWAY. My grandmother's electric kettle bought from the early 80's which she uses daily is functioning to this day.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect up of tea every time!
reviews.reviewText:
I am an avid tea drinker (never touch coffee, ever.) I have always just boiled the water and dumped it over the tea and drank. A couple of months ago I started to experiment making matcha (a special kind of green tea.) Well, discovered that matcha wants a VERY specific temperature to brew or it "burns". I experimented with a variety of ways to get it just so ...
Anyway, my electric water kettle broke (only 6 months old, but that is another story) so I needed to buy I new one. I decided to upgrade to the Cuisinart Programmable Kettle. Honestly, it has been AMAZING! Perfect cup of tea EVERY time and it keeps the water at the temp if you want it to. I could not believe how brewing tea in at the right temperature brought out the best in the flavor of each type (green, black, etc.) OK, I'm sold and if you are a tea drinker I highly recommend this.

We bought this kettle less than a year ago and loved the variable temp and keep warm feature since between the 2 of us, we use the kettle a lot. The last couple of weeks, it's been touchy about turning on and now within the last 2 days it went down to not heating the water enough to not heating at all now. For an expensive product less than a year old, I am very disappointed. I liked the features enough that I am looking for another kettle with the same type, but I don't think I will be replacing it with another cuisinart. I liked the kettle, but for longevity, it falls short.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easily the best kettle I've used
reviews.reviewText:
So happy to have found this. Bought the Aero coffee press a few months ago and was really getting tired of standing up a meat thermometer into the old kettle, trying to hit as close to 175degrees as I could each time...

Any kettle with a temperature shut-off would have done for me, but this one is so much more than that!

The detachable base is perfect. Cordless lack of clutter when pouring. The pour is clean (no dribble of scalding hot water onto the counter or sleep-retarded bare skin). Easy to fill, and oh yeah- it looks great.

It seems like a bit of cash to lay out for something that "just makes the water hot", but this really does make the coffee and tea-making process a delight.

Highly recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Alternative way of making your tea!!
reviews.reviewText: OK, so what the box doesn't tell you is that you can actually add the loose leaf tea into the tea maker after it heats the water to let it steep. The tea maker has a filter that doesn't let the tea leaves go into the mug while pearing. I did that and found it way better then using another container to steep and go through the hassle of straining the tea. It's just boil, steep, and pour. Love it!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great kettle, too many quality issues
reviews.reviewText:
I received this is a gift in December 2011. Since then I've sent it back twice. Once for overheating water (190F water was actually closer to 200F). Once for simply not heating water. Tried various things that the customer service people recommended but it didn't help. Customer service was very helpful. Big downside: I've spent $20 on shipping back the defective kettles.

I wouldn't buy one if it was my money. Considering how simple the device is (heat water, detect temp, stop heating) it seems like it should fail less. But there might not be a similar product.

I love this kettle! I have been using it at least once a day for a few months now. It has everything I could want in a kettle: a large capacity, fast heating times, no BPA, minimal plastic in contact with the heated water, and enough temperature settings to properly make a variety of teas and coffee. The "keep warm" feature isn't very important to me but it's nice to have if I temporarily forget about my water.

This item seems a bit expensive but I don't mind paying extra for a kettle with a solid-feeling construction, lots of reviews indicating its reliability, and all the features I want.

Some other reviewers have complained that the lid gets hot when you heat water. To me, this is not an issue at all. If I need to close the lid while it's hot, I just use a towel or a spoon instead of my finger and everything is fine.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best Kettle at the $99 price point
reviews.reviewText:
So I was looking for a new kettle which had to have quick boil, a quality feel to switches, quality build, a lift off base & good looks.

And having physically played with all that were available in the two biggest brick and mortar shops, I settled on the Cuisinart CPK-17; I'm very happy with it! For me I would have liked a bit more design flare but it's far from bad looking. I don't like the bright blue light which stays on for 5 minutes after the kettle finishes, all Cuisinart devices seem to be following this trend including the toaster (a friend just bought the toaster and they unplug it because of the bright blue lights).

I love the idea of the temperature selection though to be honest I don't think I really notice the difference! The lid is an easy to open by lightly pressing the button. The switches are a solid quality and feel good (not a plasticy or hinged press type as on others). One slight letdown is the spout pour, when nearing the last cup of water in the kettle spurts of water come off in different directions, as long as you are pouring into the cup correctly and not too near the edge it's no problem; I was surprised the design team missed this though!

The digital buttons are nice, the kettle is metal so no fear of any plastic odors, the kettle beeps when boiled (and quite quietly with a nice tone which is nice).

The price is quite high if you consider you can buy a kettle that boils water for $18. But if you have a bit of spare cash, want a good looking device, with great build quality & boils quickly (1500 watts), then this is for you.

Five stars for this kettle! My husband and I drink tea daily and this kettle has been a fixture of our kitchen for the last six months. We love the temperature control feature and have had no issues with print wearing off the buttons (as mentioned in other reviews). The body of the kettle does get hot, but the handle is cool and it doesn’t bother us. Highly recommend this if you’re looking to upgrade your kettle.

The product was fantastic... until it quit working. We received it as a gift just under three years ago, and while I believe it's failed under the warranty period (it no longer heats water, and I tried descaling it), Cuisinart's policy requires me to pay to ship it to them, and enclose $15 for them to (potentially) ship back a new one. So for $30, I can hope that Cuisinart replaces it under warranty... or I can buy another manufacturer's kettle.

I was an avid Cuisinart customer prior to this purchase.
My blender is Cuisinart
I have the Cuisinart Griddler
I have the Cuisinart hand mixer
I have the Cuisinart coffee maker
I could go on for days! I intended on buying baby items for my upcoming birth from Cuisinart but that will NOT be happening.

The point here is that I WAS loyal to this brand but that ended with this purchase. I purchased this item because I love to drink tea as does my friends when they visit and my mother. Initially, I had a stove top kettle but it by the time we were ready for the second round, the water would only be lukewarm. This kettle seemed perfect at the time since it had the “keep warm” option so I paid the $107.98 which is pretty steep for just a little but, I trusted the Cuisinart brand and was confident that the product would be of such quality it would be worth the purchase.

Needless to say, THAT was not what happened.

After the first months use, I was initially satisfied, I even came back on Amazon and left a positive review. THEN I started having problems with the kettle and it finally stopped working. First mineral stains built up at the bottom of the kettle since I was using tap water so I bought a brush with a handle that I could stick inside to conduct the cleaning since my hands did not fit into it comfortably.

That was the first inconvenience since now I had to constantly maintain it by brush to keep the build up from happening.

Second issue, well, it finally stopped working within 4 months so I called customer services at amazon, they said I was outside the warranty period. So I called Cuisinart directly.

The representative that I spoke to told me there was a $10.00 fee to complete the exchange and I would have to return the defective product. I assumed this fee would be fully loaded meaning it included a shipping label to return the defective item and the shipment of the replacement. Initially I was upset that I have to spend another $10.00 on top of the $107 spent but I figured $10.00 was better than attempting to purchase another.

Well, to my great surprise, the $10.00 additional fee was for Cuisinart to send me the replacement and the company demanded I return the defective product on my dime!

I was very upset but figured, there is no point in keeping a defective product laying around so I went to the USPS and they quoted me $25.95 to return the product. Needless to say, I did not move forward with this shipment and the defective product is still in my garage.

I would NOT recommend ANY Cuisinart product moving forward nor will I be replacing any of my current items with Cuisinart.

I attempted to correct my initial review but Amazon would not allow me so i had to create a whole new account JUST to write this review.
Woke up one morning with water all over the floor - the seal broke. Returning it would cost $15, about the cost of a cheap replacement.

So far so good. I've used it to make Sweet Tea a few times and it works great. The temperatures were exact for each setting, I used a thermometer to measure water temp. I wouldn't recommend for carrying long distances because it is a bit heavy and awkward to hold once filled with water and heated but working on the counter right next to it works. Love that it has the keep warm option even though I haven't really had to use it. All in all I love it.

After a few months of use, the handle on this thing crumpled inward while I was using it, making a crunch noise and scaring the bejesus out of my family. The handle is made of cheap plastic, painted to look like metal. After that happened, it stopped working. The light comes on, but the water won't heat. Not worth 90 dollars for this piece of garbage.

On purchasing the CPK-17 Cuisinart perfect temp kettle, our first thought was its expensive. However at this price it would last and do the job we really wanted.
For 12 months it did, after that is began to turn off early, two months later it would heat intermittently for over 25 minutes and never boil at all. We contacted Cusinart and asked them what we should do. They said that our kettle "was defective and still under warranty" and we would have to send them $15 and they would send another one, also we would have to pay guaranteed insured postage on the old one and send it back.
Now we may be living in a different realm, but if a company tells you that their product is "defective" and "under warranty" why is it that we are having to pay a considerable amount to get a working model. On writing back stating this we got a reply some time later with the standard "Valued Customer" saying yes under the circumstances we will waive the $15 but you pay the rest.
This is the third time we have had a product break down, each time we have received a replacement item in the mail, (in the case of Braun it was a much more expensive item and they just wanted us to be satisfied.
That is beyond anything we would expect and outstanding customer service.)
Look on most web sites and its "free shipping" so why is it that an expensive "defective" item is going to cost the "valued customer" in shipping.
We would have thought that if we were indeed "valued Customers" sending a replacement item with a return shipping label would have been the thing to do.
We now have a "defective" expensive kettle, and no further customer service, which leads us to believe we were not that "valued" and to know we will no longer be "customers" of Cuisinart products in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: Heats quickly, quiet, vary temps are great, but doesn't last long
reviews.reviewText: This kettle was wonderful while it lasted. I received it off my wishlist last May, and it lasted for 14 months. Then it died with no warning. We bought another base unit from the Cuisinart store, thinking that might be the problem, but it didn't work on the new base. So this is a nice kettle while it lasts, but considering that it dies after a year, it's way over priced. We're replacing it with a cheaper cordless electric kettle.

I received the Cuisinart PerfecTemp cordless electric kettle as a very generous Christmas gift from a friend. I loved it...and then less than three months later, it simply stopped working. I had the same experience that many other reviewers mention. I would turn the kettle on but nothing would happen. After a minute, the kettle would beep and shut off without heating the water. Fortunately, I live in CA so I did not have to pay for shipping to return the kettle. I packed up my broken kettle in the original packaging and UPS picked it up. A week later, I received a new kettle. That process was easy enough, but I just think that a $90 kettle should not break so soon. In fact, before I was given the kettle, I was using a $20 plastic hot pot that was still going strong after 10 years. I've begun to distrust Cuisinart. Of the two Cuisinart appliances I have owned (a mini food processor and the kettle), both broke very soon.

It died after just a little over two years. For $79 I expected it to last a little longer. I loved that it had the temperatures for the various tea types on the side. I may try to get something less expensive next time.

reviews.reviewTitle: The best kettle ever...until it stopped working
reviews.reviewText: This is the best kettle I ever had. Great design, easy to use etc. etc. Except after about 6 months it stopped heating up. Turn it on, the lights light up as they should, wait a few minutes, then beep beep beep, and that's it. I guess the heating element burned out or something. Seems like lots of people have the same problem. Threw it in the garbage and bought a cheap one to replace it.
I liked the temp guide. This is my second one. Right at the end of year it decides to give up. Trying to figure out which one I will try now. Definitely NOT this one.

I have had one of these for over two years and I LOVE it! I use it every day, usually 2 or 3 (or more) times every day. Yes, one or two of the labels on the temp buttons I use most have faded.
