http://www.amazon.com/Hamilton-Beach-40882E-Stainless-7-2-Cup/dp/B004XJWQZQ/ref=sr_1_3?ie=UTF8&qid=1415988475&sr=8-3&keywords=electric+kettle+hamilton

This Cuisinart kettle is better than the Hamilton in three regards:
1. The Cuisinart has multiple temperature settings
2. The Cuisinart can maintain your water at one of the set temperatures
3. The Cuisinart has a nicer closing mechanism (it requires just a light touch)

But in every other regard, the Hamilton Beach is superior. Here are a few of the important ones:
1. The Hamilton won't burn you if touched by accident. The Cuisinart either is not insulated at all or has poor insulation. Several members of my family (me included) have accidentally burned ourselves when our hands brushed against the Cuisinart. This NEVER happens with the Hamilton. The Cuisinart requires caution that is inconvenient in comparison.
2. The Hamilton pours MUCH better. Due to the use of a water screen filter on the spout, the Cuisinart pours miserably. It pours like 5 separate scattering streams of water in different directions when you pour water out. It's incredible that this design flaw somehow got past the product team at Cuisinart because it makes the kettle so hard to pour. The Hamilton has a straight forward, smooth pour that is expected of any Kettle. Cuisinart is just terrible at pouring and can spray water out of your mug accidentally.
3. The Hamilton is confusing to use. When you put back the kettle onto the base after pouring out freshly heated water, the background light indicator goes blue. I have no idea what this means and the manual does not describe it either. Neither the "STart" nor the "Keep warm" button lights go on, so I'm not sure if it's keeping warm, reheating or what. It certainly doesn't look off because the blue light indicator is on. So this forces me to press the "Start" button to turn the "Start" indicator button on again, and then re-press the "Start" button again to shut off ALL the lights. This is the only way I can be certain the kettle is off after use and it's very inconvenient. Granted extra features add complexity, but this is still poorly thought through design that got past the product team.

There are more smaller issues but they are not substantial.

Hopefully either Cuisinart or a competitor comes out with an improved version of this soon.

reviews.reviewTitle: This kettle is one of the best investments you can make in your kitchen!
reviews.reviewText: This kettle is one of the best investments you can make in your kitchen! I never use my stove top burner kettle any more. It comes up to heat very quickly and beeps to let you know the water is heated. I use it everyday! It about as fast as a Keurig but more environmentally friendly. My favorite feature is the different temperature settings. I drink tea and coffee and don’t have to guess if I am reaching the proper temperature range. I got rid of my old drip coffee pot and only make pour over or French press coffee now. I am a firm believer that every kitchen should have one of these. 3 or 4 times a year I will boil a little white vinegar inside to de-scale the inside from hard water buildup.

Overall I am pleased with this kettle. It does exactly what I wanted.

I love the Keep Warm option. I can walk away and get back to making coffee whenever I have the time.

I like the lit measurement window. I no longer have to hold it up to eye level to see how much water I am pouring into it.

The keep warm button for boiling kicks back in when the temperature dips to 200 to 203 (it varies)

The 200 degree button heats the water to 204 to 208 degrees (again, it varies) and the keep warm kicks in when it dips to 200 to 203 degrees.

The other buttons do likewise, e.g. subtract 10 from each number and that is what the 190 button does.

The 200 button is perfect for coffee. Ideally the water should never reach boiling in order to keep the air in the water and one should use water between 195 and 205 degrees.

The thermostat stops at the same temperatures if you start cold or hot (unlike my smaller Adagio Teas 3 UtiliTEA Variable-Temperature 30-Ounce Electric Kettle)

It takes about 5.5 minutes to get 1.5L of cold water up to 195 degrees and about 7 min to get to boiling (actually 6.5, but it takes another 30 seconds before it dings).

I did not anticipate the lack of ounce markings, so I put notations in permanent marker on light tack masking tape for 12, 18, 24, 30, 36, 42, 48, 54. Why 6 oz intervals? The standard for coffee is 10g per 6oz cup and that is how my grinder dispenses itBreville BCG800XL Smart Grinder, so 6oz markings work best for me.

It is difficult to see the water level at 12oz and impossible for less than that amount.

I was a little annoyed at the lack of a dedicated OFF button. You turn it off by pushing the START button again (or taking the pot off the charging stand), but this one-button method has a downside. If you are like me and only pour into it the exact amount of water you want and always empty it... You need to turn it off BEFORE you pick it up off the stand because once the pot is put back on empty and begins to heat up again, a safety mechanism kicks in and it just blinks and beeps until you either keep it off the stand or put cold water into it and wait a minute for it to click.

There is a piece of plastic attached behind the screen at the pour spout to keep tea bags inside the pot I suppose. It effectively stops the water from exiting gracefully from the kettle from the spout near the end of the pour. When the pot is not quite empty, it starts to comes out in several different streams and always traps some of the water so I have to re-pour several times if I do not want to leave any water in the pot to leave behind mineral deposits. There is a nut holding it place. It is difficult to do so, but I finally managed to use a socket wrench to remove the nut and the plastic, so all is well now.

It has an interesting method to keep the water away from the plastic level gauge. The interior is all stainless steel except for a bulb near the bottom which lets water into the measurement window. Since you are not looking at the main body of water directly (like you do with a measuring cup). The delay is a bit odd at first and it does gets steamed up, but it does work and it limits exposure of the water to the plastic during heating.

This kettle has two major fails - both related to cleaning.

Firstly - the top opening is too small to fit my medium sized man hand into. This makes washing the thing into much more of a chore than it needs to be.

Secondly - there's some things sticking into the chamber. One on the back wall, the other up from the bottom. The attached photo shows them. These too make cleaning the kettle more difficult than it needs to be.

I'm being super picky because I bought this kettle to replace my heavily worn Krupps kettle. That kettle is (almost) perfect. Big opening and nothing to snag a sponge.

Other than these two fails, this is a good kettle that heats quickly, maintains temperature etc. It's just so annoying to clean it.

reviews.reviewTitle: excellent right out of the box
reviews.reviewText: update: one month, very happy!! So easy to get hot water, with optional temps! Prior: Glad I got this. Only used two days, happy so far! Just fill, press the temp you want, start. Literally less than 3 minutes to heat up. 1L was under 2 mins to 160. So the Pro's are: the SS looks nice, sits stable on the heat plate, cordless serving, no spill spout. A low, blue light is on while heating , easy push button to start. When done, three low chimes tell you it's done. This is very low and will not wake the sleeping spouse. FYI: the cord is short. 12 to 15 inches short. You must put base near an outlet. There is some plastic, inside, due to it having a mesh filter at the pour spout. I think most people filter water before filling the tea kettle, so it does not do much. But I also think it's low contact with your water, during a few seconds of pouring. Having control over the temperature is great. It's accurate. I tested first pot to 160, my household meat thermometer said same. Con: Only one, you cannot easily clean the inside. Barely maneuver a bottle brush in there! Fill hole is large enough to easily fill, but no adult can get their hand in it. Totally does what it says. Hope this helps.

Do not waste your money. Honestly, I love this pot with it's temp programs, but after 4 months suddenly I noticed that every time I used it, it leaked all the water out of the bottom all over my entire countertop. I even nearly burned my hand on the boiling water as it was dripping out of the bottom.
It created a huge mess. I emailed them and they said it's under limited warranty and they will replace it, but I have to pay $15 for shipping of the new tea pot and also pay for return shipping on my own! Absurd. I only paid $80 for this in the first place! No way am I paying another $30 for a replacement of a defective, dangerous item. Also, the opening is really narrow and it makes it hard to clean.

reviews.reviewTitle: Replaced twice, both defective but in different ways
reviews.reviewText: Bought this kettle after reading good reviews on wirecutter. After a few months, it started leaking from the base of the handle. Cuisinart replaced under warranty, but I had to pay the shipping. Now the replacement kettle has started leaking from the spout. The attachment to the body has come loose. Still waiting to hear back from CS but this does not bode well for what used to be a reliable quality brand.

reviews.reviewTitle: DO NOT BUY!!! Cheap unit & warranty is a joke
reviews.reviewText: This is a higher end, higher priced, nice looking multifunctional...piece of garbage. As several other reviews pointed out, this product is cheap, plain and simple. Often times, we see some negative reviews and buy anyway, sometimes successfully, but this was not one of those times. After less than three months, this has formed a leak on the bottom where the plastic meets the body, and slowly drips water out. Twice now I have woken up in the morning to a huge pool of water all over the counter. After that, I tightened the three screws on the bottom thinking it might help, and filled it 1/4 full with water...same drip from three different areas immediately. Didn't help. This kettle is now unusable and we have to replace it. Like many others have pointed out, this has a 3 year limited warranty; I called the manufacturer, and Cuisinart wants $15 shipping for a new unit, then I have to pay more separate shipping to send the defective unit back...$25, $30 in all? Oh but a new unit is free! LOL. I tried to get the shipping charges waived but no go, so don't even try. No way I'm paying $30 MORE now in addition to the $76 originally paid, just so I can get a replacement that likely will also be defective. Like George Bush said "Fool me, you can't get fooled again!" (LOL). Amazon took care of me though...no surprise there. This product is garbage and so is Cuisinart's warranty policy...Amazon continues to dominate though as usual.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's a beautiful kettle and worked great for awhile
reviews.reviewText: I used this kettle for about a year and a half and for the last 6 months it's hardly functional. As a tea lover, I was very excited to have the quick temperature select buttons for different kinds of tea. It's a beautiful kettle and worked great for awhile. Now on occasion when I plug it in it won't tun on. When it does turn on, it will shut off mid boil cycle. Sometimes it will come back on after several minutes, sometimes it won't for far longer. On the rare times it gets to temperature, it sometimes will only beep once and shut off where before it would beep 3 times. Even with the keep warm setting off it sometimes will turn itself back on and start boiling so I just keep it unplugged when not in use. I've taken very good care of it. I descale it with vinegar, keep it clean, and baby it, but it didn't matter. Seeing other recent reviews this is a pattern and I hope the Cuisinart takes responsibility for this. They want me to pay shipping both ways to replace it. I may as well put that money towards a competitor's kettle. I'm just angry considering how much I paid for this expecting a higher end product. Oh well, buyer beware.

Absolutely love this kettle! I have owned mine for 8 years now. It still functions just as well as the day I purchased it. I have had no issue with the writing coming off and had no need to utilize the warranty. I always have the perfect temperature water for whichever tea I choose that day, and I use it to quickly boil water to heat up my son's thermos for his lunchbox. It is so versatile!

Works great. I love the fact it keeps the water at the right temp. I french press my coffee so its ready when I am to make another pot. It takes 5 minutes for it to turn off if you don't have it set to keep the water at temp. At first I thought something was not right but after reading the manual that is the design.

*** 4 Month update ***

Got up this morning to make my coffee and it just beeps at me like so many others. I will contact Cuisinart but I shouldn't have to, it should still be working after only 4 months and used once daily. I was cautious after reading the reviews on this but sure enough, it happened to me as well. I've taken good care of it and before it broke it did work great but with so many having this issue its simply a badly designed product or cheap parts.

*** Update to 4 Month Update ***

I left it unplugged for a couple of days and it started working again. Don't know why but works for me. It is still working today so only once has it not wanted to heat the water up but does have me worried it won't last near as long as the Breville I have.

I love this electric kettle. It's my first, so I have nothing to compare it to. It heats up fast. Water stays at selected brew temp for 30 minutes. I've been using it daily (sometimes several times a day) since it arrived and it's holding up well. The stainless steel is low maintenance. Descaling seems easy enough in the directions, but I haven't needed to do this yet. I love the portability of the kettle. I would highly recommend this kettle. The only exception would be of you have small children around it, as the outside does get hot because it's not insulated in any way. Just an FYI. If you keep it up on top of a counter, that shouldn't be a problem, however.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for temperature presets but keep warm feature is pointless and wasteful
reviews.reviewText:
After 3 months I'm still pretty happy. It's very convenient especially if you drink green or white tea to get the temperature preset.

Personally I don't like that by default it tries to maintain the temp when you put it back on the base (they claim this is a feature) since 9/10 times either;

a) I don't want more water
b) It needs refilling aanyway before it has enough for another pot of tea
c) It has very little water left and tries to keep boiling a tiny bit of water for no reason
d) I don't want my next pot for more than 30 minutes when it already shuts off and thus is just wasting power

So generally after I pour my water I just don't put it back on the base - which is kind of silly. You can turn it off but you shouldn't have to do that. Temperature maintenance only really makes sense when you have a much larger kettle. It's also pretty pointless since it boils from cold very quickly anyway.

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes the perfect cup every time.
reviews.reviewText: This pot works wonderfully. Heating water is fast and convenient. Being curious, I checked the temperature at a few of the settings with a cooking thermometer, and the water was within 2 degrees, give or take, of what it claims. Having the ability to hold a temperature for 30 minutes is a very nice and useful feature. As well, the removable filter is a nice touch, though with hard water can be a bit of a nuisance. The stainless steel body is easy to clean, and the blue internal light makes seeing the water level easy. The only thing I would change would be to give this unit a longer power cord.

I like it a lot as it heats up small and large volumes quickly. All that doesn't matter though if quality fails: the kettle started leaking after 3 months regular usage.

I contacted the seller (My Goods) for replacement and hope to update this comment when I have next steps.

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent product but it malfunctioned. Utilizing 3 yr warranty
reviews.reviewText: The kettle is decent. I don't know if it's defective or it's by design but after boiling, it doesn't shut down. It'll wait and keep boiling again. I read elsewhere where some thought this is a bug but we just assumed it's bad design. As a result, we always remember to pull the plug after it boils. We've been using this every day since Jan 2016. Last few months, the plug has been getting really hot and yesterday it just blew out. Super dangerous. Called Cuisinart after being reminded from reviews here that there's a 3 yr warranty. They took my information, sending a new product plus a prepaid return label. Hope the new one works properly and we get more than 3 yrs out of it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Having to replace twice in about 3 months.
reviews.reviewText: It started out great. Heats coffee fast and easily. Then, after about a month it stopped working. They replaced it for free which was great. But now, about another month and a half later the entire Kettle is leaking. Where the side walls go down to the base water slowly drips out. I thought maybe one of my kids had just put some water on the counter a couple times so I put a couple dry paper towels down on the counter and set the kettle on top of it. Sure enough water is leaking out of it. I'm going to have to send in for another replacement. This is getting old.

reviews.reviewTitle: Modern accurate with multiple temp settings
reviews.reviewText:
Love this hot cattle. This is only my second one on 10 years. I considered different ones as a replacement, but in the end I went and got the same one (updated version). It has more temp settings and self temperature monitoring with option of keeping the water at set temperature for period of time, or of auto shutoff, than any other electric cattle I could find in this price point. It also looks beautiful in stainless steel with blue light.
I find it hard to clean because of its shape but it can be done just as any other appliance.

I bought this kettle "used - like new" as an Amazon Fulfillment guarantee. I expected it to be a brand-new product that someone simply changed their mind about and returned. I was surprised to see that the Start button had a worn patch from use, which to me means it had been used quite a bit; but given that, more surprisingly the unit was incredibly clean inside and out with no marks, blemishes, or discolorations. Very pleased with that. I've just had it a month now, but kettle functions perfectly so far.

The only con for me is the ergonomics of the handle - despite having fairly large hands, I cannot reach the Open button while holding the kettle mid-air; I have to set it down on the counter to reach the button that opens the lid. Kind of annoying, but not a deal-breaker.

I bought this in 2011 and it's now 2019. It is still going strong after almost daily use. The selectable temperature is a godsend for my green tea. It also boils water so quickly that I normally start-off my boiling needs in the kettle before pouring into a pan on the stove. This is as durable as a stove-top kettle. At least two of my friends have purchased this kettle after my recommendation and have been just as happy.

I suggest you put ONLY water in this kettle. That way you don't have to clean anything. So, don't put tea, teabags, or coffee in the kettle.

I ordered this almost one year ago and it has stopped working. Does anyone know how I can fix it? The lights come on, but it just doesn't heat up.

I like that it has different temperature settings and that it is not made of plastic, but when I was looking on Amazon for the warranty I found this---We are providing the following warning for products linked to this page:

WARNING: This product contains chemicals known to the State of California to cause cancer and birth defects or other reproductive harm.
That sort of worries me.
I was going to order another one, but now am not sure.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great unit, Not the most accurate
reviews.reviewText:
The bottom line is it is a really nice unit, The Sweet Home was right.

HOWEVER, my one grype is that is isn't very accurate. Google it or read the comments and you will sometimes see that the temp is too low, sometimes too high.

I did a few tests a couple times:
175 F setpoint for green tea - and I pour immediately into a cup and used 2 brand new thermometers to test (they are 5 second read thermometers) - it reads 163-165 regularly.
185 F setpoint for green tea - and I pour immediately into a cup and used 2 brand new thermometers to test (they are 5 second read thermometers) - it reads 170-175 regularly.

I stopped at that point, knowing mine likes to be a little colder than what I click - that's what I needed to know. I may contact Cuisinart about it.

Anyway, it's still the best boiler I've had.

reviews.reviewTitle: It looked good in the kitchen
reviews.reviewText: I didn't buy this from Amazon, but another store. I bought is as a present and I thought I might be getting what I paid for as this is not a cheap item, but after less than a month of use it wont even heat water anymore. The lights come on and after a couple minutes it turns off without heating anything. I have used other kettles and this one was the most expensive and lasted the shortest by a long shot. It looked good in the kitchen, but that's the only good thing I have to say about it. looking at Cuisinart web sight it doesn't seem to be worth even trying to get a replacement. Because of this I will probably avoid getting any Cuisinart items in the future. They appear nice, but if they are like this the internal quality is horrid, for someone spending $100-$150 for something that only have one job ( heat/boil water) this thing should last quite a few years not 3 weeks!!

reviews.reviewTitle: The best mid-range kettle on the market.
reviews.reviewText: I searched everywhere for the perfect hot water kettle. They range in price from about $20 for an ugly plastic unit to over $400 for a premium brand. I wanted a great quality mid-range unit that would look awesome on my coffee bar. I have been extremely happy with this. It’s easy to use and heats water very quickly. I love that I can set the exact temperature depending on whether I’m drinking green tea or black tea. I’m a fan of Cuisinart and trust their brand, and like always, they didn’t disappoint.

This worked fine the first two years (although it was very noisy as it heated up). But then it just stopped heating. It’s within the warranty period, so I called them. I would have to pack it up and pay to ship it to them PLUS enclosed a check to cover their shipping costs back to me. This is poor customer service. I paid $70 for this and would expect it to last more than two years. I’m not paying more money to have it fixed. And I’ll think twice before buying another Cuisinart product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mine has about six months in pretty constant service
reviews.reviewText:
Mine has about six months in pretty constant service, and I've had to disassemble the lid which stopped opening. The components are fairly low end, and while the opening button work again, I kind of have to fiddle with the retaining tabs in order to close the lid now (if you choose "boil," you must close the lid lest all your water boil away).

Pretty much, the lid is the only disappointing feature. It's over-engineered (no need for a push button unlocking mechanism), but it's over-engineered poorly.

As far as function and size, this thing is awesome. Volume is important in my household, so that's subjective, but great in my case. Functionality of choosing a temperature preset and "keep warm" really makes this a flexible product. No more too-hot, over-extracted coffee for me, and my wife loves choosing the correct temperature for her tea.

Really just a shame about the lid...

reviews.reviewTitle: I've had my kettle for a year and a half with no issues, another great product from Cuisinart!
reviews.reviewText: I've had this kettle for about a year and a half now, and I thought I would write a review. I am always pleased with Cuisinart products, and this one is no exception. I was a little worried before buying this kettle because of all the mixed reviews and the steep price. I haven't experienced any of the issues other reviewers have, such as the writing on the buttons rubbing off, and after a year and half my kettle is still working well! I love that it's stainless steel, relatively fast, holds a large amount of water, has temperature settings, and has a beep to alert you when the water is ready. I love this kettle and would recommend it to anyone!

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice kettle for the money. Is it really worth it though?
reviews.reviewText:
I've only had this kettle for a week to replace my dearly departed Hamilton Beach one and I'm not too sure how I feel just yet.
It works fine over all. When you plug it in the kettle has a blue light inside unless you click the Start button to turn it off.

There almost seems to be too much going on. The auto-heat function is nice but I don't want to have to turn it off every time I set it back down on the stand. I also do love the fact that there are different tea settings, which was my primary motivation for purchasing this kettle.

It is very very quiet throughout the entire brewing process, only at the very end when it's about to boil do you hear the bubbling. It releases 3 beeps when it is done which is convenient (or annoying) depending on what you are used to.

My main concern is the screws rusting on the inside, after seeing the images it's definitely something I will be looking out for.

Will update over time.

Bought this kettle in May of 2015 and have made more hot water for tea and coffee than I can possibly recall.
Unfortunately just four months after it's 3 year warranty has expired the base of the kettle where the handle meets the bottom is now leaking each time water is heated (see pic). Since it's out of warranty I don't see how I get this repaired and am likely going to have to buy something new. Bottom line, it's great while it lasts, which in this case is 3 years, 4 months.

reviews.reviewTitle: Perfect Temp is Right and Amazon Service Excels
reviews.reviewText: This water heater is indeed the perfect temp tool for the tea and coffee lover in your family. It heats water fast for the green tea and french coffee press blends to perfection. The features are all laid out nicely and the keep warm function is a real plus. The beep signals and blue light functions are well thought out and useful. A hi-tech specific temp water heater for your coffee and tea brew - very nice. Now for Amazon's service. The first one I got went kaput out of the box so I used Amazon's replacement web tool and before I could send the broken one back - I got the new one! I know there is always a few lemons in the manufacturing process but how a customer is treated when that happens is very important. Amazon has it right and I am not being paid anything to say this. I was one of the first Prime members and plan to stay for the future. This is better service than you would get a retail store with no hassle.

reviews.reviewTitle: Please add a temperature gauge and fix the disappearing letter issue
reviews.reviewText:
This is my 4th electric kettle and this one is acceptable but could use improvement.

Pros:
This looks nice and is comfortable to hold. It is easy to fill and pours well. It heats up fairly quickly and holds the temperature.

Cons:
It has many buttons but no temperature gauge so it is not possible to tell how quickly the water is heating up or how hot it is at the moment. I would prefer a single button for selecting different temperatures and use the space for a temperature gauge. This seems to be an issue with most electric kettles and it seems so odd because it is very useful.

I do not know if the problem of disappearing writing is still an issue but I have that problem with my keyboard and it is really annoying.

If these issues could be fixed and the kettle I have lasts a few years I would buy more in the future.

This kettle is SO LOUD! I purchased it to keep in my office, and I am returning it because I feel bad about disturbing the people around me. The beeping is really intense. It beeps when you turn it on, makes an intense churning noise as the water boils, and beeps three times when heating is complete. It also beeps repeatedly if it runs out of water while on the "Keep Warm" setting. All these things are so noisy that they're distracting to me in my office. I went outside my office and walked down the hall to see if the noise was traveling, and I could hear the sound of boiling water more than three doors down! I'm sure everyone around me is annoyed by this kettle and will be grateful when it's gone.

As for the functionality, the kettle is great. If you're a tea purist, then the different temperature options are a nice touch. But I'm taking my chances that another, quieter kettle will do just as well. After all, it's just boiling water.

reviews.reviewTitle: SO VERY HAPPY WITH THIS KETTLE
reviews.reviewText: I WANTED TO GET INTO MAKING TEA WITH LOOSE LEAVES AND SETTLED ON THIS ONE AFTER DOING SOME RESEARCH AND SO FAR IT IS A WINNER IN MY KITCHEN. EASY TO OPERATE - I HAVE SOME VISION PROBLEMS AND CAN MANEUVER IT QUITE WELL. HEATS SUPER-FAST AND i LIKE THAT THE CORD DOESN'T GET IN THE WAY. I'VE FOUND THAT OWNING CUISINART PRODUCTS HAS ALWAYS BEEN EXCELLENT AND RELIABLE.

reviews.reviewTitle: It stopped working in two months
reviews.reviewText: Bought one of these two years ago. When it died we decided to roll the dice and get another one. This time it lasted only two months. After (finally) reading the other reviews, I decided I didn’t want to deal with the hassle of trying to get cuisinart to replace it, so I took it out back and smashed it.

This kettle has changed the way that I drink tea.

I drink a lot of tea. Easily my husband and I go through 4 individual 6 cup pots each a day. From greens, to herbals, to yerba mate, to black, and then decaffeinated for the evening, it was tough to find a kettle that could keep up with everything we drink all day long that was within our price range.

There is plastic on the level indicator which was off putting for me at first but honestly it is difficult to find any kettle that doesn't have any bit of plastic in it. Because of the other people's reviews stating that the inside area when the screw is will rust after a year or so, we unplug and wipe it down in the evening and leave the lid up. While this might not totally prevent that, we figure that it will help to fully dry it every night and it honestly just takes a second out of our day.

It's not noisy. It heats within 5 degrees of the stated temp. I do like my tea a bit more cool then the temperatures that are on the buttons (I like my white teas at 165, blacks at 185, etc) but it really isn't that big of a hassle. Although we've only had it about a month and a half, we've used it 10 times each of those days without any problems. My only complaint is that for a full boil it can take 2 min as opposed to my old kettle that took under a minute but that's really minor.

This is a wonderful mid priced kettle for tea drinkers that want the best within a budget.

reviews.reviewTitle: I think we've been poisoned with melted plastic. STAY AWAY!!!
reviews.reviewText: Ordered one from Amazon and it was working fine for about 2 months. It started to leak from under the spout when pouring out hot liquid nearly burning my self and my daughter. I called up the manufacturer and they replaced it. Would be great except the replacement is also defective. The water tastes like plastic. We noticed a funny taste in the hot water and then about 2 weeks after it became EXTREMELY noticeable and unpleasant. It was a plastic type of smell, how long have we been getting poised by melted plastic?

reviews.reviewTitle: I loved this Cuisinart - it is well built and despite ...
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this as a gift for my son who loves to brew various teas which require precise temperatures. This Cuisinart kettle performed very well, rapidly heating water to the preferred temperature and then maintaining it that temperature. The unit eventually turns off automatically after a certain amount of time, but the kettle is well insulated and water remains heated for an extended period. There is a one-year warranty which I did have to rely on, with the unit failing just one week shy of that anniversary. I called Amazon which put me in touch with Cuisinart. They replaced the unit after I mailed the defective one back. My only issue was having had to pay for the return shipping. The new unit has lasted beyond another year after continual use. My son has since moved out to college and taken the kettle with him, which leaves me searching for a new one. I loved this Cuisinart - it is well built and despite the first failure, remains a sturdy product. I will not be using one as much as my son did so I will likely purchase a less costly model for myself.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice product let down by bad reliability and poor warranty
reviews.reviewText: When it works this is a great product. It's really nice to be able to chose the right temperature for the kind of tea you are brewing. On top of that, it is a stylish unit on the kitchen counter. However, the first one failed after a little over one year, and a second one failed after just six months and that is just not acceptable. To add insult to injury, Cuisinart's limited warranty requires paying both directions of shipping and handling for a failed unit which can hardly be classed as standing behind their product. Amazon, to their eternal credit, were able to provide great customer service and sort something out.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cannot get rid of plastic chemical taste, stopped using it.
reviews.reviewText: I used this for awhile, and could never get the plastic taste out of the pot. I've gone back to using the microwave to heat my water for now, until I can find another pot. This was an expensive lesson. I'll never spend this much to test a pot again, no matter what the reviews say. The lid is plastic, and the base is extremely lightweight plastic. I'm still looking for an electric kettle without plastic and heated chemicals going into the water, but I don't think they exist anymore. If you are going to get an electric kettle, get something a heck of a lot cheaper than this thing, which infuses plastic chemical taste into your water anyway. Sure, it looks snazzy, but it tastes like pooh.

I bought this to replace an Epica kettle I had that broke after a year of mild use.

This kettle is fantastic! It’s so much quieter than the old one and I love that it beeps when it’s ready, something the Epica did not do. A great feature for me is that the temperature buttons list what tea is right for the temperature - I can never remember.

I only wish that the outside didn't get hot but that seems to be the norm in electric tea kettles.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for teas and other uses
reviews.reviewText: I love this kettle, and have used it for about 5 years (purchased at Best Buy). One of the labels is just now wearing off. We like it so much that we bought a second for another residence (also from BB), and bought a third for a relative from Amazon. We use the Cuisinart kettle 3-4 times a day for teas, instant cereal, cocoa, ramen noodles, etc. Besides ease of use, the multiple temperature settings are perfect for our variety of teas. I got my first after getting spoiled in other countries by convenient "hot pots". So far, we've had no problems with any of them.

I ordered this kettle a couple of days ago to replace a year old Krups which had unexpectedly started leaking badly. I chose Cuisinart because I had previous good experience with a Cuisinart electric kettle and owned it for 15 years with no issues. Personally, I don't think I really need quite so many temperature options, however, it may be useful for other things besides tea. Off hand, I can think of bread baking where I need water at a certain temperature to proof yeast. Also, my husband doesn't like tea and coffee as hot as I do, so he will probably appreciate being able to select the temperature.

So, the kettle arrived today, via Prime shipping, with all the appropriate parts and such. There was an odd plastic/metal smell to the pot, but I rinsed everything according to the directions and then filled it with clean, cold water and set it to boil (212 degrees). I didn't find the water level indicator difficult to read, but my husband did. The lavender/blue light is a very nice touch, but truly serves no useful purpose. The kettle was easy to turn on (select the temperature button, and then hit "start") and was not at all noisy while it boiled. I was sitting in my office while it boiled and did not hear the "ding" to say it was done. I emptied the water, refilled it with clean, cold water and reboiled it. Again, I didn't hear the "ding", but that's not really a huge problem for me, given that this kettle has a "keep warm" feature. Once the second pot finished boiling, I set it up again to boil to actually make tea and stood over it while it worked. It only took a few minutes to heat up, was very quiet and seems efficient. The lid does get some condensation on the outside from the steam -- no big deal, just use common sense and keep your hands away while it's boiling. The outside does get warm, too warm to touch comfortably for any length of time -- it's a kettle. The purpose is to boil water, of course it's going to get warm. I made my tea, and was very pleased to note that there was no plastic smell or taste to the water. So far, I'm very happy with this and will update the review as necessary.

UPDATE 09/06/12 -- kettle is still going strong! No scaling that I can see in the bottom and the thing gets a lot of use. I recently felt very comfortable buying some loose green tea because I had a kettle that would brew it at the appropriate temperature. No leaks yet. So far, this is a winner!

UPDATE 04/07/13 -- the kettle is almost a year old, gets used on a "several times daily" basis and is still going strong. I have on a couple of occasions forgotten to fill it with water before hitting "start" (I thought there was enough water in it), but it will shut itself down if it's dry. That has more to do with my forgetfulness and busy-ness than anything wrong with the kettle. The labeling on the buttons is starting to wear down a little, but you can still read what they say, and if it gets really bad, I'll just paint it on. I would definitely recommend this kettle to anyone who asks (and have done),and I'm looking forward to the next 10 years or so.

UPDATE 01/25/16 -- Wow, it's been almost 4 years already?! Time flies. The kettle is still amazing, but it is starting to show some wear and tear consistent with regular use. The "212 (Black Tea)" button has no lettering on it at all, it has all worn off. No big deal, since I know which button it is. The lettering on the water level indicator has pretty much worn off as well, so the fact that it lights up really helps me to see how full the kettle is. There are no cracks or scratches or any other issues in the body of the kettle to worry about. The only thing that seems to be failing is the "ding". Sometimes the kettle will "ding" when it has boiled, sometimes it won't. Again, it's not a big deal because of the keep warm feature and the fact that I generally remember that I've put the kettle on and should go check on it. Still very happy with it and when the time comes to replace this one, I'll replace it with the exact same model.

UPDATE 04/07/18: Well, it finally died on me, after 6 years. It's a very sad day in my house, but I will replace it with the same model.

reviews.reviewTitle: Okay, could use some design improvements
reviews.reviewText:
This works well and is pretty easy to use. It's a good product if you want a cordless with temperature settings. We still have and use ours, bout it something like a year ago.

A few complaints though. Within a month of buying it the metal disk on top of the lid came off. The eat was too much for the glue that held it on. So its a little on the ugly side now.

Also, the sequence of how to work the buttons is not intuitive. I'm constantly turning it on when I want it to be off. I'll be in the other room wondering what "that sound" is and go in to find it boiling away. And I have to fuss with it to figure out how to shut it off.

But it's still working for us, and it does work well. It's not worth replacing for those issues.

reviews.reviewTitle: Have had it for 5 years, and still works great!
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this kettle for five years now, and it still works beautifully. It heats up water very quickly, and I love that I can control the temperature of the water. I use this for so much more than just tea - boiling water for Jello or a Neti Pot, whenever a recipe calls for warm water, etc. I just bought one as a gift and the recipient was delighted to receive it.

The one downside is that it is difficult to clean - mine will get mildew spots on the bottom of the kettle (because I constantly leave water in it) and getting your hand inside to scrub the bottom of it is tight. But for a product that consistently works well, I'll deal!

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought this solely based on reviews across multiple sites

reviews.reviewText: I bought this kettle a little over a month ago. I love the different temperature settings. Although I usually turn off the "keep warm" setting, it's really convenient in the morning; I can turn on the kettle, go do something, then come back and make my tea without having to wait around or interrupt what I'm doing to make tea. My husband has started making pour-over coffee with it, and he likes it as well. All in all, it feels like a lovely step up from the whistling stove-top kettle I had for 10+ years.

I am going to start my review by saying that I really did not want one of these Kettles. It sort of seemed redundant. I had a perfectly good kettle that I would put right on the stovetop and that was that. My husband, however, thought this was a great appliance. He saw what this kettle was capable of when they bought two for his office. He convinced me to at least give it a try.

One of the main reasons I gave in to try was because I felt that if this was as good of a kettle as was claimed, I would buy one for my dad. He's getting up there in years and he's forgotten he had things on the stove and they burned, including his kettle. I love that this is electric and it turns off automatically after a while. I also love that fact that there are so many temperature options. I just recently started drinking all sorts of tea and with this temperature function, my teas have come out quite well, and not overly brewed like they were with my regular kettle. (No more bitter green tea). Lastly, not only did I feel it was safer for my dad to use, but my children as well (don't worry, I still help them pour so they won't get burned), but I still like that they are not dealing with the stove and can now make their own hot chocolate and teas if they want to.

So far, I have been really happy with the performance of this kettle. It does just what it says it will do. It is easy to use, I like the lights so that you can see you have pushed the right button. I love that you can see the water reservoir so you know just how much water you are putting in. I also like that it really keeps the water warm for quite a while and will even keep your water heated to the correct temp. if you use that function. Frankly, I just like the basic function of it heating the water to the correct temperature.

Some cons: First is the price. I still feel it's a little much for basically what I feel is a fancy electric kettle. It is what it is I supposed. There are some electric kettles out there that are less expensive, but knowing that my husband's office uses two of these almost constantly, showed me that it's a hardy appliance and will stand up to use. Second, I noticed that I already have staining...it almost looks like rusting in the bottom of the kettle. We have very pretty hard water, so I expected it, but I guess I was surprised that it happened so fast. It still works fine, and doesn't effect the taste of the water so I guess it's more of a cosmetic issue for us. Not really a con, but more of a wait and see type of thing is what many other reviewers have written and that it stops heating up the water after only about a year? THAT does not sit well with me, but a lot of those were earlier reviews and I hope Cuisinart has fixed that problem.

Overall, I am happy with this Cuisinart Kettle, how it's performed, how it looks, and everything it does. I just bought another one for my dad's place. He used it more than we did when he was staying with us for the winter. I feel safer knowing he's using this instead of a regular kettle. I'd give this more of a 4 1/2 stars if that were an option.

reviews.reviewTitle: Super fun luxurious kettle, plastic inside the only drawback
reviews.reviewText: I love this kettle! It is so awesome to use this after using my previous stovetop kettle. It is quick to heat, taking only a minute or two for a full pot, and I love that you can adjust the temperature. The only thing I dock a star for is the plastic inside that is in place to hold the removable filter. That plastic can't be removed, but if I keep the water level below it, then the only plastic the water touches is the water gauge. They are hard plastics which they say are bpa free, so I'm sure they aren't that bad, still I'd prefer that no plastics come in contact with my morning tea and I hope that cuisineart and other companies with be moving in that direction according to consumer demand and opening awareness regarding the materials that come into contact with our food especially. I would definitely buy a new and improved kettle with only stainless steel or glass for the water to come into contact with before I consume it, how about you guys?

So far, our family loves this kettle. We've had it just over a year. The temperature control choices, ease of use, and reliability have been perfect. I read the one review re: the rusty screws. If we're not using our kettle, we don't leave water in it. While it's still hot, we empty whatever little bit of water may be left, and then we leave the lid up until the kettle has completely dried and cooled. Whether or not this is the reason we've had no rust problem, I do not know. I agree the response by Cuisanart's customer service department was poor. Anyway, so far, all is well with our kettle.

::::: BACKGROUND :::::

After years of having really bad coffee and tea, I started to educate myself. While there are SO many elements that go into a good cup of joe/tea, one of the biggest and most overlooked issues is brewing temperature. I have and use both a Chemex Coffee Maker 8 Cup Classic for pour-over coffee (the best method I've ever used) and a Teavana Perfect TeaMaker for teas. Both require pouring water through the top.

For the longest time, I used a tea kettle for all of my water-heating needs. Then I thought I wanted an inexpensive electric kettle, one that just heats until boiling and then shuts off (I'm not sure why, that wouldn't have done anything differently). But then I realized that I really need precise temperature control; a different temperature for every kind of tea and coffee is different still. That's when the Cuisinart came into view.

::::: PERFORMANCE :::::

The kettle heats very quickly. It's really nice that the heating element is actually in the base of the unit, shaving off a cord and weight from the kettle itself. While I haven't double-checked the temperature to see how accurate it is, I must say that I have noticed a drastic difference in taste with all but black tea (which should be brewed at boiling anyway). My whole life I thought I hated green tea and I couldn't figure out why oolong from a Chinese restaurant tasted so much better than at home. The brewing temperature!

::::: BUILD :::::

This has a very nice, strong build and looks very handsome on the counter. At first I thought the blue light on the water level window and buttons looked tacky, but now I rather like it. The "stainless" steel exterior is incredibly vulnerable to smudges and fingerprints, to the point that some marks seem to be permanently on there, no matter how hard I scrub. The lid has some sort of spring mechanism and opens very smoothly. There's also a removable screen in the spout that seems kind of silly to me; it could only filter very large particules, larger than anyone would have in their source water. Seems kind of pointless to me!

::::: ERGONOMICS :::::

The handle has pretty good placement, balancing the weight of the water quite nicely, allowing a nice, even pour. The spout also gives a nice, steady stream. The streamlined base is really nice and includes the heating element and single cord.

::::: OPTIONS :::::

The temperature selections are pretty convenient; that IS the point of this product. In a perfect world, this would be a variable selector, allowing you to dial in the exact temperature, but I'm guessing that would be more costly. Each button not only has a prescribed temperature, but a suggested substance to brew with that water. For example, I most frequently use 200º French Press, which really should just say "Coffee". Coffee is optimally brewed at 195-205º, so this preset is spot-on.

The keep warm function works really nicely for me. In the case of brewing coffee via Chemex, you need to pour over rather slowly, as to not flood and underexpose the grounds. Periodically placing the kettle back on the base instantly heats the water right back to 200º and I'm good to go.

::::: OVERALL :::::

All in all, I'm very happy with this kettle. It's a great brand, is nice looking, free of BPA, and offers convenient and (at least relatively) accurate presets. Most importantly, it helps me brew all of my favorite beverages at the proper temperature, yielding a VERY noticeably better drink. Though it's relatively expensive, its very worth it to me! Highly recommended!

::::: COFFEE SETUP :::::

Just as an extra plug, I use this as a part of my perfect-coffee trio:
- Cuisinart CPK-17 PerfecTemp 1.7-Liter Stainless Steel Cordless Electric Kettle
- Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, Black
- Chemex Coffee Maker 8 Cup Classic
I've never had a better cup than what this makes!

I have only just received this and am happy with the shipping and packaging. It's a little smaller than I had imagined, but it's fine and actually takes a little less space on my counter than the old electric kettle it is replacing while holding the same amount (1.7L). I did a lot of research and expected to get a glass kettle this time, but many reviews steered me away from them and towards a stainless steel one, and this was the best of the those I researched. It has many temp settings that I don't really need (as yet) not being a tea drinker, so I just use it on boil. I'd prefer that it would have that as a default setting but it's no big deal to push that button and then the Start button. It does heat up quickly and the water level window lights up in blue. If I designed it, the window would be bigger and not underneath the handle - just easier to read from across the room. With the handle facing you, you can't see the water level. I also find it a little unwieldy and unbalanced when picking up a full kettle - it's not a perfect design and I felt the need to grab it with my other hand. It pours nicely and the Keep Warm feature is nice. I'm pleased, and hope it lasts - the old one, a plastic Merlita, was over 10 years old! Nowadays I don't expect things are made like that, but fingers crossed...

I would give it 5 stars if it lasted longer than 4 years. The numbers tend to wear off, which is fine, you can still use it if you remember what they were, which we did, and then the lid stopped opening so we had to fill it through the spout, which is fine, it still functions. But we like it enough to have purchased our second one when the first one wore out so badly it was rendered useless. I utilize the different temperatures all the time. Black tea at boiling, coffee at 200, and green tea/chamomile tea at 175 are the main ones we use. It is fast and efficient and works great...at least in the beginning :) It's also big and heavy, but we don't mind that too much.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works but temperature doesn't control well
reviews.reviewText:
It heats up very quickly, so it serves my purposes well. I tested the device with a thermocouple, however, and it seems to always heat to roughly 10-20 degrees F below where the setpoint should be. If you want 195F water you will get 170F. Other than that, it seems to do its job well. I purchased an extended protection on the device because I've seen so many get rusted, but I haven't had mine long enough to see any rust.

Another minor complaint is that there is no OFF button. Once it's finished warming the water, I have to set it somewhere else to cool down instead of set it back on the plate, otherwise it will start to heat up again and freak out when there's no water (or unplug it). Why no off button?!

reviews.reviewTitle: Not accurate enough for science experiments, but makes a great cup of tea! ;)
reviews.reviewText: Love this kettle. I understand from other reviewers that I should expect the writing on the buttons to wear off sooner than I would like, but I am willing to live with that for the plus of having multiple buttons preset for my teas and the stainless steel "innards". As to that, the interior is nearly 100% stainless steel. The only places that are not are the area around the little hole near the bottom that lets water into the window area so you can tell how full the pot is, the underside of the lid, and the tab that holds the filter screen. The water-level window is BPA free per the manufacturer, but it is nice to know that most of my water is not touching it as it boils away. As to the lid and the screen tab, these only touch the steam in the kettle, not the water. Granted the steam can condense and fall back into the pot, but this does not seem to cause an off-flavor that I can identify. As to accuracy, I'd say it is good enough. I have tested it at full boil and at the Green Tea setting of 175 degrees. I'm at 5600 feet, so full boil here is 204 degrees not 212. The pot is clearly confused by this and wants to keep working to get the temperature up. However, it shuts itself off after a minute, then a minute later it tries again, boiling the water away. Since it has an automatic "boil dry" shutoff, I am not worried about this issue, but I will keep and eye on it when it is set at the Black Tea (boil) setting. When tested at the green tea setting, I noticed the water was always heated about three to five degrees past the set temperature (it took 1.7 liters of 67 degree water to 178 degrees in 6 minutes, and 7 minutes to get to full boil). When the water cools to one degree below its set point, it turns on the heat again and heats the water up to 178 again. In two cases, it went up to 180 degrees. I don't find this a problem though, because as soon as you pour the water into a cup, even a pre-heated cup (using the hot water in t he pot), it always cools down three to five degrees (I tested this too!). So, it is the perfect temperature IF it is overheated in the pot. Finally, the beep. It beeps when it reaches temperature, but it is a very soft beep.... kind of like hearing a truck back up way down the street from you when you have all your windows closed. Easy not to notice if you are in another room. I'm good with that too, as I have excellent hearing, and if I miss the cue it automatically keeps the water warm for 30 minutes anyway. Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lid broke after less than a year
reviews.reviewText: Loved this kettle until it broke less than a year after purchase. The lid button no longer opens the kettle. Trying to pry the lid off only pulls the lid apart and breaks it further. Granted we used this kettle 3-4 times a day, but for this price it should last longer than a year!

I’ve had this for 5 years, and have used it several times every day.....only now has the lid started to malfunction. But I can still use it. Every few months I descale it with 1:1 vinegar solution. The only thing I don’t like is it’s hard to pick up when full, so I’m looking for one with the handle on top, but all those have bad reviews—rust spots and such. If this kettle is still made as well as it was 5 years ago, I’d highly recommend it, but how can you find that out, right?!

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality product, accurate temp, looks nice, heats water quickly for french press coffee
reviews.reviewText: I've been using this water heater daily for about a month or so. So far, I've been very happy with it's performance. Heats 1.25 L (french press size) to 200 degrees F in about 4-5 minutes, and seems pretty accurate although I haven't measured the temp independently. It automatically keeps any remaining water warm after you replace it on the base...a nice feature. Overall, the product is made of high-quality stainless steel and looks very nice. The buttons glow blue and I haven't had any issues with the text rubbing off like some other reviewers mentioned...however, I've been careful not to apply a lot of friction to the buttons with my thumb when pouring out the water. I';s also more quiet than many other water heaters I've seen over the years. Three semi-quiet beeps indicate when the water reaches the correct temp...not too loud, not too soft. I've never noticed any strange tastes. Very happy so far...I'll try to provide an update in 6-12 months.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hot water in seconds at several different temp readings...different likes, different needs...this is it.
reviews.reviewText:
After vacation in Europe I came back and bought my first electric teapot. Which meant I had to give them as gifts. My own eldest daughter bought this Cuisinart CPK-17 because it heats water at different temperatures. She loves her tea and hot chocolate also...so different temps for different drinks. For myself I heat water up quickly to get my pasta pot boiling. Water heats in a couple minutes in these electric teapots.
I bought this Cuisinart COK-17 for my son and his future wife as a gift.
My older daughter though warned against wearing off the temp numbers with cleaning...be genital...she and her husband have them memorized however...better to have readings that don't ware away.
Oh yeah...I bought the 3-yr warranty as part of this gift.

Does what its intended to do, heat water fast to various pre-set temperatures.
Have only had for a week or so, so can't talk about reliability.

Pros:
Attractive SS styling
Easily visible water level
Simple controls remember last setting
Appears to shut off before empty
No cord when pouring
Will work with half a pot so you can heat water fast for a quick cup or small pot
Quiet
So far no discoloration with moderately hard water
SS interior, no discernible flavor added.

Cons:
The audible alert is super quiet (at least for 60 year old ears) and volume is not adjustable
Very high pitch shut off sound
The time it will run is not adjustable, its either 30 minutes, or nothing.
I'd prefer one that would stay on until it was near dry, if asked to.
-- but it reheats water from near room temperature and higher very fast.
So far no reliability issues.
There is a little bit of plastic in direct contact with the water for the level indication.
Rather pricey for what it does, but a nice self-indulgence or gift

reviews.reviewTitle: Cuisinart warranty service needs to enter the 21st (or even the 20th) century
reviews.reviewText:
When this kettle works, it's great. The features are great. But an important part of a product is reliability, and when a product fails, whether the company stands behind the product and is easy to work with on replacement/repair is essential. On that count, Cuisinart fails big-time.

My kettle stopped working about 3 weeks ago. After pressing the START button, it would appear to be working for about a minute, would beep four times - not the three beeps you expect when it reaches temp - and then shut off (all lights go out). So, being well within the 3 yr. warranty, (and living in Calif., where we don't need to pay for shipping to return an item for warranty repair/replacement), I called the toll-free number in the instruction booklet.

After going through the regular script of "did you check this, did you do that?" we got around to returning my unit to them and getting a replacement sent to me. Well, the replacement is on "back-order"... Amazon and everywhere else has them in stock, but Cuisinart doesn't, and they can't tell me when they might be getting them back in stock. Okay. So we move on to returning the dead unit to them.

They wanted to issue a call tag for UPS to show up at my door at some random time on some random day (totally not going to work for me), so I asked instead to have a label emailed to me so I could drop it off at a UPS Store which is more convenient. Sure. They take down and we confirm all my info over the phone. I was told they "would send an email." Great. (No mention of how long it might take to get the email, but I'm assuming a few hours. This is 2014, after all.)

After 3 days, no email. I called again. They asked if I'd checked my spam folder. Yup, done it already, not there. They said they'd sent it, but would send it again. Waited 6 days this time. Still nothing.

Called again. Same routine. Still nothing.

Called this morning. Was told I should allow 3-5 business days for the email to go out... was told that previous reps had "lied to me" (exact words) about how long it might take to set up the service tag, send out emails, etc. That even 3-5 business days was a little too optimistic.

I told them I had gone through this several times already, and asked to speak to a manager... well, they put me on hold for several minutes and come back and inform me that's going to be impossible, the "the person who knows how to do that" has just stepped out. They're (supposedly) sending an email in 3-5 business days hence (saying it was impossible to put a rush on it or push it through whatever incredibly stupid system they've created).

So, here I am, waiting (as I have for the past 3 weeks) for them to do whatever it is that they do that takes 3-5 business days to send out an email, thinking that this time will be different. I know that fits the definition of insanity, but that's what happens when you deal with Cuisinart warranty service. They will drive you insane. And you're stuck with a broken appliance and very little hope of ever getting it replaced. And when it is replaced, after a few months, will I be faced with this frustration all over again?

So, yeah. One star ... it would be zero if that were possible.

UPDATE (6/18/2014): Just hours after submitting the above, UPS delivered the replacement. The replacement kettle that just this morning, when I was on the phone with Cuisinart customer service, was "still on back-order/out-of-stock". Astounding, the technological ineptitude which this company displays. They have no idea what's what going on or how to do the simplest "customer service" things. The replacement unit appears to be actually "new" but it does also appear to be less carefully made than its predecessor... comparing them side-by-side, there are a number of fairly rough/sharp spots on the inner part of the new handle (poor plastic molding or lack of finishing work), the new buttons look cheaper (almost like they're going to fall off), etc. I've fired it up and it appears to work okay. So, now, I'll wait a few days to see if they ever get around to sending me an email with a label for UPS, and make sure this replacement isn't a total dud. And then call. And then, when they start to inform me once again that the replacement is "still on back-order/out-of-stock", I'll correct them. Someday, I'll get a return label... maybe. And then they'll get their defective product back. At some point, however, I will give up on this process, as I've long ago given up on Cuisinart as a brand... because they've wasted much too much of my time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't hold up, the quality is not what you deserve for the price.
reviews.reviewText: I wanted to like this kettle, I really did., so much so that I have purchased two of them. But no more. They are sleek, modern looking and seem to do all the things a serious tea drinker wants in a kettle. Push button temperature controls, warming feature, easy to see water level. But the fact is, my first one died after a year of use. It was already looking a bit worn with the labels getting hard to read. I bought a replacement anyway, and after a year, the labels were almost gone. And, though it was still operating, the temperature regulation was next to worthless. I finally gave up the dream. I now own a Bonavita goose neck kettle. It isn't quite as slick, and the control panel looks like some sort of lab instrument, but it works like a dream and pours so well. For two years it has been warming my water to perfection to indulge my taste in tea. So long Cuisinart, You promised, but didn't deliver. I have found happiness elsewhere.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not reliable; going on my third unit under warranty.
reviews.reviewText: Bought this because of the Cuisinart name, stainless steel and apparent discount off retail price ($80 vs. $185), along with pretty decent reviews. It worked fine, even if it heated more slowly than I expected. [Having lived in Europe I've experienced $15 electric kettles boiling water twice as fast as this one.] So while not thrilled, I was content with this kettle because it did what it said it did -- until it didn't anymore. It lasted a year, and yes, I descale every couple of weeks with vinegar. I got warranty replacement, which cost $15 for shipping plus I needed to pay to ship the broken one back to them, and the second unit died after a year. Now I'm going on my third unit (at least they're not charging me for shipping this time, but I still need to pay to ship the broken one to them) and I don't expect it to last much longer than the remainder of the warranty, which is three years from the date of original purchase. Maybe I got a couple of lemons and the third one's the charm; I just think a kettle this pricey should last a minimum of five or ten years.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awesome Kettle-Works Like a Champ....and is going strong after five years!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this over six months ago and heat it up at least two times per day. It is fantasticl Not only can I choose my temperature, it will stay at that temp for another half hour if I'm not around to pour it. It is consistant and has many great features.

Addendum: I have now used this kettle for over a year and a half and it still works fantastically!! Still using it 2x or more per day. I drink many types of tea and love to make French-press coffee upon occasion too. The temperature selections are phenominal for multi-use. It has a window for easy measurment, looks high-tech with an elegant design, and its working quality and features are well worth the rather steep pricetag. I am very happy that I can choose to keep the water "cooking" for a half an hour (for when I'm busy or have company) or program it to immediately shut itself off. I used to have accidents using a stovetop teakettle, no more with this appliance. I couldn't be happier with it.

It is now five years since purchase and it's still going strong. My husband and I remain avid tea drinkers. We now use this 4 to 5 times per day, every day, for the last five years. It works so great that they should win a medal for design and durability. Like many others, the lettering on the most used buttons have worn off as you can see in the photos.

This is the best kettle I have owned so far. High quality materials and solid built. There is a lot of little details Cuisinart got right - from the way the lid opens, to the simple operations of the buttons, to the water meter lighting, and the way it beeps when it is done. The kettle seems have a good core that holds the temperature for far longer than other kettles. My previous kettle was a Bonavita (died after 2 years), and the build quality is nowhere near this PerfecTemp model. However, this model lacks granular control of temperature so may not appeal to the coffee/tea connoisseurs. I love tea, but Bonavita has been disappointing and I am making this compromise for a quality product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Solid performer and is able to keep up with Englishman's constant need for tea
reviews.reviewText:
I am English, and with that comes the insatiable need for hot tea. I needed a good kettle to replace my 10 year veteran kettle and figured I would try for something much more useful to me. I chose this kettle because of the variety of options for heat and the keep warm feature. I am mostly happy with it but there are a few things worth noting.

Pros
Love the temperature features
Easy of use
Good construction

Cons
Easy to burn yourself on (If refilling after recent use the lid is in the perfect position to drop hot water straight down the handle...the handle also guides thumbs of big hands towards the hot metal kettle too)
Keep warm keeps on keeping warm after you have used the kettle, wastes some $$$ on heating the kettle when you have got what you need from it
The kettle seems to catch on the base when replacing it, feels like that will cause a problem in the future.

I do recommend this kettle, just watch your hand when pouring (no brainer, but thumbs easily slip onto the kettle body), and when putting in water keep the kettle tipped forwards if you have recently used it to keep the hot water drips from the lid away from your hand.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... doesn't 'boil' water - it warms water to the perfect temperature (hence the name)
reviews.reviewText: This product doesn't 'boil' water - it warms water to the perfect temperature (hence the name)... This is an accurate description. My wife is a long-time and regular tea drinker who prefers her beverages quite hot. When we used a generic electric tea kettle, I couldn't drink tea for quite some time after steeping, often leaving me with harsh flavors or simply forgetting that I had tea and letting it cool to room temperature. This product allows you to bring water to the perfect temperature for your brewing your tea or coffee (there are six temperature choices)... and a large benefit of that is that green and herbal teas are brought to lower temperatures that optimize subtle flavors and let me drink these teas more quickly!

reviews.reviewTitle: They don’t stand by their product
reviews.reviewText: I loved loved loved this tea kettle until I couldn’t open the lid. I didn’t think it was worth the money to send it back their warranty stinks! BUT, I liked the kettle so much I bought another on Amazon I think about two years ago. Now I noticed there is water all over the counter when I use it. For supposedly a top of the line product it’s a piece of crap. Won’t buy another I do not recommend this product Cuisinart should be ashamed of themselves for their crappy warranty.

I had purchased a Breville for brewing loose tea, but I wanted a separate kettle for boiling water. The CPK-17 is a nice looking kettle, cordless, and has variable temperature settings. I was previously using a very old plastic kettle that took forever and made a mess when boiling. This kettle, while not as fast as I would like, does the job without spurting hot water everywhere. It also has a useful Keep Warm function and can boil up to 1.7 liters. I like using this kettle for bagged teas, French Press, matcha, and boiling water to sanitize my sinks. It pours nicely for the most part. I had some mess with pouring into my matcha cup, but I guess I'll have to try to pour it lower next time.

There is a tiny amount of scaling at the bottom of the pot. I haven't been using filtered water, but I think I'll start doing that from now on. The buttons light up in sci-fi blue and the heat will not start until the Start button is pressed. I like being able to see the water level and having many functions for various teas. This kettle is still fairly new, so if something changes, I will update this review. I have read reviews of the numbers fading off, so perhaps in the future, Cuisinart will consider making raised numbers. The settings are all in Fahrenheit, and there's obviously no way to set in Celsius, but this should not be a problem for most US buyers.

I had a Chef's Choice for the last 6 months and I am glad that it broke. This one comes close to the SAECO ( discontinued / went out of business ) we had for 3 years before that...not quiet as intuitive however. The basic Kettle's just boil the water and shut the heater off. This one goes into a "keep warm" mode after it reaches the target temperature. That makes a lot of sense. It takes a couple of days to figure out the buttons and in which sequence to push them to for example shut it completely off etc...but we are glad to have that functionality back in the kitchen. I read a lot of complaints about the Cuisinart not being reliable...will see..I will downgrade it if it lasts less than 1 year...

Update after a couple of weeks
We have had it for a couple of weeks now..it has a couple of flaws..you really dont know when it reached the target temperature the first time..it does a beep ( not very loud )..if you miss it you would not know ( it may change the "blinking" pattern or go from "blink" to "steady" )...especially if it is in the "keep warm" mode..that mode is the next issue...each button is backlid and the light shows whether it is activated..unfortunately the lights are so close together that you can't make out which button is on or off. For example , if the "Keep warm" button is on together with the " boil" button, you may think the "start" button is on as well. It may be off, in which case nothing happens until you realize the mistake..I still give it 4 star just because of the lack of any good alternative kettles..

Greatest invention ever! I'm a big tea drinker, and I love to drink many different fancy teas, green and oolong and regular black tea. This kettle is sooo easy it makes making the PERFECT cup of tea in matter of a couple minutes a breeze. I love the different temp settings, as you CANNOT boil water or overheat water for green and oolong tea otherwise you create a bitterness to the tea. From setting it to the exact tea temp and then time the tea for being in the water to 3 minutes you have yourself the ideal tea that tastes just as it should. The kettle heats fast and beeps when reaches temp, you can also keep it on a warm setting to keep your water warm for more cups. This is actually my second kettle as the first one shorted out or something, but I loved it so much I couldn't live without, so returning it was easy and it was replaced with no charge. This time I learned not to leave the kettle on when there is no water or very little water inside and I also try not to keep the heat setting on after I reached the temp desired, but either turn it off and unplug or set to the warm setting. If you don't do this the water will continue to come up to temperature and I'm not sure if that may have caused the issue I had with the first kettle. Also note the side of the kettle gets very hot and will burn your fingers so don't touch!

reviews.reviewTitle: Terrific Tea -- two years and counting
reviews.reviewText:
UPDATE: October 30, 2017

Well, almost exactly 5 years to the day I bought it, my Cuisinart electric tea kettle finally bit the dust. In the last couple of months, it seems to have been catching water in the base area, and then when I'd pour hot water into a mug, some water would leak out the bottom of the pitcher from the seam where the base meets the sidewall. I wasn't sure if it was from boiling over because I filled it too high, or if something had cracked on the inside where I couldn't see. Finally today, when I tried to get it to operate, it warmed slightly but then shut itself off and wouldn't boil the water. I am assuming that this is a protection mechanism probably to help me avoid a fire. Regardless, I was very happy with this product, I used it multiple times each day when I was home, and I enjoyed the multiple temperature options. I would periodically use a sharpie marker to indicate the temp gauges on the handle for guests who might use it because the printing had long ago worn off from simple use.

UPDATE: December 2014

I have been using this tea kettle for two years, several times (5?) each day, practically every day. It's shows no sign of burning out, and it still looks great. The printing has worn away from almost all of the buttons, but as I use this so often, I have all the temperature settings memorized. However, I can see that being something worth fixing going forward. (=

*******************

ORIGINAL REVIEW: As of this writing (June 2013), I have been using this tea kettle for 7 months, every day, several times a day, save for a few weeks away here and there. I drink tea all day long, and I work from home. I was a tad leery before making this purchase because some people had complained about the tea kettle burning out. Thus far, I have not had this issue at all.

I LOVE that I can set the relevant temperature for the tea I want to brew. Mostly I brew black teas in the morning, but I then switch to milder ones as the day turns later. It didn't take long for the "boil" (hottest) button to become illegible, which is about the only "bad" thing I have to say about this product. I'm not sure how I could have prevented the printing from wearing away from the most-used buttons, other than using some kind of plastic glove, but other than that, I am extremely pleased with this product.

I was initially intrigued about the "warm" button, which promised to keep the water at the proper temp for 30 minutes, which means that it will start heating it up again all by itself. I didn't actually like that, and so I now never have that function selected. I sometimes take longer than 30 minutes to drink a large cup, and when I go back, it's quick enough to simply reheat the water again anyway, so instead of wearing out the heating element, I'd rather just do that manually myself.

It's easy to clean, it looks sleek, I love the illuminated buttons, and it's a lot nicer than the several basic versions of electronic tea kettles I'd had in the past in Germany. I will never go back to a traditional tea pot on the stove. These are so much faster to heat up, and now with the precise temperature controls, it almost seems barbaric to think back to when I used one!

reviews.reviewTitle: "You aren't going to like this at first because it's something else that plugs ...
reviews.reviewText:
