reviews.reviewTitle: Great water heater: efficient, quick, and accurate.
reviews.reviewText: Great, so far. If it dies in the future I'll probably come back to tell everyone. I've had this unit for approximately three weeks now, and I use it to make 2.8 liters of tea, for iced tea, every morning. I let it steep in glass 1-liter carafes, and making it right after breakfast gives it time to slowly cool down naturally as well as suck all the benefit from one standard-sized tea bag per carafe. At lunch I have a liter plus a little and my wife has about .8 liter. For dinner I have another liter of tea, and mi esposa has water. That's in addition to the glass of wine we each have with dinner. I've been looking for something like this for a year, and I hadn't been impressed enough to even try anything I could find until now. There were either control issues or size issues that made the other kettles I'd considered unsuitable for my use. For years I've used my coffee maker to heat the tea water, and my coffee maker, one of the discontinued Braun models, is getting rather long in the tooth. I really like the coffee it makes, so I'm using the Cuisinart tea pot to absorb a great part of the workload. I heat the water for two of the carafes (1.8 liters total) together, and after I pour them from the pot into the first two carafes I immediately pour the third carafe containing the final liter of water into the Cuisinart pot. I don't have to do anything to restart it since it remembers what it was doing for about two minutes after it's removed from the base. Finally, after it finishes heating, and I've poured the hot water into the third carafe along with a tea bag, I set it back on the stand, it lights back up, and I hit the start button again to turn it off, and I'm done with it for the day. Very efficient operation. Since the tea we use is almost always black tea I normally use the highest or boil setting.

This thing boils water for tea, coffee, or even ramen very quickly. My favorite trick is to bring the water to a boil in this pot and then poor it into the pot to boil my ramen. Fastest ramen ever. My wife is a big tea and coffee drinker, so this thing is great for bringing the water to whatever temperature is appropriate.

As a lover of green tea, I always had a problem getting the water to just the right temperature. Ordinary tea pots heat to boiling which detracts from the tea's flavor. This unit heats fast and to the requested temperature.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love the varying temps & ease of use
reviews.reviewText: Love the varying temps & ease of use. It keeps the water at the temp I want for 30 minutes, so I can get things done before I pour.
Really enjoying my new kettle. It boils extremely fast and the feature that keeps the water at the desired temperature is very hlful

Love the look and the different temperature for different teas is very energy efficient. We drink a lot of green tea and the temperature is less than black tea and the tea was perfectly steeped. We hardly use the higher temperature for boiling. There is no funny taste. Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mine is great! No wearing off
reviews.reviewText: Who ever says the top wears off don't know what their talking 'bout! Or they don't know how to use the product.

I just started drinking tea about 6 months ago and I like different types of tea. It is so nice being able to just push a button to get the correct temperature for the tea I am brewing. My husband uses it for his french press coffee maker too.

I use this this alot. It does its job and does it fast. I wish one of its settings was 195 I've had alot of teas ask for that temp and its loud so im taking away a star but I really do like it! I wonder if someone makes one with a water filter that would be sweet!
Great product that does what it claims. My lady just loves making her drinks with this.

reviews.reviewTitle: Over 17 months and still going strong
reviews.reviewText: Have had this for over 17 months and I still love it. I've used every setting with great results. It could shut off earlier when boiling, but it DOES shut off in a reasonable amount of time. Somehow, that doesn't become a problem with lower settings. reviews.reviewTitle: Best decision: go electric instead of using the stovetop!!

I saw it when staying at a friend's house (an avid tea drinker) and thought, hey, I really need to up my antioxidant intake through green tea drinking so I ordered one. It's not perfect, but it's really good. The turning on/off takes some getting used to. The variable temp is great, as is the keep warm function. I haven't seen better than this anywhere...so go ahead, you won't regret it.
Started leaking after only 1 year of use. The most expensive kettle we had, that lasted the least amount of time. Very disappointing!

We ordered this after viewing most of the competing products. One of the features we love is the ability to set different temps. for different beverages. I use it for French Press coffee, my wife for black & green tea. Because of the different settings it is always at a perfect temp. Wish it had a alarm of some sort when it's finished.

I like my hot food hot. This kettle is attractive, quiet, and actually gets the water hot enough. I had another brand for years. When that one broke, I tried a few other kettles, but returned them because tbe tea was not hot enough for me. This kettle works and keeps your water hot if you want a second cup. Water is boiled quickly and quietly.

Every now and then something come along that is so simple and elegant in it's design that you just wonder why it didn't arrive sooner. I'll leave that answer to the philosophers. This thing works....perfectly. If you are a coffee or tea drinker, you'll love it. If you're not, well, your friends who are, will love it! Buy it. It works!

reviews.reviewTitle: He said it's great because it boil 1

My husband loves his tea and loves this product!

reviews.reviewTitle: great for making non bitter green tea- just like starbucks iced green tea!
reviews.reviewText: I love the starbucks iced green tea, but at 3 bux a pop its way over my budget... this little kettle makes the green tea just at the right temperature, so it tastes just like starbucks! Use 5 Zen Tazo teabags and brew with 1 liter water for 5 minutes or less...that makes your green tea concentrate! add water and ice to taste, and voila, you have starbucks iced green tea, sans waiting in line!!

I bought two. One died after a year. The other died after 2 years. I loved them, but they just died. I will probably buy them again, as I really want my water cooked in stainless steel and not aluminum. But, the life time is very disappointing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Scolding hot to touch, broke after a year
reviews.reviewText: Had this unit for 13 months before it stopped working. Worse kettle I've ever owned and I've owned a few. It's not insulated, so it gets scolding hot on the sides -- read: dangerous. I burnt myself more than once. Different settings are 'fun' but we never changed them as, well, we just wanted boiled water. Over priced.

I love the variable temperatures and the "keep warm" feature. The lid gets a little in the way when filling it from my water filter in the refrigerator and watch your fingers because the kettle gets very hot, there's no insulation. Overall I'd highly recommend this item!

reviews.reviewTitle: Best electronic kettle I have used
reviews.reviewText: Bought this for my dad who make tea every day and he absolutely love it. The kettle heats up water fast ( 4-5 minutes faster than the traditional kettle over stove top ). The preset temperature is amazing, for making hot ( but not boiling hot) water, or brew any of 6 preset tea type ( personally only used setting for green and black tea so far). Overall a great product, highly recommend for anyone want an electronic kettle that heat up water fast and have control over the temperature.

this thing rocks! not only it looks cool, but it allows me to prepare different teas and even keep the water warm for up to 30 min.

the only disadvantage is that the metal gets very hot and you can't touch the side of it (unlike plastic made devices)

This electric kettle is awesome... Heats up fast, color display is readable and clear. Before getting this kettle I am aware that I was burning my green tea. What a taste difference when water is at the right temp. Do yourself a favor invest so you can drink your tea at the Correct temp.
My son even uses it when he is making noodles, quick, simple, easy...

reviews.reviewTitle: Leaking and dead after 4 months of use

It all breaks anyway, so may as well go for something considerably cheaper and expect it to break in a few months anyway. Really too bad. Very disappointed.

The design of this electric tea kettle is simply excellent! My hats go off to the engineers and product designers who conceived of this design! They've pretty much thought of everything! Major pluses are - it lets you heat up about seven cups of water in under 2 minutes and to the correct temperature, also keeps your water warm for you. My family owns two of these electric kettles and I highly recommend it! With free shipping this item arrived in 3 days, to Alaska no less! Thank you Amazon!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product, probably a bit too pricey
reviews.reviewText:
Pros:
Well constructed

Expensive.

I have found that if the water has to be above 190 I have to revert to the good old stovetop. This is a very good product. It works very well. I am still amazed how fast it boil water. It is well made and I like it a lot. It is just what I wanted.

Like the styling of this but all the temperature buttons have lost their markings. Just wiping it down with a damp paper towel takes off some of the writing. Now can't tell what button is what temperature. Heats very quickly and is a good unit otherwise.

Accurate and has lasted a year so far without fail!

I am a TEAVANA guru!! I love their tea but could not afford their super high priced kettle thingie.. This kettle is a perfect option. It has great pre-sets that are perfect for getting the water to the exact temp at which to steep my tea... I am loving it!
good product

reviews.reviewTitle: Great concept, but fails on numerous fronts
reviews.reviewText:
Save your money. The idea behind this kettle is perfect, if only it did what it was supposed to. When I am able to get a cup of hot water I am a happy camper, but my issues with this kettle are as follows:
* When I fill the kettle, with 1L of water, and immediately set it on to the base for heating, I get a constant beep. After filling the kettle I have to set it on the counter and wait 3 minutes before the base will receive the canister.
* The water goes cold VERY quickly. There is a button allowing option to keep the water warm, but it keeps it tepid at best. If you're hoping to top up your tea or coffee you will be sorely disappointed with the temperature.
* More often than not I am unable to heat the water without setting the kettle down for 3 minutes to reset. I never overfill, so I'm not sure what the problem is, but if you have guests, or are trying to make coffee in a rush this is extremely frustrating.

* What I DO like about this kettle is that WHEN it works it heats the water quickly. With my old kettle I had to wait 4-5 minutes for the water to boil. This boils much faster, but I'd say overall I spend much more time trying to get this kettle to work properly. Between trying to reset the kettle and the actual boiling time it can take more closer to 6 minutes to make a cup of coffee, if I'm lucky.

The concept is great, but it's not without serious glitches. If you're hoping for a good cup of coffee I'd stick to a simpler design.

Importantly, the kettle is almost impossible to turn off! Even if you turn it off prior to pouring, it will turn-on again the minute you place it back on the heating element, and overheat. If you don't turn it off again by clicking twice, lights will flash. Watch out! Then, the only way you can turn off the demented, overheated thing is fill it with water, turn it on, then turn it off with repeated clicks. Or unplug it. And fill it with water to cool it off. I strongly suggest that for safety, unplug it after every use! If you don't, and it inadvertently gets bumped, even a little bit, it can come back on by itself when empty. Silly, silly design changes. The pour spout doesn't even work as well. We'll see if this works for five years, like the last one did. reviews.reviewTitle: Dangerous, impossible to empty, but handy for childless lovers of fine tea
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this kettle for 9 months. It's my go-to kettle for tea because I love having several options of temperatures, and I love the keep-warm feature which allows me to easily brew several small infusions of tea over 30 minutes (or more). Also it's very quick to come to temp, and I like the audible alert when the water's ready. BUT:

This kettle is dangerous. I can't believe this isn't mentioned in every single review. This kettle is a single-walled, stainless steel design. Stainless steel is a fantastic thermal conductor. If the water inside the single stainless steel wall is 212 degrees, what temperature do you think the outside of the stainless steel wall is? About 212 degrees. I'm serious. Do not touch the walls of this thing while water is boiling in it! Or even near boiling in it. How did this get approved for sale in the US? Do not let your kids anywhere near this while you're using it! I don't have kids and I know not to touch it when it's operating (guess how I know!), so this is okay with me since holding it by the handle is perfectly comfortable. But really, I'm stunned that it's allowed on the market.

Also, the last ounce or two of water does not pour out cleanly, and you simply cannot completely drain the kettle. This is due to the plastic clip that is bolted over the pour spout on the interior. The clip holds the filter, which is meant to keep flakes from hard water build up from ending up in your cup. But whether or not you use the filter (I don't), that clip interferes with the stream of water in such a way that the last ounce or two of water pours out not in one coherent stream but in 3-5 separate trickles, one of which drips down from above the spout! And the last tablespoon or two of water simply will not come out no matter how you hold / jiggle / shake the pot. Very annoying.

Despite those two design flaws, one of which is IMO very serious, I still use it because it's the only option I've found that lets me quickly bring a small volume of water (less than 1/2 liter) to any of several different temps and hold it there for 30 minutes (or more if you hit Start again). But if there was a comparably priced alternative without these two major flaws, I'd buy that one instead.

Update (4/22, 4 years later):
-------------------------------------
It's actually holding up quite well after four years of daily use comprised of heating up water for my siphon coffee pot and nightly sleep teas. The numbers have pretty much rubbed off the prefixed temperature buttons but after years of routine I just push the same buttons and haven't noticed. I can always refer to the images here if I need a reminder for lapse in memory. Also, I never use it to boil water for coffee and teas as that negatively impacts the taste of my coffees and teas.

The kettle is as beautiful and stylish as the day I got it. There's a tiny bit of lime scale at the bottom of the kettle as a result of not routinely rinsing it with a lime scale remover. Think I ran vinegar through it only once. I highly recommend this kettle. Rating upgraded from four to five stars as a result of it's longevity and quality.

Original review:
-----------------------
I'll have to follow up with a follow up review. A couple of points:

* Not as heavy as I had imagined based on the reviews (male in my late 30s)
* Initially a little concerned about the buttons on the kettle itself which might get wet from washing. Curious if any of the failures people are reporting have anything to do with this part getting wet. I'll pay cautious attention to this.
* Heats up really fast and beats having to watching my old tea pot in getting the right temperature for green tea. Think I've almost burn myself a few times popping open the lids to gauge temperature.
* Operates at 1500 watts. I would have settled for 1000 but wouldn't get the quick heat up.
* Plastic / poly-blah-blah-blah parts. None of the pictures show exactly where the plastic parts are. The product video barely flashes the internal of the kettle to disclose how much of it is plastic. None of the other kettles seem to show the internals as well. This is a sticking point and I hope by next year they will have come up with a better engineering design to eliminate the need for any plastic parts. As it stands today all of the variable temperature kettle at least use some plastics for sealing the lid for a better seal.

All in all I'm satisfied with the purchase. I went through several options to the Pino, Chef's Choice, Breville, and Adagio. The Pino doesn't seem to be well built with the cheap looking digital readout along with complaints of rusting (that's unacceptable). Chef's Choice didn't offer anything over the Cuisinart with it's bigger price tag (still has the plastic water gauge but looks to come in direct contact with the water). I'm not sure if the Breville is bpa free or not. Either way, I don't care for the design where the water gauge is part of the water container. With the Cusinart the water is separated from the water gauge somewhat and the exposure is reduced. The way the water gauge works is that there's a tube in the bottom that moves the gauge up through water pressure. Adagio is coming out with a new kettle but that's not for a few months and their previous kettle had issues. Lots of consumers seem to have had issues with their previous model (as they noted on their web site even). The new kettle from Adagio looks pretty attractive from the web pictures however.

With all that in mind, the round up choice is this Cuisinart. Let's see how it holds up. For those curious I'll be posting photos of the internals of the kettle so you know exactly where the plastic parts are. I removed the plastic screen filter so that won't be shown.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great kettle functionality - but has serious design flaws (some dangerous!!)
reviews.reviewText:
We've had this kettle 2 days now and it definitely is superb with regard to heating water to the best temp for the kind of tea you drink. In fact, I can honestly say now that green and white teas are definitely wonderful when brewed at the proper temp - I never would have guessed. However, I have yet to figure out what they mean by "delicate teas"??

Meanwhile, here are the design flaws that bug me and my husband:
* The outsides of the kettle get super hot and you can really burn yourself seriously if you accidentally touch the sides once the kettle has boiled. The handle, of course, is fine, but it is easy to brush against the sides of the kettle with your hand.
* Another problem with the kettle is the lid for the top opening: if you have boiled water, the lid gets hot like the outer sides of the kettle. This poses a problem if you have run out of water and need to refill -- you pop open the lid with the "open" button, fill the kettle, then you have to use your hand to push the lid closed. BUT... the lid may still be hot from the recent boil and you can actually burn your fingertips slightly!!
* I find the kettle is weighted poorly when filled with more than 1.25L of water and it can be very difficult to pour - a dangerous problem when pouring hot water.
* I personally find the opening at the top of the kettle is a bit too small. I filter my water and fill the kettle from the filter pitcher instead of the faucet. I find the kettle opening is too small to easily pour into from the pitcher, causing water to spill outside the kettle and onto the base (which is not a good idea). I am learning to stop and take careful aim with the pitcher when I fill the kettle - a really annoying inconvenience.
* The beeps that sound when the water is ready are very low in volume and barely audible, even if you are standing right next to the counter.

So, beware of these problems, esp. the first three items that I noted. As I indicated in the title, the kettle functionality is excellent and I am now getting to enjoy certain teas more than ever. As we have only 2 adults in our household, we can deal with the dangerous problems, but you need to decide if you want to introduce that into your home.

For example, my first use: hit the temp I want. It should have started, but it looks like it hasn't - heh, "Start" is unlit, press that; hey - now the temp is flashing, wtf? looks urgent, I have to press something... Hit the temp again... nothing changes. Oh, perhaps it just flashes like that in that urgent looking manner for no reason... Well, not too painful. Wait, I've finished with it, how do I make it stop...? What?, I really have to manually turn the thing off every time?

This is all in the manual and not too obscure, but really, how much should I need a manual? How confused should a guest in my house be by /an electric kettle/?

At this price I expect someone to do a quality design of the controls, not just the aesthetics. I do like the kettle and I'm feeling generous so I'm giving it a 4, rather than a 3, but it's a close thing.

Review Edit: definitely dropping this to 3 stars, might contemplate 2. My wife and I, who are pretty tech-savvy, get caught out by the silly interface for this frequently - both intending to turn it on and failing, and failing to turn it off when we're finished with it. Added to that, and it's increasingly failing to shut off from the boil setting in a timely manner. I think it still shuts off, but takes a couple of minutes of boiling. Overall, it's a nice looking product, but the user experience was not designed properly at all, and the performance is questionable.

What can I say? Thought these were utterly frivolous until I got my own. Now I feel ashamed for how long I spent scoffing at these marvels of human engineering. We have a french press and making coffee was always a pain in the butt, until now. The coffee tastes way better, probably because it's actually being brewed at the correct temperature.

I am not even remotely a tea snob. I always just microwaved my tea. Heresy, I know. I didn't know there were different optimal temperatures for different kinds. I'm still not sure it makes a difference. (Like I said, heresy.) But I don't care because this is so much easier than heating two mugs in the microwave for 5 min each.

Anyways, get this, it's super rad and you'll be glad. Rhyme unintended.

My CPK-17 started leaking when filled with more than a liter of water after less than a year of use. I contacted Cuisinart who said that they would replace it if I paid to ship it back to them *plus* $15 to cover shipping me a new one. So, $30 dollars (more than a third of the item's cost) to get a replacement for an item that failed due to bad manufacturing or design. I'll just buy another brand instead.

Avoid Cuisinart--their warranty replacement policies are out of date compared with other manufacturers.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great kettle, but the button ink wears off after about a year
reviews.reviewText:
I wish I could give this product 5 stars, because I do love it and it works perfectly. HOWEVER after about a year of use the buttons that we use the most have had their ink worn off, so the buttons are just plain.
Your kettle will continue to work as always, but hopefully you've memorized what all the buttons are!

reviews.reviewTitle: Buyer Beware, Looks Good, Very Short Lifespan
reviews.reviewText: My wife and I originally loved this Kettle. It's a nice modern design and originally, it worked as advertised. We liked it so much that we bought my parents one as a gift too. A little more than one month after my parents received their kettle, it just stopped working. Luckily Amazon was good enough to take it back even though it was after the 30 day period. A few months have gone by since my parents Cuisinart Electric Kettle stopped working, and ours stopped working too!? I could understand if one of these kettles was defective BUT both of them? That is unacceptable. In addition to both of these not working within a short time of buying them, they both had issues with the tops getting stuck and rust starting to form on the insides. After our experience with this CuisinartCuisinart CPK-17 PerfecTemp 1.7-Liter Stainless Steel Cordless Electric Kettle Electric Kettle, I can not recommend this product nor will I buy other Cuisinart products. Do yourself a favor and read the 1, 2 and 3 star reviews. I originally ignored them but after my first hand experience, I realize they are unfortunately true. I'm not sure why Amazon isn't showing my review as "Amazon Verified" but I purchased this item on Amazon.

reviews.reviewTitle: Six Months and an Average Use of 10 Times a Day later...
reviews.reviewText:
I am quite sure we use this kettle to make tea much more than the average American household, as I am from China, and my boyfriend is from Southern England. So when we moved in together six months ago, we knew we needed a kettle that can take our daily use and abuse. As it turned out, between the two of us, we use this kettle to boil water on an average 10 times a day (we also go through 600+ tea bags a month), and it's still going strong, working well as ever.

As for the negatives, and they are really not a big deal:

1. The lid only springs open half way, and one has to manually push the lid to open completely. We got too lazy to do it, and just started refilling water through the spout.

2. The water level is hard to read as it is, like so many kettles, located right behind the handle. In order to read the water level, one has to bend over, or tilt the kettle, which causes the accidental touch of the buttons and changes the temperature setting.

Other than the very minor inconvenience, we really like this kettle and how hard it has been working for us.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after 3 years, Customer service useless
reviews.reviewText:
Started leaking all the water out the bottom a little after the warantee expired.

The agent Amanda said after 20 minutes that she couldn’t help me because “millions” of things could have caused this problem. She had no knowledge of this model, of other reports about issues of leaking after only owning it for a few years. She let me know that warranties are only 3 years. This kettle lasted me way less than a cheap plastic kettle did which I used for 6 years. Then she asked me to keep buying from the company with a 20% off coupon. We all know that they make a 90-70% profit so they still asking for me to buy a product that will only last for 3 years, creating more electronic waste.

(note: I didn't buy it on Amazon)

I wondered
"Who needs an electric kettle ? Just use the stove! " .
But now I am a convert !
1. Safer and more convenient than the stovetop.
Set it and forget it. Perfectly safe to leave it unattended if you wander outside do some gardening, laundry etc; no worries about boiling the kettle dry on the stove top and creating a hazard. Plus it has automatic shut off after 30 minutes.
2. Absolutely love the preset temperatures much more than I expected to.
3. Timing. Faster than the stove. Possibly saving on power bills over the long run.
My husband heated a .50 litre of room-temp bottle water to 175°f in the kettle in
2 min 54 sec. The same volume of water on the stove(using a thin-walled, wide volume pot with a tight fitting lid), was only about a hundred and fifty degrees after three minutes.
4. Fit, finish, and function all seem smooth and good quality. Power cord is an appropriate length, heavy-duty quality yet flexible & has a three-prong plug.
5. Minus -1 star because damn this thing is heavy when it's full. Could possibly be easier to lift and carry if the handle was positioned a little bit lower? Of course that's not really possible with the design and engineering.
Outer surface is very very warm to the touch. Don't leave any plastic or meltables near by.

Yes i recommend this kettle !

P.s. would love to have a wake up feature so the kettle turns on at a ⏰ predetermined time.

Received as a Christmas present in Dec 2013. 6 months later the top of the kettle flew off when the kettle was opened. Inside are 2 pieces that latch the lid and a spring. The spring and latch pieces saw their opening and ran for freedom. I managed to catch them and reassemble the opening mechanism and snap the top on. I thought - problem solved. But no, the top now routinely comes off and I am tired of reassembling my kettle top. And if the top is not on either the kettle will not open, or it will not close. The gift giver bought Cuisinart on their reputation, but all their products are now very cheaply made in China, so beware. The amazing number of problems and bad reviews you see also says that Cuisinart people are not doing any quality assurance on their products - something the earlier management was absolutely religious about. Current management is just raking in the bucks based on the old reputation. You may get something that works, but then again, you may get a piece of overpriced junk. And Cuisinart is very happy to replace items under their 1 year warranty - if you pay the freight each way. This is my second Cuisinart product to die in less than 6 months. Yet my Cuisinart food processor is 14 years old and still working great.

reviews.reviewTitle: Would buy again. Good for teas, instant coffee, and hot water for recipes and instant hot cereals.
reviews.reviewText: I did not purchase my electric kettle from Amazon, but that was happenstance. I bought this kettle locally more than 5 years ago, when I was shopping for another item. Although it is still working perfectly, I will buy the same model again as either a gift or replacement. The lettering has worn on the butttons that receive the most use, but I consider that a fair trade off for the lack of little cap covers or other design details that would more likely collect residue from frequent use. My family uses the kettle multiple times daily. Although our water has considerable scale, the kettle has relatively little build up. This kettle replaced another brand that malfunctioned within its first year.

I picked one of these up at Walmart when I was getting some stuff for college. Didn't even think to look on Amazon, but that's beside the point. What really matters is this wonderful kettle.
I use it almost daily with my AeroPress for coffee and I've found that the different temperature settings are perfect for this. It makes a bit of noise as it boils, but compared to some kettles my friends have, it's downright quiet! I like the beep at the end of the heating cycle which lets you know it is done. It also keeps warm incredibly well, which is great if you are making multiple warm beverages.
From what I can tell, the temperatures are fairly consistent between runs. I don't have anything to measure this, but as far as the taste of the coffee I use it for, it's pretty consistent where too much variance in temperature can affect the flavor.
It also is quicker than a microwave/measuring cup combo. It takes longer to boil a cup of water in the microwave than it takes to boil 1/2 L (~2 1/8 cups) in the kettle.
I know this is a feature on a lot of kettles, but the power base that you can take the kettle off of to pour is a nice feature. I had friends over for a Christmas party and we were all making hot chocolate with our own mixes we got at the store and I heated a liter of water and poured it in everyone's cups and didn't have to worry about a cord or anything like that. It's these little things that make a product feel nice.
My friend with a plastic kettle said that if she ever gets a bonus at work or works overtime for something, she'd get one of these in a heartbeat.

Cuisinart kettle- you had one purpose. To heat up water.
This little kettle looks the part with its sleek stainless steel outer, lined with pretty blue lit buttons on all the many temperature options you can set it at. That would be lovely- if only anything happened once you press the blue button and then ‘start’.
Nothing.
The pretty blue light will stay on, almost as if taunting you into believing somethings happening. After 5 min of waiting and false hopes- it lets out a squeal that won’t stop unless you unplug it.
Thanks cuisinart. I’m back to heating up water in the microwave.

reviews.reviewTitle: Determine country items are manufactured if you can
reviews.reviewText: made in China.say no more!

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent electric kettle for all water temperatures
reviews.reviewText: My husband bought me this as a birthday gift in 2011 because I like tea. We have used it daily ever since. This makes brewing all kinds of tea simple because the water is just the right temperature. The kettle stops at the temperature, beeps and after a while reheats it to the same point if you do not get to it right away. Prior to this, we had an electric kettle that only heated to boiling. Getting water for white, green or oolong was a manual process. It's nice there's a 200F french press setting as well. I'm very happy with this product!

reviews.reviewTitle: DO NOT BUY THIS KETTLE - Look elsewhere
reviews.reviewText:
Received as a gift via our wedding registry. Bottom line, do NOT buy this kettle. We liked the features and that it has that stainless steel look but in the end, more trouble than it's worth.

My wife is from England so this is used a couple times a day every day. First one broke after several months of use - just wouldn't turn on. I took it apart and had a look but couldn't figure it out. Contacted customer service and like at least one other reviewer has posted, I had to pay for shipping both ways to have it serviced! They sent me a replacement up front, which is appreciated, but I was asked to send mind back for the to research and I had to pay for that plus was asked to enclose a $15 check to pay for shipping the new one. My wife was ticked but I figured we'd pay more than that for a new one anyway so OK.

Fast forward a couple of months, the replacement has a limp lid that no longer opens when we push the button. I figured out a spring on one side fell off it's place but you can't put it back. And just now, less than 1 year later, the thing is leaking.

My advice is to look elsewhere, especially at this price. A tea kettle is a simple device - it has to hold water and boil it. I appreciate the added features but don't bother if you can't get the basics down. This thing may say Cuisinart on it but it's garbage. This is the kind of product that degrades a brand faster than you can build it. AVOID.

I don't like the quality, it has been leaking and cannot contact technical customer service because it's over warranty?!! I need to get a new one, another brand, of course. Worst my time reading reviews from a famous website that mentioned they actually use it! Did they use it more than 1 month? I don't think so.

Sigh..

reviews.reviewTitle: The perfect tea pot for tea lovers!
reviews.reviewText:
Of all of the appliances we received for our wedding three years ago, I guarantee you this gets the most use. This is truly a great tea kettle for anyone, but if you're a true tea enthusiest, this really raises the bar.

Pros:
Stainless steel keeps clean with little to no maintenance.
Temperature controls let you get just the right temperature for the type of tea or coffee you're making, and of course, there's a boil feature for anything you'd need boiling water for. I've even used this to keep water hot for when I'm taking a bath and I want to spike it with hot water :-)
This is quick. Super quick. Only fill it for how much you need. It's rare that I fill this all the way full as it's not every day I'm entertaining a group of tea drinkers.
The keep warm feature will turn the kettle back on and keep your water at your perfect temp for up to half an hour.
I like that you can fill this by either flipping open the lid, or just filling it through the spout which is typically what I end up doing from my PUR faucet filter.
It's fairly quiet. No annoying whistle when you're water is boiling, just a quick beep.
You have the option of unselecting the "keep warm" button so if you're going for single serve, it'll just cut off when you return it to the base.
Cordless kettle, so you can have it on its base close to a plug and carry the kettle itself wherever.
Fairly large capacity lets you boil up to 1.7 L which can be useful if you're using this for things other than making a drink.
I've had mine for 3 years with daily use and none of the writing has worn off as some other reviews have said.
Water gauge on the outside of the kettle lets you see how much water you have.

Cons:
The default is for the "keep warm" option, which I rarely use. Took me a bit to figure out what combination of buttons would let me just warm up water and then have it cut off.
The blue light on the water gauge is quite bright and lights up when you return it to the stand. Stays lit for a while. It's just bright.
Water gauge sometimes has to be shaken around a bit to get an accurate reading.
Cord on base is short, so you need to be near a plug.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great teapot but started leaking in a bit over a year
reviews.reviewText: I liked it overall. The ability to select temperature (I didn't test how precise it is) is great. "Keep it warm" feature is great too, suitable when you don't want to get up from the table the moment it boils. The only disappointment was ~18 months after we got it when it started to leak, at first just a little but leak progresses over time. I might actually buy another one like it because we liked how practical it is.

We used to use a 4 L water heater on our countertop. We gave it to a friend. Instead, we bought this one. It is more convenient to use. You heat it when you need water. Washing is much easier because this unit is much smaller to handle.

I really hate it in one aspect. The temperature button labels wore off quickly. If you use it often, your favorite button will have no label in one month! I really hate this. Did they actually test the product because they started selling it? The labels should be etched. Several months after using it. All labels are completely gone. Brain-dead design!

I received this as a work anniversary gift.

The kettle works as advertised. It heats a large amount of water quickly and efficiently at the selected temperature. I found that I can fill the kettle beyond the 1.7L capacity and not have the water bubble over through the spout. That's nice if you want to fill up extra and reduce the amount of fill-ups you need during the day. The see-through window for the water is very convenient and reliable. I find that the blue glow makes for a good night light if you happen to wake up early and need a soft glow to illuminate your kitchen or other surroundings. Odd, but nice. The stainless steel finish is clean and neat. There aren't any unsightly weld marks. The steel does tend to attract stains from fingerprints. I am careful to wipe down the surface before heating the water. Otherwise, the oils will be permanently stained into the steel.

One big black mark against the kettle is its ergonomics. The handle is very uncomfortable to use for lifting the kettle and pouring. There is too much curvature for my hand to grip it securely. I would have preferred a flat grip surrounded by curves. My guess is that the product designers looked at the kettle when it was empty or only lightly loaded with water and they don't use the kettle multiple times during the day.

I have no doubt the kettle will work for a long time. However, when it breaks then it will have to be thrown away. It's electronically, vs. mechanically, controlled. I don't think I would buy this model if it were my own money vs. corporate money. My #1 CTQ would be a better handle. I would be willing to give up capacity and temperature control if required.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fast water heating, and yes the numbers and letters rub off
reviews.reviewText:
Although I buy lots of stuff on Amazon, and reading reviews for this and the Kitchenaid, I had to go into a real store since I wanted to compare them side by side, and with the 20% off coupon, was a little cheaper at the store. I like french press coffee and this one heats up to the recommended 200 degrees, whereas the Kitchenaid settings are either 190 or 195 or 212 degrees. Minor difference but what the hell. As for the markings coming off, decided to put some clear nail polish over each, and amazingly, if I pressed down too hard while doing it, the number started to disappear, so if you want to try it, a light touch is useful. Have no idea if it will last, but thought it worth a try. Don't know why they don't have the numbers and words etched into the tabs, that's still be visible after the ink wears off.

As for the beeping, I don't think it's bad at all, not loud, it's kind of like a soft sounding beep on a digital alarm clock. It does heat up the water quickly, so am looking forward to many cups of good coffee. Have to say it was not encouraging while reading the instruction manual to read that Cuisinart suggests holding onto the packaging in case it's needed at some point!

This kettle brings 1.7 Liter of cold water to roaring boil in 7 minutes. Half kettle full of water takes half the time to boil. I bought mine from local BBB. I was initially interested in purchasing the Breville BKE820XL Variable-Temperature 1.8-Liter Kettle but luckily it was out of stock and so I settled for the Cuisinart and I am glad that I did.

The key differences between this kettle and the Breville model are: the Breville has the controls on the all-stainless steel base while the Cuisnart has them on the handle. The Cuisinart base has some plastic that make it look a bit fragile and cheap. Breville has 1.8L capacity while Cuisinart has 1.7L. Breville has some polycarbonate on the water window while the Cuisinart has none. Breville costs $30 more than the Cuisinart. Breville sets oolong preset at 195 degrees F while Cuisinart has it fixed at 190. Finally and the main reason I settled for the Cuisinart- Breville has one year limited factory warranty while Cuisinart has three full years!

I debated whether to duck one star for a couple minor issues but decided to let it slide. First the cheap plastic containing base (should have been all stainless steel like the Breville). Second the beep is barely audible. It is supposed to beep three times to alert you when the set temp is reached. While it chimes three times, the room has to be dead silent for you to hear it. It should have been louder.

NB: The body gets and stays hot: If you grab or bump into it anywhere other than the handle you will get burnt.
NB: If you drink mainly Herbal Teas like I do you should be aware that the setting for Herbal Tea is same as the French Press (200 degrees F). Also remember that if you do not want the kettle to hold the temp for 30 minutes you should either push the keep warm button before or during the heating cycle or simply push the start button after the desired temp is reached to turn off the unit.

Overall this is a great looking Kettle that does what it is built to do pretty well. Highly recommended.

reviews.reviewTitle: Attractive and functional unit, recommend for those who enjoy loose tea or aspire to
reviews.reviewText:
I've owned this kettle for 2 years now and am satisfied with it. I would recommend this product to anyone who is looking for a hot water kettle steps and steps above the cheapie $20 plastic ones, which I liked anyway and owned before. I have considered buying this kettle as a gift for others and certainly miss it when away from home for its convenience and utility. One tip - Bed Bath & Beyond sells this unit at retail price of $100 - with a 20% off coupon - it is $80. Keep this in mind if the price here is above that and you have a BB&B nearby.

The best feature of this kettle, and the reason I bought it, is the different temperature settings. I enjoy loose leaf tea, and without a machine to heat water to specific temp for optimal brewing, I wouldn't bother with loose teas. I haven't measured the accuracy of each temperature, though I'm sure if you scroll through the reviews you will find someone has, and my tea comes out well, and I have not noticed any blatant discrepancies. I also enjoy using this kettle to boil water for cooking to expedite waiting for water to boil on the stove.

I like that this unit has a keep warm feature which if you enjoy several cups of tea and prefer not to wait to heat the water again, using this setting it will keep the water at your selected temp. You can just as easily turn this feature off after reaching your desired temp. When water has reached the desired temp, it will beep. The beep is a reasonable volume.

The stainless outside is very sleek looking, but it does catch stains easy, like stainless steel does, and needs occasional wiping to keep it looking clean. The unit overall is very sturdy and beefy, and I never feel it wobble when opening the lid to add water, or when pouring the water out. The lid opens with a button release, it is not a concern the lid will pop open while pouring hot water.

I have noticed that there is some mineral build-up inside from using tap water. I've boiled vinegar to see if it would loosen it without avail. If anyone else has figured out a trick, I'd like to hear it. Anyway, the build-up is a minor flaw, attributed to my tap water.

The length of the cord is sufficient for my kitchen. This kettle stays out and is very near the outlet. and even so there is cord left. If outlets and counter space is a concern for you, don't forget to double check the technical specs of the cord length.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works well while it lasts. But it doesn’t last.
reviews.reviewText: This kettle works well, there is no doubt about that. But it just doesn’t last long. We bought our first one about two years ago and loved it. There is a reason it gets the best reviews over and over on the consumer sites. Then, after about 16 months, it started leaking. Cuisinart customer service was responsive and sent us a new one. Great. However, then also requested we send back our old one (not cheap to mail) and pay them for shipping the new one. That is questionable service, as has already been mentioned in other reviews. Now, less than six months later, our new one made some funny noises and stopped working. This is extremely wasteful. Our first kettle had just a boil function and lasted about 8 years. Are all programmable kettles disposable items? This one seems to be. The consumer sites only test items for function, not durability. My experience says beware because this one is not durable.

reviews.reviewTitle: Absolutely in love with this kettle.
reviews.reviewText: I got this tea kettle for Christmas from my boyfriend's family. It is probably one of my most treasured things now. It heats up the water AMAZINGLY quick, and there's just one beep when it's done, so not super obnoxious for very long. My problem with normal kettles was how long they took to warm up because the noise of it starting to boil would drive me insane- so I love that it's usually less than a minute (even to boiling) before I have my water. ALSO, the feature that keeps it warm is so awesome because I generally forget about my water for a while after its boiled because I'm off doing other things. I pretty much use this everyday now and I'm in love with it. I love the tempature buttons and the light just gives it a very fancy "futuristic" feel. Can't rave enough about it! Oh, and after giving me mine for Christmas- my bf's family actually bought one of their own! Lol! Now if that hasn't sold you, I don't know what will!

reviews.reviewTitle: Numbers wear off quickly; lid jams. Still heats water ok though...
reviews.reviewText:
This kettle does an excellent job heating water very quickly. The temperature pre-sets are quite accurate. The kettle also looks very nice and is well constructed. Here's my one beef with this product (and the reason it gets 3 instead of 5 stars)-the temp numbers on the buttons begin to wear off with regular use. In less than one year of regular use two of them completely disappeared. After over a year and half of heavy use ALL TEMP NUMBERS ARE NOW WORN AWAY!!! Even the temps I rarely or never use are gone because of my thumb over-lapping the button I was pressing onto the other ones!! ARRRGH! This so very aggravating. I know what the settings are because they are the ones I use most often, however for a kettle with a list price of $185.00 (I paid $80.00) THIS SHOULD NOT BE HAPPENING! Other than that it works perfectly.

--UPDATE 12-8-2015-- The lid has now jammed forcing me to pry it open each time with a butter knife. Between this and the numbers wearing off I reduce my review to 2 stars--can not recommend and would not purchase again. At this price point I expect far better build quality.

My trusty electric kettle died after about 4-5 years of daily use. I had no quarrels with it and was sorry to see it go. But decided to try another brand and chose Cuisinart CPK-17 because I liked the many features on the handle and because, not being a tea drinker, had no idea that differing degrees of heated water was needed to make a good cup of tea.
I read ALL of the negative comments. And decided that I would make my own opinion and bought the item anyway.
I did not buy it from Amazon although I first came to the Amazon site, gained all the info on the product and all the comments pro and con.
I bought it from a local company because I decided if all the negative comments proved to be true, then I could take the kettle back to them, either get my money back or try another one and have no hassle. I checked with the manager to make sure that would be the case, and she said that so far they have not had any returned, although at the price Cuisinart asks, they do not sell many.
I've had it for exactly two days. It works like a charm. However, I do several things with this that I did with the other one. I do not need the 'keep warm' mode, so probably will never use it. I use a French press for coffee, but would not bother to take the time to use a thermometer to see if it was exactly 200. Picky to such an extreme seems petty to me.
I don't leave water in the container and pour it out after using what I want. I leave the top open so it will dry.
Thanks for all the negative comments because they, along with the sensible and reasonable positive ones, have given me much to watch for and to try and counter problems before they appear.
I will again write when I've owned it for a much longer period. Until then, I'm going to enjoy my new kettle.

reviews.reviewTitle: Defective kettle Keep Warm feature turns itself on.
reviews.reviewText: This kettle is horrible. The keep warm features kept turning itself on after I switch it off, to the point that it had damaged the base of my cabinet with steam. I called cuisinart and had the most bizarre customer service experience, the customer service representative listened to my complaint and then put me on hold, when he came back, the very versatile customer service rep. told me that he had 'plugged the kettle in and tested it in the lab and that it is defective as described'. He offered me a new kettle as it was under limited warranty, the new kettle would have cost me $30-. I declined and he said I could file a complaint with upstairs which I did, He would only take my phone number and not my email for this complaint and I was told I would be contacted in 3-4 days. Eight days later I still have not been contacted by upstairs, so I called again today and this time the rep. did not leave me on hold to run to the lab to test the kettle and I was offered a replacement for free. No thanks, I can't damage another cabinet. I filed another complaint with upstairs and will hear back in 3-4 days, maybe...

reviews.reviewTitle: this thing is sweet. It heats up water really fast (it seems ...
reviews.reviewText:
Yo, this thing is sweet. It heats up water really fast (it seems faster than if I did it on the stove), the buttons are way more handy than if you had to set the temperature manually, and it's kinda sexy. All stainless and stuff. Meeow.

It'd be a pain to clean, so don't be a moron and use it to cook soup. Seriously. That would be super dumb. It'd work, though. But it'd be dumb.

The labels are somewhat arbitrary. I use the 190 degree setting for French Press coffee all the time, but I use 200 for Aeropress. There's enough range to cover basically anything you're doing.

The instructions include a "history of tea" thing. How weird is that?

Also, when the protection circuit kicks in because you forgot to turn it off after emptying it, it's scary. You'll think you broke it. It clicks, the lights blink. It's a whole thing. But it's fine. It's supposed to do that, and it will bounce back.

But, yeah. This thing is sweet. Get one. Or buy something cheaper. I'm not trying to tell you how to live your life. This one's worth the money, though.

This tea kettle is solidly built and the variable temperatures are nice. But it has serious flaws. First, the keep-warm mode is the default and that's not how I typically use it: heat water, dispense, done. Instead, the default behavior is to keep heating the water, wasting electricity, until the kettle runs dry, then to make an alarm which could compete with a fire or security system and flash the lights as if it were an emergency requiring everyone's attention. The keep warm mode can be turned off, but it's easy to forget to do this. Another issue is it's slow. My previous heater, a Braun, was faster (it began leaking, however). Finally, it can be difficult to determine if it's on or not, as the main "heating" light gets stray illumination from surrounding lights.

So this heating is adequate, but it tries to do to much. What I want is 1. heat to the desired temperature. 2. beep once. 3. shut off unless I specifically requested keep warm, for example by multiple hits of the power button, or some other signal, 4. don't act like there's been a nuclear meltdown because you shut off the power.

reviews.reviewTitle: It was great for the nearly 2 years we had it. Then it broke down.
reviews.reviewText:
This was a pretty great kettle, up until tonight. Nearly 2 years since we bought it, it never failed us! It was easy to use, and made making the perfect cup of tea and coffee a snap! It's been getting a lot of use in the past 6 month, I use it for pre-boiling water to make oatmeal for the morning and for making pour-over coffee. It's used at least once a day. I normally don't fill it to the max line, but tonight I did. I noticed "air escaping" bubbles chortle away in the water window. I didn't think anything of it, until I picked up the kettle to pour water over the oatmeal for tomorrow... water started to leak from the bottom of the kettle! When I looked over at the base, a nice little puddle was sitting there.

SO, I expected more than two years out of this thing, so I'm a little disappointed. There is a three year limited warranty, if I can find the receipt, and it's not a hassle or expense to have it serviced, I will. If not, on to another brand.

Also of note, the labels on our most used buttons have worn off. Not the end of the world, if it wasn't leaking from the bottom.

WHAT AN UPGRADE! Prior to this water boiler, I had the same one for about 10 years... Yep, a plastic one... Probably leaching chemicals into each cup of tea I made. Anywho... I finally tossed it for this one and um, AMAZING!! You can boil to specific temperatures, boiling takes literally 60 seconds and the kettle will keep the water warm for about 20 minutes before turning off, yet the water will still stay warm for quite some time. This kettle also holds a lot of water too, so don't worry about having to fill it up 10 times in a row! Very impressed... Although I have to admit, I have never had a bad Cuisinart product before so I didn't really expect anything less than stellar!

reviews.reviewTitle: A good word from the office "Tea Lady"
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using my Cuisinart PerfecTemp Cordless Programmable Kettle for about 4 months and I absolutely love it. This kettle is definitely designed for practical tea lovers!

Every work day I steep a whole pot of tea (all different kinds) directly in the kettle. I scoop loose leaf tea into a pot-sized disposable tea bag, drop it into the water, push the button marked with the preset temperature for that day's variety, and just let it sit for a minute or two after the beep sounds before throwing the bag away. Then I can reheat the tea throughout the day as needed or pour over ice. I share with my co-workers, and everyone comments on how I have the best tea.

What makes it great is the variable temperature buttons, marked with the ideal temperature for each tea variety. I am generally not willing to spend time or energy fussing with getting exactly the right temperature if it's not ridiculously easy - but this does make it ridiculously easy, and it really makes a difference.

I previously had a different brand variable temperature kettle, and that one was such a quality disaster that it reminds me of why I love this one so much - this Cuisinart kettle is reliable, safe, easy to use, reasonably attractive, and does its job very well. No plasticy taste since it is all metal. Comfortable to hold and pour. Pop-open top stays securely shut when needed, but has an opening large enough for me to reach my hand in to clean. Beep sound is a good volume and not annoying. After reading a few reviews about electrical problems with this kettle, I have been looking out for that, but nothing so far. I'm trying to think if I can report on any negatives.....can't think of any. Enjoy!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Well Designed Electric Water Kettle - Exaclty the Right Feature Set!
reviews.reviewText: This review is for the Cuisinart CPK-17 Electric kettle. I was wasting a lot of time boiling water in a small pot then measuring and adjusting it sometimes reboiling the water till it was just right at the ideal 185 Deg temperature for coffee. So I got this kettle. I looked and researched hard as to what was out there. This kettle is really fast and quickly obtains and holds the temperature I set. It has a good set of choices for temperature settings for various teas and coffee. It holds the temperature well enough I think for most users. I Love it! Now there is no delay in fiddling with the water boiling it manually (which I do because I use the fantastic Aerobie AeroPress), I turn in on, come back in about 3 minutes for example let the dog out, come back and make my perfect AeroPress coffee without typical bitterness in abut 30 seconds to a minute. The best cup of coffee you have ever had or can make any way. See: Aeropress Coffee and Espresso Maker here on Amazon. I thought abut it a while as it is pricy. But so worth it. I was wasting precious minutes, 10 to 15 minutes every morning boiling the water and adjusting it. I needed something to make water for my fantastic Areobie AeroPress that I have been using for years. for the best coffee you can make. This is fast. I bought mine on sale as Macy's in the store with sale/discount. It is available here on Amazon at a good price. About $99.00 right now. It really is worth it if you are going to use it. I use it every day. So far no problems Had it a couple of months. I would recommend to others and buy this electric kettle again without hesitation. Very quick if you do not fill it up too much more than you need at one time. I fill to 1 or 1./1-2 major divisions. It has auto shutoff so if you run off to work and forget it it will take care of itself. Very stable and well designed. Stainless Steel water container. Kettle lifts off powered base which is a great feature. It swivels ion the base. Very good design. We will see how it lasts. But I have high expectations for this product from Cusinart. Not all Cuisinart is great, but many things are and I think this is one of those. better than most. I think it is a superior design to the other electric kettles I looked at.

reviews.reviewTitle: Finally a kettle for tea lovers!!! (5 Year update)
reviews.reviewText:
5 YEAR UPDATE: (4.5 to be exact)I still own this kettle and love it, surprised that nothing better has been invented yet. It's the only kitchen gadget that's been used heavily daily for so long without needing repairs or replacements. The build quality is still excellent, nothing is falling aparat. I didn't even clean it once and while there are plenty of mineral deposits on the outside, inside it looks clean. The reason I am looking for a new one is my current one started acting up. Occasionally, it would shut down half way during boil with "error" beeping sounds. I just push start again and it starts boiling. It may actually

UPDATED entire review on 9/12/2013 (Originally purchased and reviewed on August 2010)

We've owned Krups FLF2-J1 electric kettle for about 4 years and while it was doing the job I was desperately looking for something with selectable temperatures until I saw newly released CPK-17. While there were no reviews available at the time of the purchase I decided to try it out anyway and I was perfectly satisifed from the first cup of tea. We've been using it for over 3 years now and still enjoy the kettle as the day we got it. There is no rust on the kettle and all functions are working. What I like:

Blue led when in operation

Cap opens with a push of a button

Not so Great:
